revision.text:
{{Update|2012–2016|date=May 2016}} [[Image:CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Iran holds 10% of the world's proven [[oil reserves]] and 15% of its [[gas]]. It is [[OPEC]]'s second largest exporter and the world's fourth oil producer.]] [[File:Iran's Total Primary Energy Consumption in 2015.svg|thumb|250px|right|Total primary consumption in Iran, by fuel (2015).]] '''Energy in Iran''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption|energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption, import and export in [[Iran]]. Iran has the fourth largest [[oil reserves]] and the largest [[natural gas reserves]] in the world.{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2178rank.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020171232/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2178rank.html |archivedate=2012-10-20 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/statistical-review/statistical_review_of_world_energy_2013.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814004347/http://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/statistical-review/statistical_review_of_world_energy_2013.pdf |archivedate=2013-08-14 |df= }} [[Iran]] is an [[energy superpower]].{{cite book | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=CA1Cn8tDMv4C&pg=PA50 | title= Energy and the Iranian economy | agency = [[United States Congress]] | date = July 25, 2006 | accessdate= June 11, 2014}} ==History== Iran is in a constant battle to use its energy resources more effectively in the face of [[Iranian targeted subsidy plan|subsidization]] and the need for technological advances in energy exploration and production. Energy wastage in Iran amounts to six or seven billion dollars (2008). The energy consumption in the country is extraordinarily higher than international standards. Iran recycles 28 percent of its used oil and gas whereas the figure for certain countries stands at 60 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/08/oct/1303.html |title=Energy Wastage In Iran Equals 6-7 Billion Dallars Per Year |publisher=Payvand.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Iran paid $84 billion in subsidies for oil, gas and electricity in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm |accessdate=June 18, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612142508/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm |archivedate=June 12, 2008 }} Iran is one of the most energy-intensive countries of the world, with [[List of countries by energy consumption per capita|per capita energy consumption]] 15 times that of [[Japan]] and 10 times that of [[European Union]]. Also due to [[Iranian Economic Reform Plan#Subsidy reform plan|huge energy subsidies]], Iran is one of the most energy inefficient countries of the world, with the [[energy intensity]] three times higher than global average and 2.5 times the middle eastern average.{{cite web|last=Taghizadeh |first=Reza |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Sanctions_And_Irans_Achilles_Heel/2066744.html |title=Sanctions And Iran's Achilles Heel |publisher=Rferl.org |date=2010-06-10 |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Half of the country’s energy is wasted in domestic sector, 3.4 of which is wasted through [[single-occupancy vehicle]] use and 2/3 parts of [[List of power stations in Iran|power plants]]' energy are also wasted.http://en.mehrnews.com/detail/News/102219 Iran is one of the leading members of [[OPEC]] (Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) and the [[GECF|Organization of Gas Exporting Countries]] (GECF). Iran received $47 billion in oil export revenues, which accounts for about 50% of state revenues.BBC News, “Iran Energy: Overview”, http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4688984.stm, April 1, 2008. Natural gas and oil consumption both account for about half of Iran’s [[domestic energy consumption]]. With its heavy dependence on oil and gas revenues Iran continues to explore for new sources of natural gas and oil. Recently Iran has focused its energy sector on the exploration of the [[South Pars]] offshore natural gas fields in the [[Persian Gulf]].EIA, “Iran’s Energy Data”, {{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402152533/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }}, April 1, 2008. Iran has become self-sufficient in designing, building and operating dams and power plants and it has won a good number of international bids in competition with foreign firms.[http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3266/html/economy.htm ]{{dead link|date=February 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/10/mar/1073.html |title=Iran to build power plants in Ecuador |publisher=Payvand.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Energy generation capacity of Iranian thermal power plants reached 173 terawatt hours in 2007. Accounting for 17.9 percent of energy production in the Middle East and African region. Natural gas has been the main energy in Iran in 2007, comprising over 55 percent of energy needs, while oil and hydroelectricity accounted for 42 and 2 percent respectively. The region’s energy need will increase by 26.8 percent until 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3280/html/economy.htm |accessdate=November 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204232447/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3280/html/economy.htm |archivedate=December 4, 2008 }} Energy plays an important role in [[Politics of Iran|Iranian politics]]. [[Robert Baer]] in his book ''The Devil We Know: Dealing with the New Iranian Superpower'' argues that Iran has attained the status of an [[energy superpower]] and is on its way to become a military-political superpower.{{cite book|author=Robert Baer|title=The Devil We Know: Dealing with the New Iranian Superpower|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ztdT0tncFnUC|year=2008|publisher=Crown Publishers|isbn=978-0-307-40864-8}} ==Overview== Iran plans to create an [[energy saving company]] in conjunction with the [[Iranian subsidy reform plan]] (2014).http://iran-daily.com/newspaper/page/4836/4/14106/0 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |+ Energy in IranIEA Key World Energy Statistics Statistics [http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld_Statistics_2015.pdf 2015], [http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/keyworld2014.pdf 2014 (2012R as in November 2015] + 2012 as in March 2014 is comparable to previous years statistical calculation criteria, [http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2013.pdf 2013], [http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/kwes.pdf 2012], [http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2011/key_world_energy_stats.pdf 2011], [http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2010/key_stats_2010.pdf 2010], [http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2009/key2009.pdf 2009], [http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2006/key2006.pdf 2006] [[International Energy Agency|IEA]] October, crude oil p.11, coal p. 13 gas p. 15 |- ! ! Population
(million) ! Prim. energy
(TWh) ! Production
(TWh) ! Export
(TWh) ! Electricity
(TWh) ! CO2-emission
(Mt) |- | align="left" | 2004 || 67.0 || 1,696 || 3,233 || 1,530 || 137 || 369 |- | align="left" | 2007 || 71.0 || 2,151 || 3,757 || 1,602 || 165 || 466 |- | align="left" | 2008 || 72.0 || 2,350 || 3,801 || 1,429 || 174 || 505 |- | align="left" | 2009 || 72.9 || 2,514 || 4,068 || 1,537 || 168 || 533 |- | align="left" | 2010 || 73.97|| 2,423|| 4,060|| 1,574 || 196|| 509 |- | align="left" | 2012 || 74.80|| 2,467 || 4,113 || 1,614 || 200 || 521 |- | align="left" | 2012R || 76.42 || 2,554 || 3,523 || 961 || 210 || 532 |- | align="left" | 2013 || 77.45 || 2,656 || 3,477 || 649 || 224 || 526 |- | align="left" | Change 2004-10 || 10.4% || 42.9% || 25.6% || 2.9% || 43.0% || 37.8% |- | align="left" colspan=7 | Mtoe = 11.63 TWh, Prim. energy includes energy losses 2012R = CO2 calculation criteria changed, numbers updated |} ==Oil== {{Main|Petroleum industry in Iran|National Iranian Oil Company|Oil reserves in Iran}} {{See also|Ministry of Petroleum of Iran|2007 Gas Rationing Plan in Iran|National Iranian Petrochemical Company|Asalouyeh}} [[Image:Top Oil Producing Countries.png|thumb|Top oil-producing countries
(million barrels per day)]] Iran has the second largest oil reserves in the world, and the third largest exporter of it. According to 2006 estimates Iran produced about five percent of total global crude oil production. They produced {{convert|4.2|Moilbbl/d|m3/d}} of total liquids and 3.8 million of those barrels were crude oil. Iran plans to invest $100 billion during the next four years in different sections of its oil industry (2009).[http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=99089§ionid=351020103 PressTV:Iran invests $100b in oil industry in 4 years] Retrieved July 14, 2009 By the end of 2009, Iranian oil [[Reserves-to-production ratio|R/P ratio]] was 89.4 years which is the world's highest.{{cite web|url=http://www.bp.com/liveassets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2008/STAGING/local_assets/2010_downloads/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_report_2010.pdf |title=BP Statistical Review of World Energy |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825171459/http://www.bp.com/liveassets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2008/STAGING/local_assets/2010_downloads/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_report_2010.pdf |archivedate=2013-08-25 |df= }} By 2009, Iran had 52 active [[Oil platform|rigs]] and 1,853 producing [[oil well]]s.http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/ASB2009.pdf Iran possesses abundant [[fuels]] from which to generate energy. Since 1913 [[Iran]] has been a major oil-exporting country. Oil industry output averaged {{convert|4|Moilbbl|m3}} per day in 2005, compared with the peak output of {{convert|6|Moilbbl/d|m3/d}} reached in 1974. Following the 1979 [[Iranian Revolution|revolution]], however, the government reduced daily oil production in accordance with an oil conservation policy. Further production declines occurred as result of damage to oil facilities during the [[Iran–Iraq War|war with Iraq]]. In the early 2000s, industry infrastructure was increasingly inefficient because of technological lags. Few exploratory wells were drilled in 2005. Iranian oil was [[nationalization of the Iranian oil industry|nationalized in 1953]] and thus is owned and operated by the [[National Iranian Oil Company]] (NIOC). Iran held 10.3% of the world's total proven [[oil reserves]] and that figures out to be about {{convert|137.6|Goilbbl|m3}} of oil reserves at the end of 2009. Oil also is found in northern Iran and in the offshore waters of the [[Persian Gulf]]. Nevertheless, in 2005 Iran spent US$4 billion on [[gasoline]] imports, mainly because of [[contraband]] and inefficient domestic use that result from [[Ministry of Petroleum of Iran#Gasoline subsidies|subsidies]]. Iran is one of the largest [[gasoline]] consumers in the world ranking second behind [[United States]] in consumption per car.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-e-sabz.org/news/iranenv.html |title=Green Party of Iran - News |publisher=Iran-e-sabz.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} There is a growing recognition that prices must rise faster to curb consumption and ease the burden on the public finances. Cheap energy has encouraged wasteful consumption in Iran, and a brisk business in smuggling petrol into [[Iraq]], [[Turkey]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Afghanistan]]. Demand has also been supported by rapid increases in car production in recent years. In the absence of imports, [[Iranian automobile industry|the car industry]] has developed strongly (albeit from a low base) with output reaching over 1m vehicles in fiscal year 2006/07 (March 21 – March 20). [[File:Oil Balance Iran.svg|thumb|right|Iran oil production, domestic consumption and exports]] The growth in consumption of domestically produced oil has been modest, owing to [[National Iranian Oil Refining and Distribution Company|refining constraints]]. By contrast, fuel imports rose to {{convert|180000|oilbbl/d}} in January 2005 from {{convert|30000|oilbbl/d}} in 2000, and petrol consumption is estimated to have been around {{convert|1800000|oilbbl/d}} in 2007 (before [[rationing]]), of which about one-third is imported. These imports are proving expensive, costing the government about US$4bn in the first nine months of 2007/08, according to parliamentary sources. Nearly 40% of refined oil consumed by Iran is imported from [[India]].[http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0718/p25s05-usfp.html Does US road to better relations with Iran pass through India?], ''The Christian Science Monitor'', July 18, 2009 [[Image:USGS world oil endowment.png|thumb|right| A [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] map of countries where [[oil]] is located.]] Iran contains 27 onshore and 13 offshore oil-producing fields, largely concentrated in the southwestern [[Khuzestan]] region near the [[Iraq]]i border. The Iranian government is heavily reliant on oil revenues and they have heavily subsidized the energy industries, which figures out to be about 12% of Iran’s [[GDP]]. However, domestic oil consumption has decreased due to the alternative use of natural gas. Economic growth from these resources is uncertain and stunted in Iran due to these subsidies and population growth. Iran has been unable to reach it full production levels due to a combination of [[Economic sanctions|sanctions]] and war plaguing the region. Iran’s oil fields have a natural decline rate at 8 percent for onshore wells and 10% for offshore fields. The Iranian recovery rate is currently approximately 27 percent, which is well below the world average. Iran needs structural improvements made to coincide with their [[enhanced oil recovery]] efforts. ==Natural gas== {{Main|Natural gas reserves in Iran}} {{See also|National Iranian Gas Company|South Pars Gas Field}} [[File:Gas Balance Iran.svg|thumb|right|Iran's gas production, domestic consumption and exports]] Iran is the world's third producer of [[natural gas]] (5.1% of the world's total and 184 BCM); which is primarily used for domestic electricity generation or heat production.https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2016.pdf It contains an estimated {{convert|1187.3|e12cuft|km3}} (Tcf) in proven natural gas reserves. In 2005 a large share of Iran’s natural [[gas]] reserves were believed to remain untapped. About 62% of these reserves are located in non-associated fields. Iranian production of natural gas is expected to increase over the next few years due to continuing discoveries in the [[North Pars]] and [[South Pars]] regions.[[National Iranian Gas Company]] Domestic consumption has matched production at {{convert|3.6|e12cuft|km3|abbr=on}} in the year of 2005. Domestic consumption is expected to go up at about 7% per year for the following decade. The Iranian government has also subsidized natural gas prices along with [[gasoline]] prices, and this is expected to sustain this high level of domestic consumption. In lieu of this increasing domestic demand, natural gas exports are expected to decrease in the following years.EIA, [http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html Iran’s Energy Data] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402152533/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html |date=2009-04-02 }}, April 1, 2008 Iran has the third largest consumption of [[natural gas]] in the world after [[United States]] and [[Russia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2181rank.html?countryName=Iran&countryCode=ir®ionCode=me&rank=4#ir |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Iran also has the world's largest growth rate in natural gas consumption. ==Electricity== {{See also|List of reservoirs and dams in Iran|List of power stations in Iran|Ministry of Energy (Iran)}} [[File:Energy consumption per capita-Iran.png|thumb|right|Energy consumption in [[Iran]] is 6.5 times that of global average.[http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3374/html/economy.htm Iran daily:Energy Wastage Criticized] {{dead link|date=February 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Retrieved April 15, 2009 It is estimated that 18.5% of electricity generated in Iran is wasted before it reaches consumers due to technical problems. [[Electric power]] wastage hit $1.1 billion in 2006.]] {{Pie chart | caption= Electricity generation by fuel in Iran - 2012http://www.eia.gov/countries/cab.cfm?fips=IR | label1 = [[National Iranian Gas Company|natural gas]] | value1 = 69 | color1 = violet | label2 = [[National Iranian Oil Company|oil]] | value2 = 25 | color2 = red | label3 = [[List of dams in Iran|hydropower]] | value3 = 6 | color3 = green | label4 = non-hydro [[renewable energy|renewables]] (e.g. [[Wind power in Iran|wind]], [[List of power stations in Iran#Geothermal|geothermal]] or [[List of solar power stations|solar]]) | value4 = <1 | color4 = blue | label5 = [[Mining in Iran#Coal|coal]] | value5 = <1 | color5 = white }} [[File:Shazand Combined-cycle power plant.JPG|thumb|Shazand power plant]] Iran’s domestic consumption and production have steadily grown together since 1984 and it is still heavily reliant on traditional [[Thermal power station|thermal]] energy sources of electricity, with a small fraction being produced by [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]] plants.[http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3103/html/economy.htm#s295833 retrieved April 2, 2008.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012074726/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3103/html/economy.htm#s295833 |date=October 12, 2008 }} Consumption has steadily risen and it is expected to rise at about 6 percent per year for the following decade. Accordingly, the Iranian energy sector must focus its efforts on meeting this continuing demand. Today Iran ranks 19th largest producer and 20th largest consumer of electricity in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203093100/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |archivedate=2012-02-03 |df= }} A research by the [[Ministry of Energy (Iran)|Ministry of Energy]] indicated that between 15,000-20,000 megawatts of capacity should be added in [[Iran]] in the next 20 years.[http://iran-daily.com/1386/2814/html/national.htm Iran Daily - National - 04/11/07] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181550/http://iran-daily.com/1386/2814/html/national.htm |date=September 30, 2007 }} In recent years Iran has put greater emphasis on participation of domestic and foreign investors in electricity generation sector, with projects underway to add 40,000 MWh more capacity to the national grid.[http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/197642455.html ]{{dead link|date=February 2012}} It is estimated that some 18.5 percent of electricity generated in Iran are wasted before it reaches consumers due to technical problems.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3374/html/economy.htm |accessdate=April 15, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Iran is among the top ten manufacturers of [[gas turbine]]s with a capacity of 160 megawatts.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3402/html/economy.htm |accessdate=May 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521090141/http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3402/html/economy.htm |archivedate=May 21, 2009 }} Iranian experts of JEMCO (a subsidiary of [[Industrial Development and Renovation Organization of Iran|IDRO]]) have succeeded in developing the capacity to produce one-megawatt [[Electrical generator|generators]].{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=123039§ionid=351020103 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606135415/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=123039§ionid=351020103 |archive-date=2012-06-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Iran has acquired self-sufficiency of over 80 percent in constructing hydraulic turbines and over 90 percent in producing gas turbines. Within the next few years, Iran can join the list of countries that produce [[power plant]] technology (2009).{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3473/html/economy.htm |accessdate=August 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819023142/http://www.iran-daily.com/1388/3473/html/economy.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2009 }} Iran has achieved the technical expertise to set up hydroelectric, gas and combined cycle power plants.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=109957§ionid=351020103 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515214254/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=109957§ionid=351020103 |archive-date=2012-05-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Iran is not only self-sufficient in power plant construction but has also concluded a number of contracts on implementing projects in neighboring states.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=124967§ionid=351020103 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606135335/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=124967§ionid=351020103 |archive-date=2012-06-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3103/html/economy.htm#s295833 Iran-Daily:Hydroelectric Power Generation Will Increase] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012074726/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3103/html/economy.htm#s295833 |date=October 12, 2008 }} The exploration efforts for sources of power generation are wide and diverse in Iran. Plans are being made to make oil efficient power plants as well as an emphasis on natural gas production in order to meet their growing electricity demand. [[Nuclear power]] and hydroelectric power are not focused on for the time being, but they are part of an overall strategy to meet electricity demands. The electricity sector is also heavily subsidized and mostly state owned companies control power distribution, transmission and generation. In order to meet the demands of the electricity sector, however, Iran is beginning to look into private investment.EIA, “Iran’s Energy Data”, {{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402152533/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Background.html |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }}, Retrieved April 2, 2008 [[Foreign Direct Investment in Iran#FIPPA|A by-law]] has been passed allowing the energy ministry to conclude rial or combined rial/foreign-currency contracts for the purchase of electricity from private companies. Private companies in Iran generated 14,440 megawatts of electricity in 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=115682§ionid=351020103 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527130330/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=115682§ionid=351020103 |archive-date=2012-05-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Although some criticize Iran's hydroelectric power plans as potentially dangerous to the environment, most agree that the country's current state of hydroelectric production is much better off than in the past. Iran has displayed a new approach to this sector. After the 1979 Islamic Revolution, the construction of hydroelectric power plants became both a popular private and public venture. Often, construction projects did not meet basic environmental standards, engineering standards, and technical requirements. As a result, many of these dams were destroyed or left in dilapidated conditions.International Journal of Water Resources Development; Mar2002, Vol. 18 Issue 1, p179-182, 4p [[Image:Karun3-dam.jpg|thumb|The [[Karun-3 dam]] & [[hydroelectric power plant]] in Iran was commissioned in 2005. Iran has emerged as one of the world's largest [[dam]] builders in recent years.[http://www.iran-daily.com/1385/2771/html/economy.htm Iran Daily - Domestic Economy - 02/01/07] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183642/http://www.iran-daily.com/1385/2771/html/economy.htm |date=September 30, 2007 }}]] By 2004, the addition of new hydroelectric stations and the streamlining of conventional [[coal]]- and [[oil]]-fired stations increased installed capacity to 33,000 megawatts (MW). Of that amount, about 75 percent was based on [[natural gas]], 18 percent on [[oil]], and 7 percent on [[hydroelectric power]]. However, in 2004 Iran opened its first [[wind]]-powered and [[Geothermal power|geothermal]] plants, and the first solar thermal plant was to come online in 2009. Iran has recoverable coal reserves of nearly 1.9bn short tonnes. The country produces about 1.3m short tonnes of coal annually and consumes about 1.5m short tonnes, making it a small net importer of coal. [[Demographics of Iran|Demographic trends]] and intensified industrialization have caused electric power demand to grow by 8 percent per year. The government’s goal of 53,000 megawatts of installed capacity by 2010 is to be reached by bringing on line new gas-fired plants financed by independent power producers, including those with [[foreign direct investment|foreign investment]] backing, and by adding hydroelectric and nuclear power generating capacity. It has also been estimated that Iran has the potential to produce at least 6,150 MWh of electricity by [[Wave power]] from its coastline on [[Persian Gulf]] alone.{{cite web|url=http://www.civilica.com/EnPaper-NSMI07-NSMI07_068.html |title=Study on feasibility of establishing a wave power-plant in Persian Gulf |publisher=Civilica.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Iran is also experimenting with electricity generation from organic wastes and plans to build power plants using sewage and organic waste of domestic and industrial origin as fuel.{{cite web|author=Suna |url=http://www.suna.org.ir/projectdetail-fa-28.html |title=مطالعه امکان سنجی و طراحی مفهومی نیروگاه بیوگاز ساوه سازمان انرژی های نو ایران |publisher=Suna.org.ir |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Another area in which there is ongoing research is assessment of Iran's [[tidal power]] potential.{{cite web|url=http://unjobs.org/tags/tidal-power |title=Tidal Power |publisher=Unjobs.org |date=2003-11-13 |accessdate=2012-02-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.civilica.com/Paper-NSMI08-NSMI08_072.html |title=Study and calculation of extractable tidal power in south coastal zones of Iran |publisher=Civilica.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} With about 300 clear sunny days a year and an average of 2,200 kilowatt-hour [[solar radiation]] per square meter, Iran has a great potential to tap [[solar energy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20101220044922 |title=Solar Power Plants To Replace Fossil Fuel |publisher=Zawya |date=2010-12-20 |accessdate=2012-02-05}} ==Nuclear energy== {{Main|Nuclear program of Iran|Atomic Energy Organization of Iran|Nuclear facilities in Iran}} [[File:Arak heavy water reactor2.JPG|thumb|left|[[IR-40]] facility in [[Arak, Iran|Arak]]]] Iran plans to generate 23,000 MWh of electricity through nuclear technology by 2025 to meet its increasing demand for energy.{{cite web |url=http://www.irvl.net/iran-and-nuclear-energy/ |title=Iran and Nuclear Energy |publisher=Irvl.net |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215143412/http://www.irvl.net/iran-and-nuclear-energy/ |archivedate=2010-12-15 |df= }} The first of four 915 MW reactors of [[Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant]], built with help from [[Russia]], came online in August 2010{{cite web |author=PRIS.Contact-Point@iaea.org |url=http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=IR&refno=1 |title=Power Reactor Details - BUSHEHR 1 |publisher=Iaea.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826050714/http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=IR&refno=1 |archivedate=2010-08-26 |df= }} after numerous delays and Iran's indigenously designed [[Darkhovin Nuclear Power Plant]] is scheduled to come online in 2016. Overall, Iran remains a [[International rankings of Iran#Energy|net exporter of electricity]] and exchanges electrical power with all its land neighbors.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/141402.html |title=PressTV - Iran exports 5.5 bn kWh of electricity |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=2010-09-06 |accessdate=2012-02-05}} While nuclear power in the US costs a little over 10 cents per kilowatt hour, Iran, with domestic uranium enrichment capabilities, high interest rates, low energy output (a single 1,000-watt reactor), low efficiency, extremely slow reactor construction, and no reprocessing pays around 68 cents per kilowatt hour (this assumes a price of $140 per separative working unit and of $40 per kilogram of uranium).http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/Iran-s-nuclear-program-has-been-an-astronomical-6359024.php {{clear}} ==Energy forecast== {{see also|Economy of Iran|Demography of Iran}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Source: B.M.I{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/11/apr/1007.html |title=Iran to Account for 14.79% of MEA Power Generation by 2015: BMI |publisher=Payvand.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} !! 2010 !! 2015 est. !! 2010-15 growth !! 2015-20 growth !! 2010-20 growth!! Remarks |- | [[MENA]]-Power generation|| 1,222 TWh || 1,518 TWh|| +24.2% || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || where markets were depressed by the economic slowdown in 2009. |- | MENA-Thermal power generation || 1.140 TWh (93.3% of total electricity supplied in the region) || 1,378 TWh (90.8% of total electricity supplied in the region) || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}}|| {{N/A}}|| thanks in part to environmental concerns that should be promoting renewables, hydro-electricity and nuclear generation. |- | MENA-Energy demand || {{N/A}} || 1117 tonnes of oil equivalent (toe) || +20.8% || {{N/A}}|| {{N/A}}|| {{N/A}} |- | MENA-Nuclear demand || {{N/A}} || ~25 TWh || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Real GDP growth|| {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || 2% per year (average)|| {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Population || 73.9 million || 78.6 million || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-GDP per capita growth || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || +31% || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Electricity consumption per capita || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || +5% || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Power consumption || 161 TWh || 179 TWh || 2.2% per year (average) || {{N/A}}|| {{N/A}} || a broadly balanced market |- | IRAN-Electricity generation || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || +12.2% || +11.9%|| +25.5% || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Thermal generation || 192 TWh (16.85% of MENA's market share) || (14.45% of MENA's market share) || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-[[World energy consumption#Primary energy|Primary Energy Demand]] (PED) & Growth || 37.8% (gas), 40.4% (oil), 0.8% (hydro) || {{N/A}} || +14.4% || +12.6% || +28.8% || {{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Energy demand || 22.38% (Iran's MENA market share) || 21.21% (Iran's MENA market share)|| {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}}||{{N/A}} |- | IRAN-Nuclear demand || 0 || 10 TWh (38.46% of MENA's market share) || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} || [[Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant]] set to go online in 2011. Nuclear power is one key element of generation growth. |} ==Renewable energy== {{See also|Iranian targeted subsidy plan}} [[Image:Manjeel windmills.jpg|thumb|right|As a further drive toward diversification of energy sources, Iran has established wind farms in several areas, this one near [[Manjeel]].]] In 2010, the [[Iranian government]] announced plans to build 2,000MW of renewable energy capacity between 2010-2015. As of 2010, Iran had 8,500MW of hydroelectric capacity and 130MW of wind energy capacity. As at 2010, private companies had signed contracts to build more than 600MW of [[biomass]] systems and 500MW of new [[wind energy]] projects.http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Energy-Voices/2012/0910/Invest-in-Iran-s-renewable-energy-Not-so-crazy Iran is also working to make [[renewable energy]] commercially viable and the [[Ministry of Energy (Iran)|Ministry of Energy]] is required to buy privately produced renewable energy at world market prices. A feed-in-tariff ([[FiT]]) for wind and biomass energy around 13 cents/kWh is helpful. In 2012, Iran allocated €500 million from the [[National Development Fund]] for renewable energy projects. Also supporting the solar industry is the state-sponsored [[Renewable Energy Organization of Iran]] (SUNA), which is attached to the Energy Ministry and enjoys a budget of around $60 million. ===Hydro=== {{See also|List of dams and reservoirs in Iran}} [[Hydropower]] makes up 10,000 megawatts or 14% of Iran’s overall energy mix (2015).http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2015/07/23/421482/iran-electricity-turbine-power- Iran is able to build its [[Francis turbine|water turbine]]s domestically. ===Biofuel=== In 2016, the [[Iranian Biofuel Society (IBS)]] in collaboration with the Vice Presidency for Science of Technology and Tehran and the Suburbs Bus Company executed the first urban pilot project for the consumption of waste cooking oil biodiesel in Tehran`s bus fleet in an attempt to generate public awareness regarding ''Global Climate Change'', wherein they recommend “reducing net [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] [[CO2]] emissions to the atmosphere” and “minimizing anthropogenic disturbances of” atmospheric gasses by partial replacement of fossil fuels with waste-oriented biofuels.{{cite web| title= تفاهم نامه استفاده از سوخت های زیستی در اتوبوسرانی تهران امضا شد| url= http://www.irna.ir/fa/News/81895032/}} The program was also supported by Small Grant Programme, [[Global Environmental Facility]], United Nation Development Program (SGP/GEF/UNDP) Office in Iran.{{cite web| title= UNDP-GEF Small Grant Programme| url= http://www.sgp.undp.org}} ===Solar=== {{main|Solar power in Iran|List of solar thermal power stations}} Iran's unique geographical position means 90% of the country has enough sun to generate [[solar power]] 300 days a year. According to [[PressTV]] Iran has 520 watts per hour per square meter of solar radiation every day. Other sources give an average of 2,200 kilowatt-hour [[solar radiation]] per square meter.{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20101220044922 |title=Solar Power Plants To Replace Fossil Fuel |publisher=Zawya |date=2010-12-20 |accessdate=2012-02-07}} Energy generated by solar power reached 53 MW in 2005 and 67 MW in 2011.http://presstv.com/Program/251519.html ===Wind=== {{main|Wind power in Iran}} Iran has the potential to generate 20 to 30 GW of [[wind energy]]. That is half of the total energy consumption needs of the country. As at 2012 Iran had 163 [[wind turbine]]s with an installed capacity of 92470 kWh. [[Sadid Industrial Group]] is a well known domestic manufacturer in this field. India's [[Sulzon Energy]] and Germany's [[Siemens]] are also potential providers of [[wind turbine]]s to Iran. ===Geothermal=== Iran has the potential to become the 9th largest [[geothermal energy]] producer. According to global tectonics Iran is impacted by subduction of the Arabian Plate under the Central Iranian Plate and four thrust faults: two that make the Southern Caspian Sea Depression and two in the north of Iran, part of the Caucasian Range. Mt. Sabalan and Mt. Sahand are two Quaternary Volcanos in the area. Sabalan is a large stratovolcano consisting of 3 summits named Soltan (4811), Heram (4612m) and Kasra (4573m). The stratovolcano is situated on a possible horst trending northeast-southwest and erupted at latest in the Holocene. Caldera collapsing has caused a depression about 400 m in height and 12 km in diameter. The lava flows consists of trachyandesite, andesite and dacite and pyroclastic deposits. There are 9 hot springs with a temperature in the range of 25-85°C. https://www.geothermal-energy.org/pdf/IGAstandard/WGC/2005/0607.pdf ==Statistics== Source: [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html CIA factbook], unless stated otherwise. ===[[World energy resources and consumption|Primal Energy Demand]]=== * ''gas:'' 55% (2008){{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3323/html/economy.htm#s358839 |accessdate=February 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001021913/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3323/html/economy.htm |archivedate=October 1, 2009 }} * ''oil:'' 42% (2008) * ''hydro:'' 2% (2008) ===Electricity=== * ''production:'' 220.3 billion kWh (2011 est.)https://web.archive.org/web/20100612004113/http://iranyellowpages.net/en/about_iran/Economy/electricity_industry/electricity_industry01.shtm * ''consumption:'' 182.7 billion kWh (2010 est.) * ''exports:'' 6.707 billion kWh (2010 est.) * ''imports:'' 3.015 billion kWh (2010 est.) ===Electricity – production by source=== * ''fossil fuel:'' 93% (75% comes from gas generation, 18% from oil) (2006); 86.2% of total installed capacity (2010 est.){{Refimprove|date=October 2017}} * ''hydro:'' 7% (2006); 13.7% of total installed capacity (2010 est.){{Refimprove|date=October 2017}} * Nuclear power: 2.1% [[Nuclear power by country]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=December 2017}} ===[[Ministry of Petroleum of Iran|Oil]]=== * ''production:'' {{convert|3589000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} (2012 est.){{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook - Iran |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203093100/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |archivedate=2012-02-03 |df= }} * ''consumption:'' {{convert|1755000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} (2008 est.) (expected to increase 10% each year since 2006) * ''exports:'' {{convert|2377000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} (2010 est.) * ''imports:'' {{convert|156000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} (2010 est.) * ''proved reserves:'' {{convert|154.6|Goilbbl|abbr=on}} based on Iranian claims (1 January 2009 est.) ''note:'' as of 2009, 1/3 of Iran's gasoline needs are imported because of insufficient domestic refining capacity, over-consumption and [[contraband]].{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Oil.html#Gasoline%20Imports |title=Iran Energy Data, Statistics and Analysis - Oil, Gas, Electricity, Coal |publisher=Eia.doe.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331224530/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/Oil.html#Gasoline%20Imports |archivedate=2008-03-31 |df= }} ===[[National Iranian Gas Company|Natural gas]]=== * ''production:'' 151.8 billion cu m (2011 est.) * ''consumption:'' 144.6 billion cu m (2010 est.) * ''exports:'' 9.05 billion cu m (2011 est.) * ''imports:'' 10.59 billion cu m (2011 est.) * ''proved reserves:'' 33.61 trillion cu m (1 January 2013 est.) ===Subsidies=== {{See also|Iranian targeted subsidy plan}} * $84 billion for oil, gas and electricity (2008)[http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm Iran Daily - Domestic Economy - 04/27/08] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612142508/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm |date=June 12, 2008 }} ===Environment=== {{See also|Environmental issues in Iran}} * ''CO2 emissions per capita (mt):'' 624.9 million Mt (2011 est.) * ''GDP per unit of energy use:'' 4.0 (2007){{Citation| first= | last=| coauthors=| contribution=Iran at a glance| title=Development Economics, Development Data Group (DECDG).| editor-first=| editor-last=| publisher=[[World Bank]]| place=| pages=| date=27 March 2009| year=| id= | contribution-url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTIRAN/Resources/Iran_AAG_March09.pdf | format=| accessdate=2009-07-12| editors= }} * ''Energy use per capita (kg of oil equivalent)'' (2005 PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent): 2,352 (2007) ==See also== {{Portal|Iran|Energy|Renewable energy|Environment}} *[[Economy of Iran]] *[[Energy development]] *[[International rankings of Iran]] *[[Ministry of Energy (Iran)]] *[[Oil megaprojects (2011)]] *[[Wind power in Iran]] *[[The nationalization of the Iran oil industry movement]] *[[List of renewable energy topics by country|Renewable energy by country]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Energy in Iran}} *{{en icon}} [https://www.moe.gov.ir/ Ministry of Energy Of Iran] - Official Website *{{en icon}} [http://www.satba.gov.ir/en/home Renewable Energy & Energy Efficiency Organization Of Iran ] - Official Website *{{en icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20081216011637/http://www.mefa.gov.ir/ Ministry of Economic Affairs and Finance Of Iran] - Official Website *{{en icon}} [http://www.en.mimt.gov.ir/ Ministry of Industry , Mine & Trade Of Iran] – Official Website *[http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/country/country_energy_data.cfm?fips=IR Iran Energy Profile] - [[International Energy Agency]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080723090455/http://www.austrade.gov.au/Agribusiness-to-Iran/default.aspx Annual Reviews] - Reports by the [[Central Bank of Iran]], including statistics about the energy sector in Iran. *[http://www.eia.gov/countries/country-data.cfm?fips=IR&trk=p1 US Department of Energy - Iran] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928000332/http://www.atiehbahar.com/Resources/Environment.htm Brief Sector & Environment Study] (2003) *[http://www.ensec.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=159:energysecurityimplicationsofaniranintransition&catid=83:middle-east&Itemid=324 Energy Security Implications of an Iran in Transition] *[http://www.tavanir.org.ir Tavanir] - Iran's Electric Power Generation Organization *[http://www.iags.org/iran121206.pdf Ahmadinejad's Gas Revolution: A Plan to Defeat Economic Sanctions] *[http://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/publications/PDF/cnpp2004/CNPP_Webpage/pages/..%5Ccountryprofiles%5CIran%5CIran2003.htm IAEA: Energy and electricity in Iran] (2002) *[http://solargis.com/products/maps-and-gis-data/free/download/iran Solar insolation maps] ;Videos *[http://presstv.com/Program/251519.html Renewable Energy in Iran] - [[PressTV]] (2012) *[http://www.presstv.com/Program/221733.html Iran's energy bourse] - PressTV (2012) {{Energy in Iran|state=expanded}} {{Energy in OPEC}} {{OPEC}} {{Asia topic|Energy in}}{{Renewable energy by country}}{{Middle East topic|Energy in}} {{Middle East topic|Energy policy of}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Energy In Iran}} [[Category:Energy in Iran| ]]

The [[Bayer designation]]s '''j Puppis''' and '''J Puppis''' are distinct. Due to [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (technical restrictions)#Lower case first letter|technical limitations]], both designations link here. For the star
*j Puppis, see [[11 Puppis]] *J Puppis, see [[HD 64760]]
==See also== [[QW Puppis]] (I Puppis)

revision.text:
{{advert|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox organization |image = LCEC Logo 2009-Present.jpg |name = Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC) |formation = 2002 |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Beirut]] {{flagicon|Lebanon}} |location = |leader_title = President/Director |leader_name = Pierre El Khoury |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |leader_title3 = |leader_name3 = |main_organ = |num_staff = |website = http://lcecp.org.lb }}
The '''Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC)''' is the national [[energy]] agency for Lebanon. LCEC is a governmental organization affiliated to the Lebanese Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW). LCEC is the technical arm of the Ministry in all subjects related to [[energy conservation|energy efficiency]], [[renewable energy]], and [[green buildings]].<ref name="intro">MED-DESIRE. (2015). LCEC. Retrieved from: http://www.med-desire.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=129&Itemid=687&lang=en</ref>
LCEC has succeeded in establishing itself as the main national reference on sustainable energy in [[Lebanon]]. It is the leading provider of energy efficiency and renewable energy programs to the public and private sectors in Lebanon. LCEC offers expertise and support to the Government of Lebanon (GoL) to develop and implement national strategies towards saving energy, saving money, reducing [[greenhouse gas]] emissions with the final target being to improve durability, safety and comfort of the Lebanese population.<ref name="intro1">Pierre El Khoury. (2013). Insights on the Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Development in Lebanon. Retrieved from: http://www.institutdesfinances.gov.lb/english/pdf/Pierre%20Khoury-CHEDE%20MED%20Presentation-%20050613.pdf</ref>
LCEC is a financially and administratively independent organization and operates under the direct supervision of the Minister of Energy and Water. LCEC has been an independent national organization ever since 2011. Actually, LCEC is registered at [[Ministry of Interior and Municipalities (Lebanon)|the Lebanese Ministry of Interior and Municipalities]] in January 2011. However, the actual work of LCEC started back in 2005 when it was initiated as a joint project between the Ministry of Energy and Water and [[United Nations Development Programme|the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)]] Lebanon.<ref name="intro3">Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation Project. (2013). About Us. Retrieved from: http://www.lcecp.org.lb/aboutus.php?i=1</ref>
==Overview==
LCEC is the technical arm of the government of Lebanon working towards institutionalizing all national efforts to: * Improve and raise awareness energy efficiency in the main sectors of the economy. * Encourage the use of renewable energy technologies through technical and policy support. * Provide reliable data on energy demand patterns and distribution. * Produce measurable and sustainable global benefits in terms of long-term [[Greenhouse gas|greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions]] reductions.<ref name="intro3"/>
It tries to reduce greenhouse gases emissions by: * Providing business and the public sector with expert advice, finance and accreditation. * Stimulating demand for energy efficiency and renewable energy products through developing national awareness campaigns. * Developing energy efficiency standards and labels. * The creation and support of [[Energy service company|Energy Services Companies (ESCOs)]]. * Establishing partnerships with public and private sectors. * Representing Lebanon in international energy efficiency and renewable energy associations. * Providing a national energy database. * Promoting the [[Clean Development Mechanism|Clean Development Mechanism (CDM)]] for [[carbon offsets]].<ref name="intro3"/>
==History== Back in 2002, the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW) and United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in signed an agreement to create a new project called “Cross-sectoral energy efficiency and removal of barriers to ESCO operation”. The project was co-funded by [[The Global Environment Facility|the Global Environment Facility (GEF)]] and the Ministry of Energy and Water and under the direct management of UNDP Lebanon.<ref name="intro"/>
One main objective of this project was to create a national energy agency for Lebanon to be called the Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC). The project team started its operation in early 2005, and gradually the project name changed to LCEC. The LCEC project succeeded in implementing a number of activities to push for energy efficiency development in Lebanon. Gradually, LCEC gradually established itself as an independent technical national center offering the Lebanese Government and more specifically the Ministry of Energy and Water all kinds of services dedicated to energy efficiency and renewable energy.<ref name="intro1"/>
The role of the LCEC project was consolidated as an independent technical national center in the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) that signed between MEW and UNDP on 18 June 2007. GEF and UNDP extended their support to the LCEC in 2009 until the end of 2013.
In 2011, LCEC finally achieved to stand out as an independent organization affiliated to the Ministry of Energy and Water and is now financially and administratively independent. LCEC operates under the direct supervision of the Lebanese Minister of Energy and Water.
In 2013, the financial and administrative support of GEF and UNDP to LCEC came to an end. During that same year, LCEC received its first financial support from the Lebanese Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW). The MEW support ensured the sustainability of the center for a minimum of 5 years. LCEC also benefits from the support of the European Union (EU) through a contract signed with the Central Bank of Lebanon (BDL).<ref name="intro"/>
== What Does LCEC Do? == LCEC has established itself as a technical point of reference specialized in [[energy conservation]] issues within the Lebanese Ministry of Energy and Water. LCEC targets fundamental energy issues.<ref name="intro"/>
LCEC works on setting national strategies and action plans to be adopted by the Lebanese Government. LCEC also works on the implementation and the quality control of national projects and initiatives in the country. Moreover, LCEC is involved in the update and development of the legal and administrative framework needed for the greening of the energy sector. Until date, LCEC has implemented numerous energy efficiency and renewable energy projects and initiatives that have resulted in many positive changes within the Lebanese society and economy.<ref name="intro3"/>
The main driver of the LCEC is the National Energy Efficiency Action Plan (NEEAP) that summarizes the national efforts in energy efficiency and renewable energy. At [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference|the 2009 Copenhagen Climate Summit]], Lebanon voluntarily pledged to increase the renewable energy share to 12% by 2020. This voluntary commitment was anchored within the “Policy Paper for the Electricity Sector” prepared by the Ministry of Energy and Water and officially adopted by the Council of Ministers in June 2010. The policy paper includes ten strategic initiatives for the improvement of infrastructure, supply and demand systems and the definition of legal framework. Two key initiatives target respectively the renewable energy and the demand side management/ energy efficiency.
Following this, LCEC developed the NEEAP Lebanon 2011-2015 which was adopted in August 2010 by the Ministry of Energy and Water and approved in November 2011 by the Lebanese Government. NEEAP summarizes all national objectives, programmes and policies in 14 independent but correlated initiatives in the energy efficiency and renewable energy sectors. NEEAP was prepared in conformance with the Arab EE guideline (based on the EU directive 2006/32/EC on energy end-use efficiency and energy service) and Lebanon was the first Arab country to officially adopt such plan. LCEC is currently updating the NEEAP while preparing the Renewable Energy Strategy for Lebanon that will include several scenarios in achieving the set target of 12% RE by 2020 and that will also be in accordance with the Arab renewable energy guideline under preparation.<ref>MED-ENEC. (2015). Lebanese Council of Ministers Approves Lebanon’s National Energy Efficiency Action Plan. Retrieved from: http://www.med-enec.com/news/lebanese-council-ministers-approves-lebanon%E2%80%99s-national-energy-efficiency-action-plan-neeap</ref>
Moreover, LCEC provides both the public and private sector with expert advice, finance and accreditation, develops energy efficiency standards and labels, and provides national energy database indicators.<ref name="intro3"/>
==Partnerships== The work of LCEC is characterized by various partnerships with national and international private and public entities.
the Ministry of Energy and Water is the central public organization in charge of the energy sector in Lebanon. LCEC is affiliated to the Ministry of Energy and Water in all major decisions, initiatives and projects related to energy efficiency and renewable energy.
LCEC is also the technical partner of the [[Banque du Liban|Central Bank of Lebanon]] (BDL) in the review and evaluation of all technical applications to low-interest energy loans submitted to BDL.
==Policy Development== At the 2009 Copenhagen Climate Summit, Lebanon voluntarily pledged to increase the renewable energy shares to 12% by 2020. This voluntary commitment was anchored within the “Policy Paper for the Electricity Sector” prepared by the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW) and officially adopted by the Council of Ministers in June 2010: it includes ten strategic initiatives for the improvement of infrastructure, supply and demand systems and the definition of legal framework. Two key initiatives target respectively the Renewable Energy and the Demand Side Management / Energy Efficiency.
===National Energy Efficiency Action Plan=== Following the “Policy Paper for the Electricity Sector” prepared by the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW) and officially adopted by the Council of Ministers in June 2010, LCEC developed the National Energy Efficiency Action Plan 2011-2015 for Lebanon (NEEAP) to achieve the national target of 12% renewable energy share by 2020. NEEAP summarizes all national objectives, programmes and policies in 14 initiatives in the energy efficiency and renewable energy sectors. The initiatives of the NEEAP are the following: * Initiative 1: Towards Banning the Import of [[Incandescent lamp|Incandescent Lamps]] to Lebanon * Initiative 2: Adoption of the Energy Conservation Law and Institutionalization of the Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC) as the National Agency for Lebanon * Initiative 3: Promotion of Decentralization Power Generation by [[Photovoltaics|PV]] and Wind Applications in the Residential and Commercial Sectors * Initiative 4: [[Solar water heater|Solar Water Heaters]] for Buildings and Institutions * Initiative 5: Design and implementation of a national strategy for efficient and economic public street Lighting in Lebanon * Initiative 6: Electricity Generation from [[Wind Power]] * Initiative 7: Electricity Generation from [[Solar Energy]] * Initiative 8: [[Hydropower|Hydro Power]] for Electricity Generation * Initiative 9: [[Geothermal energy in Lebanon]], [[Waste-to-energy|Waste to Energy]], and Other Technologies * Initiative 10: [[Building Code]] for Lebanon * Initiative 11: Financing Mechanisms and Incentive * Initiative 12: Awareness and Capacity Building * Initiative 13: Paving the Way for [[Energy audit|Energy Audit]] and ESCO Business * Initiative 14: Promotion of Energy Efficient Equipment<ref name="NEEAP">Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency. (2011). the National Energy Efficiency Action Plan (NEEAP) for Lebanon. Retrieved from: http://www.rcreee.org/content/national-energy-efficiency-action-plan-neeap-lebanon</ref>
===NEEAP 2012-2020, NREAP and RES=== LCEC is currently updating and developing the NEEAP 2015-2020 while preparing the Renewable Energy Strategy (RES) and the National Renewable Energy Action Plan (NREAP) for Lebanon. The Lebanese NEEAP was prepared in conformance with the Arab EE guideline (based on the EU directive 2006/32/EC on energy end-use efficiency and energy service) and Lebanon was the first Arab country to officially adopt such plan.<ref name="NEEAP"/>
== Pilot projects ==
The activities of the Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC) expand to the implementation of pilot projects in the energy efficiency and renewable energy sector. Through grants, donations, and partnerships, LCEC was successful in implementing different pilot projects and is currently working on the implementation of many others. Pilot projects help initiate a new momentum in the market, and most importantly offer an opportunity to benefit from the lessons learnt.
===2006: 500 solar water heaters===
The [[Chinese government]] donated 500 solar water heaters to be installed in the liberated areas in [[South Lebanon]]. The Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC) was assigned by the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW) to support its installation both technically and financially. The workload consisted of handling all project logistics, hosting Chinese experts to conduct an intensive training workshop, assisting in the selection of beneficiaries.<ref>Paving the Way for the Mediterranean Solar Plan. (2011). Benchmarking of existing practice against EU norms. Retrieved from: {{cite web |url=http://www.pavingtheway-msp.eu/index.php?option=com_downloads&task=category&cid=7&Itemid=56 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902194052/http://www.pavingtheway-msp.eu/index.php?option=com_downloads&task=category&cid=7&Itemid=56 |archivedate=2013-09-02 |df= }}</ref>
In addition to the above, a sum of 112,500 USD was raised to cater for the installation of the units.
Unfortunately and as a result of the July war in Lebanon, 200 solar units were destroyed. In this regards, and after the impressive success of the project, LCEC has followed up with the Chinese Embassy to provide Lebanon with similar donation due to its direct results on the beneficiaries. This could be achieved and will be offered under the second phase of the project.<ref name="ST">Solar Thermal World. (2009). Assessment of Energy and Financial Performance of a Solar Hot Water System in a Single Family Dwelling: Case Study from Marjeyoun- South Lebanon. Retrieved from: http://www.solarthermalworld.org/sites/gstec/files/LCEC%20SWH%20DWELLING.pdf</ref>
====Project information==== *Date of implementation: Q3 2006 *Donation: 500 solar water heaters *Type of donation: in-kind *Application type: evacuated tube solar water heaters *Beneficiaries: 417 residences and public health centers *Areas covered: liberated areas in South Lebanon *Role of LCEC: technical agency
====Achievements==== *Collection area: 1,270 sq. meters *Annual energy production: 1,018 MWh *Annual energy cost saving (consumer side): $71,000 *Annual energy cost saving (EDL side): $326,000 *Annual GHG emissions reduction: 848 tons CO2
====Implemented by==== *[[Kypros]] *Falcon Win Trading *Ghaddar Industry *Tfaily Solar *Mihsen Reda Co.<ref name="ST"/>
===2008: Solar water heaters for not-for-profit facilities===
The United Nations Development Program, through its Energy and Environment Programme, with the funding of [[Swedish International Development Agency|the Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA)]], has launched a pilot project to install solar water heaters at public / NGO facilities in selected damaged areas of Beirut, Bekaa & South Lebanon due to July 2006 war. Under the supervision of the Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation (LCEC), the project consisted of installing 93 individual (natural circulation) solar water heaters, and 11 collective (forced circulation) solar water heaters, covering a total of 1,040 square meters of collection area. The solar water heating units were executed by three qualified firms through an international bid, and divided into 5 lots.<ref>Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation Project. (2013).Pilot Projects. Retrieved from: http://www.lcecp.org.lb/pilotprojects.php?li=5&pproject=1</ref>
====Project information==== *Date of implementation: Q1 2008 *Donation: 104 solar water heating systems (11 Collective & 93 Individual) *Type of donation: cash *Application type: individual and collective solar water heating systems *Beneficiaries: 104 hospitals, orphanages, elderly centers, health care, Red Cross, and civil defense centers *Areas covered: Bekaa, South, and [[List of places in Beirut|Beirut Suburbs]] *Role of LCEC: administrator
====Achievements==== *Collection area: 1,040 sq. meters *Annual energy production: 1,017 MWh *Annual energy cost saving (consumer side): $81,000 *Annual energy cost saving (EDL side): $324,000 *Annual GHG emissions reduction: 744 tons CO2
====Implemented by==== *Aquatherma Engineering *Kypros Solar *Dawtec<ref>United Nations Development Programme. (2007). Lebanon: Evaluation of the Energy and Environment Programme. Retrieved from: http://www.undp.org.lb/WhatWeDo/Docs/EEOutcome%20Evaluation.pdf</ref>
===CFL pilot project in Niha, Bekaa===
Based on a collaboration agreement signed between LCEC and Electricité de Zahlé (EDZ), EDZ installed around 1,048 [[Compact fluorescent lamp|Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFLs)]] in the village of Niha in the [[Bekaa]] area, completely free-of-charge. The 1,048 CFLs were purchased by LCEC and the installation was offered free-of-charge by EDZ as an in-kind contribution.
The direct objective of the pilot project is to reduce the energy bill of the different consumers and therefore remove part of the financial burden on families in this area. Another major objective is the reduction of GHG emissions generated by inefficient lighting. In addition, setting this project as a success story supported by real achieved savings can increase the market share of energy efficient lighting in Lebanon and consequently boost the market toward the phase out of incandescent bulbs in the country. This strategy goes with the different strategies followed by many countries in [[Europe]], [[United States|America]], and [[Australia]]. Finally, the project shall achieve a percentage of dollars savings in the national energy bill.<ref>Ministry of Environment. (2010). Energy Crisis. Retrieved from: http://test.moe.gov.lb/Documents/SOER%20Chap%209.pdf</ref>
There are two very important reasons for which the project has chosen EDZ for this installation. EDZ is a professional electrical utility that has online control on the electricity consumption in each and every house. This means that EDZ is able to track the changes in the energy bills resulting from the project implementation and can therefore report on the measurement and savings in kWh and in dollars. The second reason is that the management at EDZ is ready to support this program financially at a later stage.
Following a site survey done by EDZ, LCEC supplied around 1,048 CFL's of different sizes to EDZ with a total cost not exceeding 2,500 USD.
Due to the importance of this pilot project, the event was covered by the media in every aspect. In fact, a press release was distributed to the main newspapers in town, namely [[An-Nahar|Annahar]], [[As-Safir|Assafir]], [[Al Anwar]], and [[Al-Mustaqbal (newspaper)|Al Mustaqbal]]. In addition, the project was covered by two main television stations in Lebanon, namely [[Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation|LBCI]] and NTV.
Recently, LCEC in collaboration with EDZ has worked on developing a complete study report on the success of this project, one year after its completion. The results of the study will be published soon by LCEC.
These pilot projects are preparing the ground towards implanting a clear DSM strategy developing currently. The strategy shall target the installation of a massive number of CFL fixtures all over Lebanon.<ref>Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation. (2010). Pilot Projects. Retrieved from: http://www.lcecp.org.lb/pilotprojects.php?li=5&pproject=1</ref>
===Chinese government grant - phase 2===
After the success of the 500 solar water heaters donated by the People’s Republic of China and subsequent to the Israeli’s attacks in July 2006 leading to the destruction of 200 of units earlier that year, the LCEC and the Ministry of Energy & Water (MEW) have been closely coordinating with the Chinese government to proceed with a phase 2 grant that will include 600 solar water heaters of similar capacity and type of phase 1 (208 L tank capacity and 28 glass tubes).
====Project information==== *Date of Initiation: Q1 2010 *Donation: 600 solar water heaters (200 to replace damaged of Phase 1 + 400 new installations) *Type of donation: in-kind *Application type: evacuated tube solar water heaters *Beneficiaries: 417 residences and public health centers *Areas covered: residences and non-profit facilities *Role of LCEC: technical agency
====Projected achievements==== *Collection area: 1,524 sq. meters *Annual energy production: 1,221 MWh *Annual energy cost saving (consumer side): $97,000 *Annual energy cost saving (EDL side): $445,000 *Annual GHG emissions reduction: 1,017 tons CO2<ref>Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation. (2010). Planned Pilot Projects. Retrieved from: http://www.lcecp.org.lb/pilotprojects.php?li=5&pproject=1</ref>
===Beirut River Solar Snake=== The “Beirut River Solar Snake” (BRSS) is the 1st pilot project in Lebanon to produce electricity from solar energy. It was launched by the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW) in 2013 and is under the supervision and management of LCEC. The project will be extended over a distance of 6.5 Km on the top of the Beirut River and have 10 MW installed capacity to be the first grid connected solar farm that seeks to generate and supply EDL with clean energy. The project will also have a technical building. The implementation of the first phase has an installed capacity of 1 MW extending over an area of 16,000 m2.<ref>Association of Lebanese Industrialists. (2013). Phoenix Offer to Ali Members. Retrieved from: http://www.ali.org.lb/english/morearticles.asp?newsid=123</ref> The cost of the 1st phase of the project is 3.1 Million USD (with a budget of 4 million USD) and is completely financed by MEW. The execution of the first phase started in July 2014 is now completed.<ref>BRSS Lebanon. (2015). Beirut River Solar Snake (BRSS). Retrieved from: http://brsslebanon.com/</ref>
===Public Street Lighting=== LCEC was engaged in the public street lighting project and managed the installation of 500 solar street lights at the end of December 2014 through a grant by the Chinese Government in the Dora, Jounieh, Cornet Chehwan and Batroun areas.
===French FASEP Initiative for Solar Photovoltaic Educational Platform=== The “Educational and Demonstration Platform for Renewable Energies in Lebanon" project is a joint initiative between the French company Transénergie and the Ministry of Energy and Water represented by LCEC with the direct support of the Industrial Research Institute (IRI) and UNDP Lebanon. It aims at the installation of an educational platform to be used by researchers, educational institutions, university students, as well as professionals in the solar photovoltaic sector.<ref>Economy and Ecology Online. (2014). French FASEP Initiative Finances Solar Photovoltaic Educational Platform. Retrieved from: http://www.eecoy.com/content/french-fasep-initiative-finances-solar-photovoltaic-educational-platform</ref>
=== Global Solar Water Heating Market Transformation and Strengthening Initiative === A main component of LCEC’s work is the GEF-funded project “Global Solar Water Heating Market Transformation and Strengthening Initiative” aiming at the installation of around 190,000 square meters of solar water heaters (SWHs) during the timeline of the project from 2010 till the end of 2014. Another aim of the project is to help the market reach a total annual sale of 50,000 m2 and the installation of 1,050,000 square meters of SWHs capacity by 2020. To achieve these goals, the project worked on pilot installation of solar water heating, on training engineers and technicians, advertisement and marketing, and all other aspects that affect the solar water heating market growth.
Till july 2014, a total of 5,878 installations were approved for SWH loans, and 49.63% of which benefited from the USD 200 subsidy. In total, 33,239 systems sold between 2012 and 2013.
Moreover, LCEC provides both the public and private sector with expert advice, finance and accreditation, develops energy efficiency standards and labels, and provides national energy database indicators.<ref>Data Bank. (2013). The Solar Water Heaters Market From 2009 to 2013 and the Way Beyond. Retrieved from: http://www.databank.com.lb/docs/solar%20water%20heaters%20market%202009-2013.pdf</ref>
===ESCO Companies=== Since 2001, a nationwide program on energy audits for medium and large consuming facilities was initiated. This was a project financed by the Global Environment Facility (GEF), managed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and called “Lebanon Cross Sectoral Energy Efficiency and Removal of Barriers to ESCO Operation”. The initial period 2002-2004 saw delays in project implementation; consequently, the project was essentially restarted with a new project team in 2005 and was operational until the end of 2009. The project was mainly targeting the high combined consumption of energy in industrial plants and buildings, where the potential for energy savings is important and promising. In 2006, LCEC aimed and worked on creating a market for ESCOs (Energy Service Companies that offer energy efficiency improvement services) where the end user can request a specialized ESCO to conduct an energy audit.
Over 125 audits were completed within the project, mostly for large facilities.
Only one ESCO was operational at the beginning of the programme. In 2010 only 8 ESCOs where active, nowadays more than 30 are available and the market is still expanding rapidly. To further support the growth of the ESCOs market, LCEC launched an initiative in NEAAP called “Paving the Way for Energy Audit and ESCO Business”. The purpose of this initiative is to support the development of the ESCO working in the energy audit business and provide them with the suitable financial, fiscal and technical incentives to remove all the obstacles hindering their growth. To support this initiative, LCEC has offered periodical trainings, workshops and seminars on energy audit activities and procedures to technician, engineers, bankers and to all those involved in the field. The ESCO pre-qualification programme was launched by LCEC by 2014 in order to regulate the market and have a recommended list of companies for potential projects.<ref>Lebanese Center for Energy Conservation Project. (2013). Energy Audit. Retrieved from: http://www.lcecp.org.lb/energy.php?i=2</ref>
== Financing ==
The National Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Action (NEEREA) is a green financing mechanism that allows private sector entities to apply to subsidized loans for any type of EE and/or RE projects. The loan has a ceiling of 20 million USD and is offered at an interest rate of 0.6% for 14 years. The greens loans are provided through any of the Lebanese commercial banks to directly reach the end user.<ref>Intercontinental Bank of Lebanon. (2014). Green Loans. Retrieved from: http://www.ibl.com.lb/RetailProducts/Loans/GreenLoans/tabid/184/Default.aspx</ref> The European Union is contributing to NEEREA by offering a grant over a share of the investment cost of maximum 5 million USD, 15% for nonsubsidized sectors and 5% for subsidized sectors.
By January 2015, more than 200 projects were approved under the NEEREA financing mechanism with a total amount of more than 200 Million USD. Results show that around 60% of the projects were for solar photovoltaic while 82% of loans amount were for green buildings.<ref>Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency. (2014). National Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Action. Retrieved from: http://www.rcreee.org/sites/default/files/lebanon_neerea_web.pdf</ref>

The [[U.S. state]] of [[Oregon]] currently has six [[state forest]]s administered by the [[Oregon Department of Forestry]]:<ref name=ODFweb>{{cite web|title=Welcome to Oregon's State Forests |publisher=[[Oregon Department of Forestry]] |url=http://www.oregon.gov/ODF/STATE_FORESTS/state_forests.shtml |accessdate=2007-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808011853/http://www.oregon.gov/ODF/STATE_FORESTS/state_forests.shtml |archivedate=2007-08-08 |df= }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !! Location |- | [[Clatsop State Forest]] || [[Clatsop County, Oregon|Clatsop County]], [[Columbia County, Oregon|Columbia County]] |- | [[Elliott State Forest]] || [[Coos County, Oregon|Coos County]] |- | [[Gilchrist State Forest]] || [[Klamath County, Oregon|Klamath County]] |- | [[Santiam State Forest]] || [[Linn County, Oregon|Linn County]] |- | [[Sun Pass State Forest]] || [[Klamath County, Oregon|Klamath County]] |- | [[Tillamook State Forest]] || [[Washington County, Oregon|Washington County]] |}
==Former state forests== Former state forests include:
*'''Adair Tract State Forest''' aka '''Paul M. Dunn Research Forest''', renamed and now jointly administered as the '''McDonald-Dunn Forest''' by [[Oregon State University]]<ref>{{cite web | url = {{gnis3|1116760}} | title = Feature Detail Report | work = GNIS | publisher = USGS | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref><ref>[http://osulibrary.oregonstate.edu/archives/archive/mss/dunn.html Paul M. Dunn Papers, 1916-1988] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603014653/http://osulibrary.oregonstate.edu/archives/archive/mss/dunn.html |date=2010-06-03 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cof.orst.edu/cof/visitors/history/dates/signific.php OSU College of Forestry: Significant Dates in School's History]</ref> *'''[[George T. Gerlinger]] State Experimental Forest''',<ref>{{GNIS|1142616|name=George T Gerlinger State Experimental Forest}}</ref> now administered in part by the [[Black Rock, Oregon|Black Rock]] Mountain Biking Association *'''McDonald State Forest''', north of [[Corvallis, Oregon|Corvallis]], now administered by Oregon State University as part of McDonald-Dunn Forest<ref>{{GNIS|1145972|name=McDonald State Forest}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://ir.library.oregonstate.edu/dspace/bitstream/1957/9117/1/Happe_Patricia_J_1982.pdf |format=PDF| title = The Use of Suburban Habitats by Columbian Black-tailed Deer | work = Masters Thesis | author = Patricia Jenkins Heppe | date = 18 November 1982 | pages = 17 ("5") | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cof.orst.edu/cf/forests/mcdonald/ McDonald-Dunn Forest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202064025/http://www.cof.orst.edu/cf/forests/mcdonald/ |date=2008-12-02 }}</ref> *'''Van Duzer State Forest''', now part of the [[H. B. Van Duzer Forest State Scenic Corridor]]<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=boFO8l8R7BsC&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=%22Van+Duzer%22+State+Forest+corridor&source=web&ots=SZPcmGFjey&sig=Wg8XXvcjm__ISf-vc_3SDeKUXZ4&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA90,M1 | title = Oregon State Parks, A Complete Recreation Guide | author = Jan Bannan | publisher = [[The Mountaineers (club)|The Mountaineers]] | isbn = 978-0-89886-794-7 | pages = 90 | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref>

'''List of Salticidae species K-M''' includes all described species with a scientific name starting from K to M of the spider family [[Salticidae]] as of December 16, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |date=2016 |url=http://www.wsc.nmbe.ch/family/83/Salticidae |title=Family: Salticidae |work=World Spider Catalog |version=17.5 |publisher=Natural History Museum Bern |accessdate=2016-12-18 }}</ref>

[[File:Culinary fruits front view.jpg|thumb|Some culinary fruits]] This '''list of culinary fruits''' contains the names of some [[fruit]]s that are considered [[Eating|edible]] in some [[cuisine]]s. The word "fruit" is used in several different ways.See [[Vegetable#Terminology]] The definition of fruit for these lists is a culinary fruit, i.e. "Any sweet, edible part of a [[plant]] that resembles fruit, even if it does not develop from a floral ovary; also used in a technically imprecise sense for some sweet or sweetish [[vegetable]]s, some of which may resemble a true fruit or are used in cookery as if they were a [[:wiktionary:fruit|fruit]], for example [[rhubarb]]."See the [[:wiktionary:fruit#Usage notes|Wiktionary definition of fruit]]{{cite book | title=Fruit and Vegetables | author1=Harri Vainio | author2=Franca Bianchini | publisher=IARC | year=2003 | isbn=9283230086 | pages=2 }} Many edible plant parts that are ''[[fruit|true fruits]]'' botanically speaking, are not considered culinary fruits. They are classified as [[vegetable]]s in the [[food|culinary]] sense (for example: the [[tomato]], [[zucchini]], and so on), and hence they do not appear in this list. Similarly, some botanical fruits are classified as nuts (e.g. [[Brazil nut]] and various [[almond]]s), or staples (e.g. [[breadfruit]]), and likewise do not appear here. There also exist many fruits which are edible and palatable but for various reasons have not become popular. {{TOC limit|2}} ==Alphabetical list by common name== [[File:Carica papaya - papaya - var-tropical dwarf papaya - desc-fruit.jpg|thumb|[[Papaya]]s]] [[File:Tropical Fruits.jpg|thumb|descriptive text|An array of [[tropical fruits]] at [[University of Hyderabad]], [[India]] ]] [[File:Malpighia glabra3.jpg|thumb|[[Acerola]]]] [[File:Mango and cross section edit.jpg|thumb|[[Mango]]s]] [[File:Maracuyá.jpg|thumb|[[Passion fruit]]s]] ===A=== {{div col}} * {{anchor|abiu}}[[Abiu]] (''Pouteria caimito''; Notable among these are natives of the [[Mediterranean]]: ====Mediterranean natives==== [[File:Close up grapes.jpg|thumb|[[Grape]]s]] {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[#olive|Olives]] * [[#mulberry|Black mulberry]] * [[#cornelian cherry|Cornelian cherry]] * [[#date|Date]] * [[#fig|Fig]] * [[#grape|Grapes]], Vitis vinifera and raisins * [[#jujube|Jujube]] * [[#pomegranate|Pomegranate]] * [[#sycamore fig|Sycamore fig]] {{div col end}} ====Citrus==== In the important genus ''[[Citrus]]'' ([[Rutaceae]]), some members are tropical, tolerating no frost. (''Englerophytum magalismontanum'') * [[Synsepalum dulcificum|Miracle fruit]] (''Synsepalum dulcificum'') * [[Parinari curatellifolia|Mobola plum]] (''Parinari curatellifolia'') * [[Muskmelon|(Musk)melon]] (''Cucumis melo'') * [[Carissa macrocarpa|Natal plum]] (''Carissa macrocarpa'') * [[Parkia biglobosa|Néré]] (''Parkia biglobosa'') * [[Elaeis|Oil palm]] (''Elaeis Jacq.'') *
