madagascariensis'') * [[Strychnos spinosa|Spiny monkey orange]] (''Strychnos spinosa'') * [[Uapaca kirkiana|Sugar plum]] (''Uapaca kirkiana'') * [[Detarium senegalense|Sweet detar]] (''Detarium senegalense'') * [[Ficus sycomorus|Sycamore fig]] (''Ficus sycomorus'') * [[Tamarind]] (''Tamarindus indica'') * [[Syzygium guineense|Waterberry]] (''Syzygium guineense'') * [[Syzygium cordatum|Waterbessie]] (''Syzygium cordatum'') * [[Watermelon]] (''Citrullus lanatus var. lanatus'') * [[Chrysophyllum albidum|White star apple]] (''Chrysophyllum albidum'') * [[Ancylobothrys capensis|Wild apricot]] (''Ancylobothrys capensis'') {{div col end}} ===Fruits of Asian origin=== [[File:LocationAsia.png|thumb|right]] Fruits native to [[Asia]] or of Asian origin: {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[#arhat|Arhat]] * [[#banana|Banana]] * [[#batuan|Batuan]] * [[#bignay|Bignay]] * [[#bilimbi|Bilimbi]] * [[#breadfruit|Breadfruit]] * [[#buddhas hand|Buddha's Hand]] * [[#bael|Bael]] * [[#mango|Mango]] * [[#carambola|Carambola]] * [[#charichuelo|Charichuelo]] * [[#calamondin|Calamondin]] * [[#burmese grape|Burmese grape]] * [[#button mangosteen|Button mangosteen]] * [[#chinese quince|Chinese quince]] * [[#che|Che]] * [[#durian|Durian]] * [[#gac|Gac]] * [[#goumi|Goumi]] * [[#hardy kiwi|Hardy kiwi]] * [[#indian gooseberry|Indian gooseberry]] * [[#jalpai|Jalpai]] * [[#jambul|Jambul]] * [[Ziziphus mauritiana|Jujube]] (''Ziziphus mauritiana'') * [[#kiwifruit|Kiwifruit]] * [[#Korean melon|Korean melon]] * [[#mundu|Mundu]] * [[#lanzones|Lanzones]] * [[#lapsi|Lapsi]] * [[#longan|Longan]] * [[#lychee|Lychee]] * [[#malay apple|Malay apple]] * [[#mangosteen|Mangosteen]] * [[#marang|Marang]] * [[#mock strawberry|Mock strawberry]] * [[#nungu|Nungu]] * [[#orange|Orange]] * [[#peach|Peach]] * [[#oriental persimmon|Oriental persimmon]] * [[#pomelo|Pomelo]] * [[#rambutan|Rambutan]] * [[#rhubarb|Rhubarb]] * [[#sageretia|Sageretia]] * [[#salak|Salak]] * [[#santol|Santol]] * [[#wild mangosteen|Wild mangosteen]] {{div col end}} ===Fruits of Latin American origin=== [[File:LocationLatinAmerica.png|thumb|right]] Fruits native to [[Latin America]] or of Latin American origin. Plants are of South American origin, except as noted. {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[#acai|Açaí]], [[Amazon basin]] * [[#avocado|Avocado]], [[Mesoamerica]] * [[#barberry|Barberry]] * [[#cainito|Cainito]] * [[#capulin cherry|Capuli cherry]] * [[#cherimoya|Cherimoya]] * [[#coconut|Coconut]], [[Americas]] * [[#feijoa|Feijoa]] * [[#giant columbian blackberry|Giant Columbian blackberry]] * [[#guarana|Guarana]], Brazilian Amazon * [[#guava|Guava]], [[Mesoamerica]] * [[#jamaica cherry|Jamaica cherry]], [[Mesoamerica]] * [[#keule|Keule]] * [[#lardizabala|Lardizabala]] * [[#mamey sapote|Mamey sapote]], [[Mesoamerica]] * [[#mammee apple|Mammee apple]] * [[#maqui|Maqui]] * [[#mora commun|Mora Común]] * [[#mortino|Mortiño]] * [[#naranjilla|Naranjilla]] * [[#papaya|Papaya]] * [[#peumo|Peumo]] * [[#pineapple|Pineapple]] * [[#sapote|Sapote]], [[Mesoamerica]] * [[#sea grape|Sea grape]] * [[#strawberry|Strawberry]]{{cite book | title=Lost Crops of the Incas | year=1989 | author=Office of International Affairs | publisher=[[National Academies Press]] | page=116 }} * [[#soursop|Soursop]] * [[#sugar apple|Sugar-apple]] * [[#ugni|Ugni]][[#lcoti|Lost Crops of the Incas"]], [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=1398&page=218 p. 218] {{div col end}} ===Fruits of North American origin=== [[File:LocationNorthAmerica.png|thumb|right]] Canada and the United States are home to a surprising number of edible plants, especially berries; however, only three are commercially grown/known on a global scale (grapes, cranberries, and blueberries.) Many of the fruits below are still eaten locally as they have been for centuries and others are generating renewed interest by eco-friendly gardeners (less need for bug control) and chefs of the region alike. {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[#american chestnut|American chestnut]] * [[#american black elderberry|American black elderberry]] * [[#american grape|American grape]] * [[#american hazelnut|American hazelnut]] * [[#american mayapple|American mayapple]] * [[#american persimmon|American persimmon]] * [[#american plum|American plum]] * [[#american red elderberry|American red elderberry]] * [[#american red raspberry|American red raspberry]] * [[#beach plum|Beach plum]] * [[#black cherry|Black cherry]] * [[#black raspberry|Black raspberry]] * [[#black walnut|Black walnut]] * [[#blueberry|Blueberry]] * [[#buffaloberry|Buffaloberry]] * [[#chokecherry|Chokecherry]] * [[#coco plum|Coco plum]] * [[#cranberry|Cranberry]] * [[#eastern may hawthorn|Eastern may hawthorn]] * [[#false mastic|False-mastic]] * [[#florida strangler fig|Florida strangler fig]] * [[#ground plum|Ground plum]] * [[#huckleberry|Huckleberry]] * [[#maypop|Maypop]] * [[#muscadine|Muscadine]] * [[#pawpaw|Pawpaw]] * [[#pecan|Pecan]] * [[#prickly pear|Prickly pear]] * [[#pigeon plum|Pigeon plum]] * [[#red mulberry|Red mulberry]] * [[#salal|Salal]] * [[#salmonberry|Salmonberry]] * [[#saskatoonberry|Saskatoonberry]] * [[#saw palmetto|Saw palmetto]] * [[#southern crabapple|Southern crabapple]] * [[#texas persimmon|Texas persimmon]] * [[#thimbleberry|Thimbleberry]] * [[#toyon|Toyon]] {{div col end}} ===Fruits of Oceanian origin=== [[File:LocationOceania.png|thumb|right]] Fruits native to [[Oceania]] or of Oceanian origin: {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[#atherton raspberry|Atherton Raspberry]] * [[#black apple|Black apple]] * [[#blue tongue|Blue tongue]] * [[#bolwarra|Bolwarra]] * [[#broad leaf bramble|Broad-leaf bramble]] * [[#burdekin plum|Burdekin plum]] * [[#bush tomato|Bush tomato]] * [[#cedar bay cherry|Cedar Bay cherry]] * [[#cherry ballart|Cherry ballart]] * [[#cluster fig|Cluster fig]] * [[#cocky apple|Cocky apple]] * [[#common apple berry|Common apple-berry]] * [[#conkerberry|Conkerberry]] * [[#davidson s plum|Davidson's plum]] * [[#desert banana|Desert banana]] * [[#desert fig|Desert fig]] * [[#desert lime|Desert lime]] * [[#dodder laurel|Dodder laurel]] * [[#doubah|Doubah]] * [[#emu apple|Emu apple]] * [[#emu berry|Emu berry]] * [[#fibrous satinash|Fibrous satinash]] * [[#finger lime|Finger lime]] * [[#illawarra plum|Illawarra plum]] * [[#kakadu lime|Kakadu lime]] * [[#kakadu plum|Kakadu plum]] * [[#karkalla|Karkalla]] * [[#kutjera|Kutjera]] * [[#lady apple|Lady apple]] * [[#lemon aspen|Lemon aspen]] * [[#lillypilly|Lillypilly]] * [[#little gooseberry tree|Little gooseberry tree]] * [[#midyim|Midyim]] * [[#morinda citrifolia|Morinda citrifolia]] * [[#mountain pepper|Mountain pepper]] * [[#muntries|Muntries]] * [[#native currant|Native currant]] * [[#native gooseberry|Native gooseberry]] * [[#native raspberry|Native raspberry]] * [[#nonda plum|Nonda plum]] * [[#pigface|Pigface]] * [[#pink flowered native raspberry|Pink-flowered native raspberry]] * [[#purple apple berry|Purple apple-berry]] * [[#quandong|Quandong]] * [[#queensland ebony|Queensland ebony]] * [[#riberry|Riberry]] * [[#rose leaf bramble|Rose-leaf bramble]] * [[#rose myrtle|Rose myrtle]] * [[#sandpaper fig|Sandpaper fig]] * [[#small leaf tamarind|Small-leaf tamarind]] * [[#snow berry|Snow berry]] * [[#sweet apple berry|Sweet apple-berry]] * [[#tanjong|Tanjong]] * [[#white aspen|White aspen]] * [[#wild grape|Wild grape]] * [[#wild orange|Wild orange]] * [[#wild peach|Wild peach]] * [[#wild plum munydjudj|Wild plum (munydjudj)]] * [[#wild plum|Wild plum]] * [[#wongi|Wongi]] * [[#yellow plum|Yellow plum]] * [[#zig zag vine|Zig zag vine]] {{div col end}} ==Culinary fruits by type of flora== ===Family Rosaceae=== The family [[Rosaceae]] dominates the temperate fruits, both in numbers and in importance. The pome fruits, stone fruits and brambles are fruits of plants in Rosaceae. The [[pome]] fruits: {{div col}} * [[#apple|Apple]] and crabapple * [[#chokeberry|Chokeberry]] * [[#hawthorn|Hawthorn]] * [[#loquat|Loquat]] * [[#medlar|Medlar]] * [[#pear|Pear]] * [[#quince|Quince]] * [[#rose hip|Rose hip]] * [[#rowan|Rowan]] * [[#service tree|Service tree]] * [[#serviceberry|Serviceberry]] * [[#shipova|Shipova]] {{div col end}} The stone fruits, [[drupe]]s of [[genus]] ''[[Prunus]]'': {{div col}} * [[#apricot|Apricot]] (''Prunus armeniaca'' or ''Armeniaca vulgaris'') * [[#cherry|Cherry]], including sweet, black, sour, and wild species * [[#chokecherry|Chokecherry]] * [[#greengage|Greengage]] * [[#peach|Peach]] and nectarine * [[#plum|Plum]] of several species * [[#drupe hubrids|Hybrids]] of the preceding species {{div col end}} ===Berries=== In non-technical usage, '''[[berry]]''' means any small fruit that can be eaten whole and lacks objectionable seeds. The '''bramble fruits''', [[compound fruit]]s of [[genus]] ''[[Rubus]]'' (blackberries), are some of the most popular of these that are not true berries: {{div col}} * [[#blackberry|Blackberry]], including many species and hybrids * [[#cloudberry|Cloudberry]] * [[#loganberry|Loganberry]] * [[#raspberry|Raspberry]] of several species * [[#salmonberry|Salmonberry]] * [[#thimbleberry|Thimbleberry]] * [[#wineberry|Wineberry]] {{div col end}} The true berries are dominated by the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Ericaceae]], many of which are hardy in the [[subarctic]]: {{div col}} * [[#bearberry|Bearberry]] * [[#bilberry|Bilberry]] * [[#blueberry|Blueberry]] * [[#crowberry|Crowberry]] * [[#cranberry|Cranberry]] * [[#falberry|Falberry]] * [[#huckleberry|Huckleberry]] * [[#lingonberry|Lingonberry]] * [[#strawberry tree|Strawberry tree]] {{div col end}} Other berries not in [[Rosaceae]] or [[Ericaceae]]: {{div col}} * [[#acaí|Açaí]] * [[#barberry|Barberry]] * [[#currant|Currant]] * [[#elderberry|Elderberry]] * [[#gooseberry|Gooseberry]] * [[#hackberry|Hackberry]] * [[#honeysuckle|Honeysuckle]] * [[#mulberry|Mulberry]], including [[#red mulberry|red]] and [[#white mulberry|white mulberry]] * [[#mayapple|Mayapple]] * [[#nannyberry|Nannyberry]] * [[#oregon grape|Oregon grape]] * [[#sea buckthorn|Sea-buckthorn]] * [[#sea grape|Sea grape]] * [[#ugni|Ugniberry]] * [[#wolfberry|Wolfberry]] {{div col end}} ===Cacti and other succulents=== Several [[cactus|cacti]] yield edible fruits, which are important traditional foods for some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] peoples: {{div col}} * [[#cardon|Cardón]] * [[#dragonfruit|Dragonfruit]] * [[#prickly pear|Prickly pear]] * [[#saguaro|Saguaro]] * [[#cereus peruvianus|Cereus peruvianus]] * Numerous other cactus species {{div col end}} ===Gymnosperms with fruit-like structures=== Only [[Angiosperm]]s have fruit, a structure that surrounds the seed. [[Gymnosperm]]s have naked seeds, but some of them have reproductive structures that resemble fruit.{{cite book|author1=Gifford, E.M. |author2=Foster, A.S. |year=1989 |title= Morphology and evolution of vascular plants |publisher=W. H. Freeman and Company |location=New York }} ====Podocarps==== Podocarps are conifers in the family [[Podocarpaceae]], The seed [[conifer cone|cones]] are highly modified and, in some, the seed is surrounded by fleshy scale tissue, resembling a drupe. These berry-like cone scales are eaten by birds which then disperse the seeds in their droppings and the cones can be eaten in many species. Podocarps are either half-hardy or frost tender, depending on species. Many genera are similar in that they have edible "fruits" and often don't have a common name. {{div col}} * [[#kahikatea|Kahikatea]] * [[#manoao|Manoao]] * [[#nageia|Nageia]] * [[#podocarpus|Podocarpus]] * [[#prumnopitys|Prumnopitys]] * [[#rimu|Rimu]] * [[#totara|Tōtara]] {{div col end}} ====Other gymnosperms==== * [[#juniper berry|Juniper berry]] (a berry-like cone) ===Melons and other members of family Cucurbitaceae=== Most gourds and many melons are regarded as culinary vegetables. The following are generally regarded as fruits: {{div col}} * [[#bitter melon|Bitter melon]] * [[#cantaloupe|Cantaloupe]] * [[#galia|Galia]] * [[#honeydew|Honeydew]] * [[#horned melon|Horned melon]] * [[#muskmelon|Muskmelon]] * [[#watermelon|Watermelon]] {{div col end}} ===Accessory fruits=== The [[accessory fruit]]s, seed organs which are not botanically berries at all: * [[#cashew apple|Cashew apple]] * [[#raisin tree|Raisin tree]] * [[#strawberry|Strawberry]] ==See also== {{portal|Fruits|Food}} {{div col}} * [[Fruit]] * [[Fruit tree propagation]] * [[List of citrus fruits]] * [[List of culinary herbs and spices]] * [[List of culinary nuts]] * [[List of fruit dishes]] * [[List of vegetables]] * [[List of edible seeds]] * [[List of foods]] * [[List of inedible fruits]] * [[Tropical agriculture]] {{div col end}} ==Notes and references== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons|List of culinary fruits}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/Indices/index_ab.html | title=Center for New Crops | publisher=Purdue University }} * [http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/index.html Fruits of Warm Climates] * [http://www.crfg.org Rare Fruit Growers of California] with [http://www.crfg.org/pubs/fl/commonAC.html Common fruit names] [[Category:Edible fruits|*List]] [[Category:Lists of foods|Fruit]] [[Category:Lists of plants|Culinary fruits]] [[Category:Types of food]] [[Category:Agriculture-related lists|Fruits, Culinary]]

[[File:Vatnsdalur 03.jpg|thumb|right|240px|The Álfar]] On an island like [[Iceland]], the rivers are short in length. None of the rivers are important as a means of navigation due to the impracticality of settlements in the [[Highlands of Iceland]] where they originate.

page.title: List of stars with resolved images

revision.text:
The following is a [[list of stars|list]] of [[star]]s whose images have been [[optical resolution|resolved]] beyond a point source. Aside from the Sun, stars are exceedingly small in apparent size, requiring the use of special high-resolution equipment to image. For example, the first star, other than the Sun, to be directly imaged was [[Betelgeuse]]. It has an angular diameter of only 50 [[milliarcsecond]]s (mas). ==List== {{Expand list|date=December 2017}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Star ! class="unsortable" | Image ! data-sort-type="number" | [[Angular diameter]] ! data-sort-type="number" | Radius ([[Solar radius|{{solar radius}}]]) ! data-sort-type="number" | Distance ! Imager ! Notes |- | The [[Sun]] | style="background-color: black;" | [[File:Sun in February.jpg|50px]] | data-sort-value="1800000"| 30 [[arcminute]]s | data-sort-value="1"| 1 | data-sort-value="0.000015"| 1 au | Resolvable with the naked eye; see also [[solar telescope]]. | |- | [[Proxima Centauri]] | style="background-color: black;" | | data-sort-value="1.02"| 1.02 ± 0.08 mas | data-sort-value="0.141"| 0.141 ± 0.007 | data-sort-value="4.246"| 4.246 ± 0.006 ly | [[Very Large Telescope]] | |- | [[Alpha Centauri]] | style="background-color: black;" | [[File:Alpha-centauri-AB.png|50px]] | data-sort-value="8.511"| {{nowrap|8.511 ± 0.020}} mas (A component)
{{nowrap|6.001 ± 0.034}} mas (B component) | data-sort-value="1.224"| {{nowrap|1.224 ± 0.003}} (A component)
{{nowrap|0.863 ± 0.005}} (B component) | data-sort-value="4.37"| 4.37 ly | [[Very Large Telescope]] - VINCI/VLTIP. Kervella, F. Thevenin, D. Segransan, G. Berthomieu, B. Lopez, P. Morel, J. The following is a '''list of unusual drainage systems'''. ==List== ===Bifurcation rivers (active)=== * The [[Casiquiare canal]] - natural waterway connecting the [[Orinoco]] and [[Amazon River|Amazon]] rivers. * The [[Chicago River]] artificially diverts water from the [[Great Lakes]] to the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]]. * The [[Echimamish River]] in Canada connects the [[Hayes River|Hayes]] and [[Nelson River|Nelson]] rivers and was much used as a shortcut by voyageurs. * The [[Nerodimka (river)|Nerodimka]] flows into the [[Aegean Sea|Aegean]] and [[Black Sea|Black]] seas. * [[Parting of the Waters]], Wyoming * [[:es:Arroyo Partido|Arroyo Partido]], [[Neuquén Province|Neuquén]], [[Argentina]] * [[Slims River]]: In the spring of 2016 a melting glacier diverted most of the Slims River from the [[Bering Sea]] to the [[Gulf of Alaska]] watershed. * [[Tärendö River]] - in Sweden
===Bifurcation rivers (extinct)=== * The [[Chu River]] in [[Kyrgyzstan]] flows east to within a few miles of [[Lake Issyk-Kul]], makes a hairpin turn, and flows west without entering the lake. * The [[Manych River]] east of the [[Black Sea]] formerly flowed both east and west.
===Bifurcation lakes=== *[[Bontecou Lake]] in New York outflows into two watersheds, those of the [[Hudson River|Hudson]] and [[Housatonic River|Housatonic]] rivers. *The artificial [[Gatun Lake]] in Panama drains into the Atlantic and Pacific. * [[Isa Lake]] in Yellowstone National Park drains to the Atlantic and Pacific. * At the summit of [[Simpson Pass]] in the Canadian Rockies is a small lake, the [[Simpson Pass|Committee's Punch Bowl]], that drains both east and west. * [[Wollaston Lake]] is a [[bifurcation lake]] that drains northwest to the Arctic Ocean and northeast to Hudson Bay. * [[Lake Diefenbaker]] - in Canada * [[Inhottu]] - in Finland * [[Isojärvi (Satakunta)]] - in Finland * [[Kivesjärvi]] - in Finland * [[Kuolimo]] - in Finland * [[Lummene]] - in Finland * [[Vehkajärvi]] - in Finland * [[Vesijako]] - in Finland * [[Lake Manapouri]] in New Zealand has been modified as part of a hydroelectric scheme such that it drains (naturally) south to [[Foveaux Strait]] via the [[Waiau River, Southland|Waiau River]] and (artificially) west via a constructed tunnel to [[Doubtful Sound]]
===Other unusual systems=== * [[Lake Vostok]] is a [[subglacial lake]] beneath the Antarctic ice cap. * [[Bahr Yussef]] - in Egypt * The [[Tonle Sap]] River flows north in the wet season and south in the dry season
==See also== * [[River bifurcation]]
[[Category:Hydrology]] [[Category:Geomorphology]] [[Category:River bifurcations]] [[Category:Bifurcation lakes]] [[Category:Lists of things considered unusual|Drainage systems]]

[[File:Lineman changing transformer.jpg|thumb|280px|right|A lineman wearing equipment for hot glove work]] In [[electrical engineering]], '''live-line working''', also known as '''hotline maintenance''', is the maintenance of electrical equipment, often operating at [[high voltage]], while the equipment is energised. The first techniques for live-line working were developed in the early years of the 20th century, and both equipment and work methods were later refined to deal with increasingly higher voltages. In the 1960s, methods were developed in the laboratory to enable [[Lineman (technician)|field workers]] to come into direct contact with high voltage lines. Such methods can be applied to enable safe work at the highest transmission voltages.
== Background ==
=== Electrical hazards === Electricity is hazardous: an [[electric shock]] from a current as low as 35 milliamps is sufficient to cause [[fibrillation]] of the heart in vulnerable individuals.<ref name="Brauer">{{cite book|last=Brauer|first= Roger L.|title=Safety and Health for Engineers|publisher=Wiley-IEEE|year=2006|pages=163–165|isbn=978-0-471-75092-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yRjz5wJWZecC&pg=PA163}}</ref> Even a healthy individual is at risk of falling from a high structure due to loss of muscle control. Higher currents can cause [[respiratory failure]] and result in extensive and life-threatening [[Burn#Causes of burns|burns]].<ref name="Brauer" /> The first recorded human fatality occurred in 1879 when a stage carpenter in [[Lyon]], [[France]] touched a 250 volt wire.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lee|first=R.C.|author2=Rudall, D. |year=1992|title=Injury Mechanisms And Therapeutic Advances In The Study Of Electrical Shock|journal=Proceedings of the Annual International Conference of the IEEE|volume=7|pages=2825–2827|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplore/login.jsp?url=/iel2/1028/12827/00593814.pdf?arnumber=593814|doi=10.1109/iembs.1992.593814}}{{Dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref> The lack of any visible sign that a conductor is energised, even at high voltages, makes electricity a particular hazard.
At high voltages, it is unnecessary to come into direct contact with charged equipment to be shocked. An [[electric field]] surrounds all charged devices. Bringing a conducting object such as a human body into that field can intensify the field enough for [[electrical breakdown]] of the air and an [[electric arc|arc]] to jump from the equipment to [[ground (electricity)|earth]] via that person. In the U.S., the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] establishes clearance guidelines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=9870|title=Working on Exposed Energized Parts|work=Regulations (Standards - 29 CFR) |publisher=Occupational Safety and Health Administration|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref> Solid materials such as rubber, while excellent insulators at low voltages, are also subject to electrical failure if subjected to a high enough field.
=== Avoiding loss of supply === [[Electric utility|Electricity utilities]] wish to avoid [[power outage|loss of supply]], for which they receive customer complaints or are financially penalised. At the same time they are obligated to maintain and replace their electrical equipment on a regular basis. Due to the hazard of high voltage, it is normally necessary for equipment to be isolated from the supply before being worked upon, termed a ''planned outage''.
In a [[wikt:radially|radially]]-supplied system, a planned outage results in a loss of supply, unless equipment is connected in parallel, back up supplies are available or the grid is reswitched to transfer the [[electrical load]] elsewhere. An interconnected grid results in no loss of power, but security of supply is compromised, and [[economic dispatch|out-of-merit generation]] may need to be ordered to maintain system security, which can be expensive.
== Methods == In general, there are three methods of live-line working which help workers avoid the considerable hazards of live line working.<ref name="EPRI" /> In various ways, they all serve to prevent current flowing from the live equipment through the worker.
; Hot stick or Live Line Tool [[Hot stick]]s are used in live line work by having the worker remain at a specified distance from the live parts and carry out the work by means of an insulating stick. Tools can be attached to the stick, allowing work to be performed with the worker himself safely away from the live conductors.
; Insulating Gloves or Rubber Gloves A live line worker is electrically protected by insulating gloves and other insulating equipment, and carries out the work in direct mechanical contact with live parts.
; Barehand or Potential The barehanded approach has a live line worker performing the work in direct electric contact with live parts. Before contact, the worker's body is raised to the same [[electric potential]] as the live parts, and then held there by electric connection, while maintaining suitable isolation from the surroundings which are at different potentials, like the ground, other people or trees. Because the worker and the work are at the same potential, no current flows through the worker.
; Unearthed or De-energised Some organizations additionally consider working on unearthed de-energised equipment to be another form of live-line working. This is because the line might become inadvertently charged (e.g. through a back-charged transformer, possibly as a result of an improperly connected, inadequately isolated emergency generator at a customer facility), or [[mutual inductance|inductively coupled]] from an adjacent in-service line. To prevent this, the line is first grounded via a clamp known as a bond or drain earth. Once this is in place, further work is not considered to be live-line working.
=== Hot stick === {{main|Hot stick}} Hot-stick working appeared in the second decade of the 20th century, when insulating poles made from baked wood were used for tasks such as replacing [[fuse (electrical)|fuses]], replacing post insulators, and transferring lines onto temporary supports.<ref name="EPRI">{{cite web|url=http://mydocs.epri.com/docs/public/000000000001008746.pdf|title=Live Work Guide for Substations|date=October 2004|publisher=[[EPRI]]|accessdate=8 December 2008}}{{Dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref> The sticks enabled the linemen to carry out the work without infringing on the minimum clearance distances from live equipment. As experience with the techniques developed, then the operating voltages at which the work was performed increased. With the advent of [[fibreglass]] poles in the late 1950s, which neither split nor soaked up rainwater, utilities were prepared to carry out hot-stick working to their highest operating voltages, perhaps 765 kV.<ref name="EPRI" />
Tools, such as hooks or [[socket wrench]]es can be mounted at the end of the pole. More sophisticated poles can accept pneumatically or hydraulically driven power tools which allow, for example, bolts to be unscrewed remotely. A rotary wire brush allows a terminal to be scoured clean before a connection is made. However, a worker's dexterity is naturally reduced when operating tools at the end of a pole that is several metres long.<ref name="Stix">{{cite journal|last=Stix|first=Gary|date=September 1988|title=Working hot: life at 765 kV|journal=IEEE Spectrum|volume=25|issue=9|pages=54 56|issn=0018-9235|url=http://www.simson.net/ref/1988/IEEE_Working_Live.pdf|doi=10.1109/6.7169}}</ref>
===Insulating glove or rubber glove working===
Usually applied for work above 1 kV AC 1.5 kV DC The primary classes are: Class 1 - phase to phase working voltage 7.5 kV Class 2 - phase to phase working voltage 17 kV Class 3 - phase to phase working voltage 26.5 kV Class 4 - phase to phase working voltage 36 kV
Gloves protect the worker from exposure to the live part being worked upon sometimes referred to as the 1st point of contact; the point where current would enter the body should an inadvertent contact be made. Covers of insulating material such as blankets and linehose are employed in rubber glove working to protect the worker from exposure to a part at a different potential sometimes referred to as the 2nd point of contact; the point where current would leave the body should an inadvertent contact be made.
=== Bare hand === Bare-hand, or potential working involves placing the worker in direct electrical contact with an energized overhead line. The worker might work alongside the lines, from a platform that is suspended from them, or may sit or stand directly on the line itself.<ref name="Stix" /> In all cases, the worker's body is maintained at the same voltage as the line. It is imperative that the worker maintain appropriate and adequate limits of approach to any part at a different potential.
The first procedures for barehand working were developed in 1960 by Harold L. Rorden, a high-voltage engineer for [[American Electric Power]].<ref name="EPRI"/> Techniques were further refined following field and laboratory tests.
There are a number of ways in which the worker can access the live parts:
* The worker can access from a specialist type of mobile elevating work platform (MEWP) termed an insulating aerial device (IAD) which has a boom of insulating material and which all conductive parts at the platform end are bonded together. There are other requirements for safe working such as gradient control devices, a means of preventing a vacuum in the hydraulic lines, etc. * The worker can stand on an insulating ladder which is maneuvered to the line by means of non-conductive rope. * The worker is lowered from a helicopter and transfers himself to the line. * The worker is brought alongside the wire in a hovering helicopter and works from that position.
As the lineman approaches the wire, an arc will form between them as the worker is charged. This arc can be debilitating, and the worker must immediately bond himself electrically to the line to prevent further arcing.<ref name="Stix" /> A worker may use a conducting wand during the approach to first make the connection. Once on the line, the worker is safe from shock as both the lineman and the wire are at the same [[electric potential]], and no current passes through his body. This is the same principle that allows birds to safely alight on power lines.<ref name="Stix" />
When the work is completed, the process is reversed to remove the worker safely from the wire. Barehand working provides the lineman with greater dexterity than the hot stick method, and may be the preferred option if conditions permit it.<ref name="Miller">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=R.H.|author2=Malinowski, J.H. |title=Power System Operation|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill Professional]]|year=1970|pages=178–180|isbn=978-0-07-041977-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6tk6yXzu62IC&pg=PA178}}</ref> With this technique, [[Insulator (electrical)|insulator strings]], conductor spacers and [[Stockbridge damper|vibration dampers]] can be replaced, or lines [[Rope splicing|spliced]], without any loss of supply.<ref name="Miller" />
The strong electric field surrounding charged equipment is enough to drive a current of approximately 15 μA for each kV·m<sup>−1</sup> through a human body.<ref> {{cite conference | first =Andrzej | last = Krawulski |author2=Niejadlik, Tomasz | title = Live wire work on 400 kV and 220 kV OHL | booktitle = Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Live Maintenance | publisher = ICOLIM 2006 | date = 7–9 June 2006 | location = Prague | url = http://www.vde-kongress.de/NR/rdonlyres/0B8B61EF-2ACC-4C29-8E66-1CFF652E1BEB/20815/etg_1_09.pdf }}</ref> To prevent this, hot-hand workers are usually required to wear a [[Faraday suit]]. This is a set of overalls made from or woven throughout with conducting fibers. The suit is in effect a wearable [[Faraday cage]], which equalizes the potential over the body, and ensures there is no through-tissue current.<ref> {{cite conference | first =Doriano | last = Bosonetto |author2=Iulita, Mario | title = The development of conductive suits: the Italian experience | booktitle = Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Live Maintenance | publisher = ICOLIM 2006 | date = 7–9 June 2006 | location = Prague | url = http://www.vde-kongress.de/NR/rdonlyres/5D1FB137-884E-41F0-88E2-B257717C84F6/20907/etg_3_12.pdf }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Davies|first=John|title=Performance of Protective Clothing|publisher=[[ASTM International]]|year=1988|pages=813–832|isbn=978-0-8031-1167-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RvVWcAbHl10C&pg=PA813}}</ref> Conducting gloves, even conducting socks, are also necessary,<ref>{{cite book|title=Electrical Times|date=July 1969|volume=156|page=58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z2rP5ie2uSsC}}</ref> leaving only the face uncovered.<ref name="Stix"/>
There is little practical upper voltage limit for hot-hand working, and it has been successfully performed at some of the highest transmission operating voltages in the world, such as the [[Russia]]n 1150 kV system.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Krylov|first=S.V.|author2=Timashova, L.V. |title=Experience of live-line maintenance on 500-1200 kV lines in Russia |journal=Transmission and Distribution Construction and Live Line Maintenance|pages=359–368}}</ref>
=== Helicopter === A lineman wearing a Faraday suit can work on live, high-power lines by being transported to the lines in a helicopter. Wearing the suit, they can crawl down the wires.<ref name=vert2015-04>{{cite magazine|first=Elan |last=Head |url=http://www.verticalmag.com/digital_issue/2015/v14i2/files/82.html |title=High-value cargo |pages=80–87 |magazine=Vertical Magazine |date=April 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419023320/http://www.verticalmag.com/digital_issue/2015/v14i2/files/82.html |archivedate=19 April 2015 |df= }}</ref>
== General precautions == Calculation of minimum approach distances take account of switching surges and other transients. Transmission systems are often fitted with coordinated protection devices called [[autorecloser]]s, which are [[circuit breaker]]s that automatically attempt to remake a circuit after a [[short circuit|fault]]. In the event that a fault did occur it would be most undesirable for the autorecloser to re-energise the circuit because the limits of approach would be greatly reduced and the workers' position could be compromised. Hence, auto-reclosing equipment is rendered inoperative while live working takes place. Additional protection against unplanned overvoltage events (such as switching surges) can be provided by means of a [[surge diverter]] known as portable protective air gap.<ref name="EPRI" />
An [[electric arc]] is extremely bright, including in the [[ultraviolet]], and can cause [[arc eye]], a painful and potentially [[blindness|blinding]] condition. Workers may be provided with appropriately tinted goggles that protect their vision in the event of a flash, and provide defence against debris ejected by an arc.
Government regulations may regulate conditions for live working conditions.<ref name="Stix" /> For example, in United States, the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] may require that more than one worker be present on site when working on live equipment above a specified voltage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=9868#1910.269(l)(1)(i)|title=Electric Power Generation, Transmission, and Distribution|work=Regulations (Standards - 29 CFR) |publisher=Occupational Safety and Health Administration|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref> The work may be postponed if adverse weather conditions such as lightning or rainfall are anticipated.
== See also == * [[Lineman (technician)|Lineman (occupation)]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Electric power]] [[Category:Electrical safety]]

[[File:Lockheed Martin Skunkworks - Nuclear Fusion Project.jpg|right|thumb|Charles Chase and his team at Lockheed have developed a high-beta configuration, which allows a compact reactor design and speedier development timeline.]]
The '''Lockheed Martin Compact Fusion Reactor''' is a proposed nuclear fusion reactor. It is the goal of a project at [[Lockheed Martin]]’s [[Skunk Works]]. It is a high-beta fusion reactor.<ref>{{citation|title=FuseNet: The European Fusion Education Network|url=http://www.fusenet.eu/node/400|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130506035703/http://www.fusenet.eu/node/400|deadurl=no|archivedate=2013-05-06}}</ref>
The high-[[Beta (plasma physics)|beta]] configuration allows a [[Compact toroid|compact fusion reactor]] (CFR) design and expedited development.
''High beta'' implies that the ratio of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] pressure to magnetic pressure is greater than or equal to 1. By contrast [[tokamak]] designs reach only 0.05.<ref name=":2" />
The CFR chief designer and technical team lead is [[Thomas McGuire (engineer)|Thomas McGuire]].<ref name="aw20141020">{{cite news|url=http://aviationweek.com/technology/meet-leader-skunk-works-compact-fusion-reactor-team|title=Meet The Leader Of Skunk Works’ Compact Fusion Reactor Team|last1=Hedden|first1=Carole|date=2014-10-20|work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]|accessdate=2014-11-24}}</ref> McGuire studied fusion as a source of space propulsion in response to a NASA desire to improve travel times to Mars.<ref name="guyReac">{{citation|title=Skunk Works Reveals Compact Fusion Reactor Details|date=15 October 2014|url=http://aviationweek.com/technology/skunk-works-reveals-compact-fusion-reactor-details|last1=Norris|first1=Guy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017164725/http://aviationweek.com/technology/skunk-works-reveals-compact-fusion-reactor-details|work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]|accessdate=18 October 2014|archivedate=2014-10-17}}</ref><ref name="guyHope">{{citation|title=High Hopes – Can Compact Fusion Unlock New Power For Space And Air Transport?|date=14 October 2014|url=http://aviationweek.com/blog/high-hopes-can-compact-fusion-unlock-new-power-space-and-air-transport|last1=Norris|first1=Guy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018065452/http://aviationweek.com/blog/high-hopes-can-compact-fusion-unlock-new-power-space-and-air-transport|deadurl=no|work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]|archivedate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="hedLead">{{citation|title=The Leader Of Skunk Works' Compact Fusion Reactor Team|date=20 October 2014|url=http://aviationweek.com/technology/meet-leader-skunk-works-compact-fusion-reactor-team|last1=Hedden|first1=Carole|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018153950/http://aviationweek.com/technology/meet-leader-skunk-works-compact-fusion-reactor-team|deadurl=no|work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]|archivedate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
==History==
The project began in 2010,<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url = http://www.theengineer.co.uk/news/news-analysis/new-details-on-compact-fusion-reveal-scale-of-challenge/1019393.article|title = New details on compact fusion reveal scale of challenge|last = Nathan|first = Stuart|date = 22 October 2014|work = The Engineer|accessdate = 24 December 2017}}</ref> and was publicly presented at the Google [[Solve for X]] forum on February 7, 2013.
In October 2014 [[Lockheed Martin]] announced a plan to "build and test a compact fusion reactor in less than a year with a prototype to follow within five years".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/lockheed-says-makes-breakthrough-fusion-energy-project-123840986--finance.html|title=Lockheed says makes breakthrough on fusion energy project|last1=Shalal|first1=Andrea|accessdate=15 October 2014|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
In May 2016, Rob Weiss announced that Lockheed Martin continued to support the project and would increase its investment in it.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://nextbigfuture.com/2016/05/lockheed-portable-fusion-proejct-still.html|title=Lockheed Portable Fusion project still making progress|first=Brian|last=Wang|date=May 3, 2016|website=[[Next Big Future]]|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/innovation/2016/05/03/lockheed-nuclear-fusion-generator-investment/83870398/|title=Lockheed Still Supporting Portable Nuclear Generator|first= Aaron |last=Mehta|date=May 3, 2016|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref>
==Design== [[File:Lockheed Martins' Compact Fusion Reactor.png|thumb|A sketch of the plasma geometry and magnetic coils inside an early model of Lockheed Martins' compact fusion reactor. This design has since been superseded with a model using only two main cusps.]]
CFR plans to achieve high beta (the ratio of plasma pressure to the magnetic pressure) by combining cusp confinement and [[magnetic mirror]]s to confine the plasma. Cusps are sharply bent magnetic fields. Ideally, the plasma forms a sheath along the surface of the cusps and plasma leaks out along the axis and edges of the sharply bent field.<ref>McGuire, Thomas. "The Lockheed Martin Compact Fusion Reactor." Thursday Colloquium. Princeton University, Princeton. 6 Aug. 2015. Lecture.</ref> The plasma lost along the edges recycles back into the cusps.
CFR uses two mirror sets. A pair of ring mirrors is placed inside the cylindrical reactor vessel at either end. The other mirror set encircles the reactor cylinder. The ring magnets produce a type of [[magnetic field]] known as a [[diamagnetic]] cusp, in which magnetic forces rapidly change direction and push the nuclei towards the midpoint between the two rings. The fields from the external magnets push the nuclei back towards the vessel ends.
Magnetic field strength is an increasing function of distance from the center. This implies that as the plasma pressure causes the plasma to expand, the magnetic field becomes stronger at the plasma edge, increasing containment.<ref name=":2" />
CFR employs [[superconducting magnets]]. These allow strong magnetic fields to be created with less energy than conventional magnets. The CFR has no net current, which Lockheed claimed eliminates the prime source of plasma instabilities. The plasma has a favorable surface-to-volume ratio, which improves confinement. The plasma's small volume reduces the energy needed to achieve fusion.
The project plans to replace the [[microwave]] emitters that heat the plasma in their prototypes with [[neutral beam injection]], in which electrically neutral [[deuterium]] atoms transfer their energy to the plasma. Once initiated, the energy from fusion maintains the necessary temperature for subsequent fusion events.<ref name=":1" />
The eventual device may reach {{val|21|u=m}} in width.<ref name=":2" /> The company claims that each design iteration is shorter and far lower cost than large-scale projects such as the [[Joint European Torus]], [[ITER]] or [[National Ignition Facility|NIF]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = http://www.technologyreview.com/news/531836/does-lockheed-martin-really-have-a-breakthrough-fusion-machine/|title = Does Lockheed Martin Really Have a Breakthrough Fusion Machine?|last = Talbot|first = David|date = October 20, 2014|work = [[Technology Review]]|accessdate = 24 December 2017}}</ref>
A {{val|200|u=MW}} [[Thermal power station|P<sub>th</sub>]] reactor, {{val|18|u=m}} long by {{val|7|u=m}} in diameter, produces about a {{val|2000|u=ton}} reactor, similar in size to an [[United States naval reactors|A5W]] nuclear submarine fission reactor.<ref name="T4B">{{cite web|title=Lockheed Martin Compact Fusion Reactor Concept, Confinement Model and T4B Experiment|url=http://fusion4freedom.us/pdfs/McGuireAPS.pdf|publisher=Lockheed Martin Corporation|accessdate=25 December 2017|date=2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171225092237/http://fusion4freedom.us/pdfs/McGuireAPS.pdf|archive-date=December 25, 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=wang|first1=brian|title=Lockheed compact fusion reactor design about 100 times larger than first plans|url=https://www.nextbigfuture.com/2017/05/lockheed-compact-fusion-reactor-design-about-100-times-larger-than-first-plans.html|website=NextBigFuture.com|publisher=New big future Inc.|accessdate=25 December 2017|date=1 May 2017}}</ref>
===Challenges=== Ring magnets require protection from the plasma's neutron radiation. Plasma temperatures must reach many millions of [[kelvin]]s. Superconducting magnets must be kept just above [[absolute zero]] to maintain [[superconductivity]].<ref name=":1" />
The ''blanket'' component that lines the reactor vessel has two functions: it captures the neutrons and transfers their energy to a coolant, and forces the neutrons to collide with [[lithium]] atoms, transforming them into tritium to fuel the reactor. The blanket must be an estimated 80–150 cm thick and weigh 300–1000 tons.<ref name=":1" />
==Prototypes== The prototype was planned to be a 100-megawatt [[deuterium]] and [[tritium]] reactor measuring {{convert|7 by 10|ft}} that could fit on the back of a large truck and would be about one tenth the size of current reactor prototypes. 100 megawatts is enough to provide power for 80,000 people.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Norris|first1=Guy|date=20 October 2014|title=Fusion Frontier|magazine=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]}}</ref> A series of prototypes were constructed to approach this goal.
===T-4=== Technical results presented on the T4 experiment in 2015 showed a cold, partially ionized plasma with the following parameters: peak electron temperature of 20 [[Electron volts]], {{val|e=16|u=m<sup>−3</sup>}} electron density, less than 1% ionization fraction and {{val|3|u=kW}} of input power. No confinement or fusion reaction rates were presented.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
McGuire presented two theoretical reactor concepts in 2015. One was an ideal configuration weighing 200 metric tons with 1 meter of cryogenic radiation shielding and 15 [[Tesla (unit)|tesla]] magnets. The other was a conservative configuration weighing 2,000 metric tons, with 2 meters of cryogenic radiation shielding and 5 Tesla magnets.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sullivan|first1=Regina|title=Preliminary density and temperature measurements in Lockheed Martin's magnetically encapsulated linear ring cusp confinement configuration|journal=57th Annual Meeting of the APS Division of Plasma Physics|date=November 20, 2015|volume=60|issue=10|ref=YP12.00044}}</ref>
===T4B=== The T4B prototype was announced in 2016.<ref name="T4B" />
Parameters: * 1 m diameter × 2 m long ** 1 MW, 25 keV H-neutral beam heating power ** 3 ms duration * Assume {{val|500|u=kW}} is converted into fast ions. * ''n'' = {{val|5|e=19|u=m<sup>−3</sup>}} * β = 1 (field = {{val|0.1|u=T}}) * ''V'' = 0.2 m<sup>3</sup>, {{val|1170|u=J}} total energy * Peak ''T''<sub>i</sub> = {{val|75|u=eV}} * Peak ''T''<sub>e</sub> = {{val|250|u=eV}} * Peak sheath loss = {{val|228|u=kW}}, about equal to ''P''<sub>ei</sub> * Peak ring cusp loss = {{val|15|u=kW}} * Peak axial cusp loss = {{val|1|u=kW}}
===TX Reactor=== Parameters: * 7 m diameter × 18 m long, 1 m thick blankets * 320 MW gross * 40 MW heating power, 2.3 s * ''n'' = {{val|5|e=20|u=m<sup>−3</sup>}} * β = 1 (field = 2.3 T) * ''V'' = 16.3 m<sup>3</sup>, 51 MJ total energy * ''T''<sub>i</sub> = 9.6 keV * ''T''<sub>e</sub> = 12.6 keV == Intellectual property == In February 2018, Lockheed Martin was granted one patent.<ref>{{Patent|US|20180047462A1|Encapsulating Magnetic Fields for Plasma Confinement}}. [https://patents.google.com/patent/US20180047462A1/en Google patent database]</ref> It applied for three others.<ref>{{US patent application | number = 2014301518 | issue-date = | inventor = Thomas John McGuire | title = Magnetic Field Plasma Confinement for Compact Fusion Power }}</ref><ref>{{US patent application | number = 2014301519 | issue-date = | inventor = Thomas John McGuire | title = Heating Plasma for Fusion Power Using Magnetic Field Oscillation }}</ref><ref>{{US patent application | number = 2014301517 | issue-date = | inventor = Thomas John McGuire | title = Active Cooling of Structures Immersed in Plasma }}</ref>
== Criticism == Physics professor and director of the [[Culham Centre for Fusion Energy|UK's national Fusion laboratory]] [[Steven Cowley]] called for more data, pointing out that the current thinking in fusion research is that "bigger is better". Other fusion reactors achieve 8 times improvement in heat confinement when machine size is doubled.<ref name=cowl>{{citation |author=McGarry, Brendan |url=http://defensetech.org/2014/10/16/scientists-skeptical-of-lockheeds-fusion-breakthrough/ |title=Scientists Skeptical of Lockheed's Fusion Breakthrough |work=DefenseTech' |date=16 October 2014 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
== See also == {{commons category}} * [[ARC fusion reactor]] * [[Beta (plasma physics)]] * [[Fusion power]] * [[Fusor]] * [[Inertial electrostatic confinement]] * [[Magnetic mirror]] * [[Polywell]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/products/compact-fusion.html Lockheed Martin Compact Reactor design page] * {{youtube|id=UlYClniDFkM|title=Lockheed Martin Compact Fusion}} * [[Solve for X]]: {{youtube|id=JAsRFVbcyUY|title=Charles Chase on energy for everyone}} February 11, 2013

revision.text:
{{for|usage in law|Miscarriage of justice}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Miscarriage | synonyms = Spontaneous abortion, early pregnancy loss | image = Anembryonic gestation.jpg | caption = An [[ultrasound]] showing a [[gestational sac]] containing a [[yolk sac]] but no [[embryo]]. | field = [[Obstetrics]] and [[gynecology]] | symptoms = [[Vaginal bleeding]] with or without pain | complications = Infection, bleeding,{{cite web|title=Spontaneous Abortion - Gynecology and Obstetrics|url=https://www.merckmanuals.com/en-ca/professional/gynecology-and-obstetrics/abnormalities-of-pregnancy/spontaneous-abortion|website=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|accessdate=5 May 2018|language=en-CA}} [[sadness]], [[anxiety]], [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]] | onset = Before 20 weeks of pregnancy | duration = | types = | causes = Chromosomal abnormalities | risks = Being an older parent, previous miscarriage, exposure to tobacco smoke, [[obesity]], [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], [[autoimmune disease]]s, drug or alcohol use | diagnosis = Examination, [[human chorionic gonadotropin]], [[ultrasound]] | differential = [[Ectopic pregnancy]], [[implantation bleeding]]. | prevention = [[Prenatal care]] | treatment = [[Expectant management]], [[misoprostol]], [[vacuum aspiration]], emotional support | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = 10–50% of pregnancies | deaths = }} '''Miscarriage''', also known as '''spontaneous abortion''' and '''pregnancy loss''', is the natural death of an [[embryo]] or [[fetus]] before it is [[fetal viability|able to survive independently]].{{cite web|title=What is pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/default.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121055/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Some use the cutoff of 20 weeks of [[gestation]], after which fetal death is known as a [[stillbirth]].{{cite web|title=Stillbirth: Overview|url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/stillbirth/Pages/default.aspx|website=NICHD|accessdate=4 October 2016|date=23 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005085055/https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/stillbirth/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=October 5, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The most common symptom of a miscarriage is [[vaginal bleeding]] with or without pain. [[Sadness]], [[anxiety]] and [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]] often occur afterwards.{{cite journal|last1=Robinson|first1=GE|title=Pregnancy loss|journal=Best Practice & Research. Clinical Obstetrics & Gynaecology|date=January 2014|volume=28|issue=1|pages=169–78|pmid=24047642|doi=10.1016/j.bpobgyn.2013.08.012}}{{Cite journal|last=Radford|first=Eleanor J|last2=Hughes|first2=Mark|date=2015-06-01|title=Women's experiences of early miscarriage: implications for nursing care|journal=Journal of Clinical Nursing|language=en|volume=24|issue=11–12|pages=1457–1465|doi=10.1111/jocn.12781|pmid=25662397|issn=1365-2702}} [[Tissue (biology)|Tissue]] and clot-like material may leave the uterus and pass through and out of the [[vagina]].{{cite web|title=What are the symptoms of pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/symptoms.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402113638/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/symptoms.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} When a woman keeps having miscarriages, [[infertility]] is present.{{Cite web|url=https://www.womenshealth.gov/glossary/|title=Glossary {{!}} womenshealth.gov|website=womenshealth.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-09-11}}{{PD-notice}} Risk factors for miscarriage include an older parent, previous miscarriage, exposure to tobacco smoke, [[obesity]], [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], thyroid problems, and drug or alcohol use. About 80% of miscarriages occur in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy (the [[first trimester]]). The underlying cause in about half of cases involves [[chromosomal abnormalities]].{{cite journal|last1=Vaiman|first1=Daniel|title=Genetic regulation of recurrent spontaneous abortion in humans|journal=Biomedical Journal|volume=38|issue=1|year=2015|pages=11–24|doi=10.4103/2319-4170.133777|pmid=25179715}} Diagnosis of a miscarriage may involve checking to see if the [[cervix]] is open or closed, testing blood levels of [[human chorionic gonadotropin]] (hCG), and an [[ultrasound]].{{cite web|title=How do health care providers diagnose pregnancy loss or miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/diagnosed.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15}} Other conditions that can produce similar symptoms include an [[ectopic pregnancy]] and [[implantation bleeding]]. Prevention is occasionally possible with good [[prenatal care]]. Avoiding drugs, alcohol, infectious diseases, and [[radiation]] may decrease the risk of miscarriage.{{cite web|title=Is there a cure for pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/cure.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-10-21|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402181042/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/cure.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} No specific treatment is usually needed during the first 7 to 14 days. Most miscarriages will complete without additional interventions. Occasionally the medication [[misoprostol]] or a procedure such as [[vacuum aspiration]] is used to remove the remaining tissue.{{cite journal|last1=Tunçalp|first1=O|last2=Gülmezoglu|first2=AM|last3=Souza|first3=JP|title=Surgical procedures for evacuating incomplete miscarriage|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=8 September 2010|issue=9|pages=CD001993|pmid=20824830|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001993.pub2}} Women who have a blood type of [[rhesus negative]] (Rh negative) may require [[Rho(D) immune globulin]].{{cite journal|last1=Oliver|first1=A|last2=Overton|first2=C|title=Diagnosis and management of miscarriage|journal=The Practitioner|date=May 2014|volume=258|issue=1771|pages=25–8, 3|pmid=25055407}} [[Pain medication]] may be beneficial. Emotional support may help with negative emotions.{{cite web|title=What are the treatments for pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/treatments.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121052/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/treatments.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Miscarriage is the most common [[Complication (medicine)|complication]] of early [[pregnancy]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0055257/|title=Ectopic Pregnancy and Miscarriage: Diagnosis and Initial Management in Early Pregnancy of Ectopic Pregnancy and Miscarriage|last=National Coordinating Centre for Women's and Children's Health (UK)|date=December 2012|website=NICE Clinical Guidelines, No. 154|publisher=Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|accessdate=4 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020003707/http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0055257/|archivedate=October 20, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Among women who know they are pregnant, the miscarriage rate is roughly 10% to 20%, while rates among all [[fertilisation]] is around 30% to 50%.{{cite book|title=The Johns Hopkins Manual of Gynecology and Obstetrics|date=2012|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9781451148015|pages=438–439|edition=4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Sg5sXyiBvkC&pg=PA438|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910181311/https://books.google.com/books?id=4Sg5sXyiBvkC&pg=PA438|archivedate=September 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=How many people are affected by or at risk for pregnancy loss or miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/risk.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093633/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/risk.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} In those under the age of 35 the risk is about 10% while it is about 45% in those over the age of 40. Risk begins to increase around the age of 30. About 5% of women have two miscarriages in a row.{{cite journal|last1=Garrido-Gimenez|first1=C|last2=Alijotas-Reig|first2=J|title=Recurrent miscarriage: causes, evaluation and management|journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal|date=March 2015|volume=91|issue=1073|pages=151–162|pmid=25681385|doi=10.1136/postgradmedj-2014-132672}} Some recommend not using the term "abortion" in discussions with those experiencing a miscarriage in an effort to decrease distress.{{cite book|last1=Greaves|first1=Ian|last2=Porter|first2=Keith|last3=Hodgetts|first3=Tim J.|last4=Woollard|first4=Malcolm|title=Emergency Care: A Textbook for Paramedics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Z3cMX7owGwC&pg=PA506|date=2005|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|location=London|isbn=978-0-7020-2586-0|page=506|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426205606/https://books.google.com/books?id=2Z3cMX7owGwC&pg=PA506|archivedate=April 26, 2016|df=mdy-all}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Signs and symptoms== Signs of a miscarriage include [[vaginal spotting]], [[abdominal pain]], [[cramps|cramping]], and [[amniotic fluid|fluid]], [[blood clots]], and [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]] passing from the [[vagina]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/diagnosed.aspx|title=How do health care providers diagnose pregnancy loss or miscarriage?|website=www.nichd.nih.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-07}}{{sfn|Hoffman|page=176}}{{Cite journal|title= Chinese herbal medicines for threatened miscarriage; Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|journal = Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue = 5|pages = CD008510|last=Li|first=Lu|last2=Dou|first2=Lixia|last3=Leung|first3=Ping Chung|last4=Wang|first4=Chi Chiu|date=2012-05-16|isbn = |language=en|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd008510.pub2|pmid = 22592730}} [[Bleeding]] can be a symptom of miscarriage, but many women also have bleeding in early pregnancy and don't miscarry.{{Cite news|url=https://medlineplus.gov/miscarriage.html|title=Miscarriage {{!}} Miscarriage Symptoms {{!}} MedlinePlus|access-date=2017-09-09|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170728020027/https://medlineplus.gov/miscarriage.html|archivedate=July 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{PD-notice}} Bleeding during pregnancy may be referred to as a threatened miscarriage. Of those who seek clinical treatment for bleeding during pregnancy, about half will miscarry.{{cite journal | author = Everett C | title = Incidence and outcome of bleeding before the 20th week of pregnancy: Prospective study from general practice | journal = BMJ | volume = 315 | issue = 7099 | pages = 32–4 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9233324 | pmc = 2127042 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.315.7099.32 }} Miscarriage may be detected during an ultrasound exam, or through serial [[human chorionic gonadotropin]] (HCG) testing. ==Risk factors== {{See|List of miscarriage risks}} Miscarriage may occur for many reasons, not all of which can be identified. [[Risk factor]]s are those things that increase the likelihood of having a miscarriage but don't necessarily cause a miscarriage. Up to 70 conditions,{{sfn|Hoffman|page=181–182}}{{Cite journal|last=Ali|first=Osman|last2=Hakimi|first2=Ihssane|last3=Chanana|first3=Adil|last4=Habib|first4=My Abdellah Baba|last5=Guelzim|first5=Khalid|last6=Kouach|first6=Jaouad|last7=Rahali|first7=Driss Moussaoui|last8=Dehayeni|first8=Mohammed|date=2015|title=[Term pegnancy on septate uterus: report of a case and review of the literature]|journal=The Pan African Medical Journal|volume=22|pages=219|doi=10.11604/pamj.2015.22.219.7790|issn=1937-8688| pmc=4760728 |pmid=26955410}}{{cite journal|last1=Tersigni|first1=C.|last2=Castellani|first2=R.|last3=de Waure|first3=C.|last4=Fattorossi|first4=A.|last5=De Spirito|first5=M.|last6=Gasbarrini|first6=A.|last7=Scambia|first7=G.|last8=Di Simone|first8=N.|year=2014|title=Celiac disease and reproductive disorders: meta-analysis of epidemiologic associations and potential pathogenic mechanisms|journal=Human Reproduction Update|volume=20|issue=4|pages=582–593|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmu007|issn=1355-4786|pmid=24619876}}{{sfn|Hoffman|page = 172}} infections,{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Miscarriage/Pages/Causes.aspx|title=Miscarriage - Causes - NHS Choices|first=NHS|last=Choices|website=www.nhs.uk}}{{cite journal|last=American College of Obstetricians and|first=Gynecologists|title=ACOG Practice Bulletin No.142: Cerclage for the management of cervical insufficiency|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=Feb 2014|volume=123|issue=2 Pt 1|pages=372–9|pmid=24451674|doi=10.1097/01.AOG.0000443276.68274.cc}}{{cite journal|last1=Lis|first1=R.|last2=Rowhani-Rahbar|first2=A.|last3=Manhart|first3=L. E.|title=Mycoplasma genitalium Infection and Female Reproductive Tract Disease: A Meta-Analysis|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|year=2015|issn=1058-4838|doi=10.1093/cid/civ312|pmid=25900174|volume=61|issue=3|pages=418–26}} medical procedures,{{cite journal|year=2010|title=Update on procedure-related risks for prenatal diagnosis techniques|journal=Fetal Diagnosis and Therapy|volume=27|issue=1|pages=1–7|doi=10.1159/000271995|pmid=20051662|vauthors=Tabor A, Alfirevic Z}}{{cite journal|date=August 2012|title=Pregnancy loss after chorionic villus sampling and genetic amniocentesis in twin pregnancies: a systematic review|journal=Ultrasound in Obstetrics & Gynecology|volume=40|issue=2|pages=128–34|doi=10.1002/uog.10152|pmid=22125091|vauthors=Agarwal K, Alfirevic Z}}{{Cite book|title=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|last=Alfirevic|first=Zarko|last2=Navaratnam|first2=Kate|last3=Mujezinovic|first3=Faris|date=2017-09-04|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd|isbn = |language=en|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd003252.pub2/abstract|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all|doi-broken-date = 2018-09-08}} lifestyle factors,{{cite journal |vauthors=Ness RB, Grisso JA, Hirschinger N, Markovic N, Shaw LM, Day NL, Kline J | title = Cocaine and Tobacco Use and the Risk of Spontaneous Abortion | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 340 | issue = 5 | pages = 333–9 | year = 1999 | pmid = 9929522 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199902043400501 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Miscarriage/Pages/Causes.aspx|title=Miscarriage - Causes - NHS Choices|last=Choices|first=NHS|website=www.nhs.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-09-10}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Venners SA, Wang X, Chen C, Wang L, Chen D, Guang W, Huang A, Ryan L, O'Connor J, Lasley B, Overstreet J, Wilcox A, Xu X | title = Paternal Smoking and Pregnancy Loss: A Prospective Study Using a Biomarker of Pregnancy | journal = American Journal of Epidemiology | volume = 159 | issue = 10 | pages = 993–1001 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15128612 | doi = 10.1093/aje/kwh128 }} occupational exposures,{{sfn|Hoffman|page=173}}{{sfn|Hoffman|page=272}} chemical exposure,{{sfn|Hoffman|page=272}} and shift work are associated with increased risk for miscarriage.{{cite journal|last1=Chavarro|first1=Jorge E.|last2=Rich-Edwards|first2=Janet W.|last3=Gaskins|first3=Audrey J.|last4=Farland|first4=Leslie V.|last5=Terry|first5=Kathryn L.|last6=Zhang|first6=Cuilin|last7=Missmer|first7=Stacey A.|title=Contributions of the Nurses' Health Studies to Reproductive Health Research|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=106|issue=9|year=2016|pages=1669–1676|issn=0090-0036|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2016.303350|pmid=27459445|pmc=4981818}}(review) Some of these risks include [[endocrine system|endocrine]], [[genetics|genetic]], [[uterus|uterine]], or [[hormone|hormonal abnormalities]], [[reproductive tract infection]]s, and [[tissue rejection]] caused by an [[autoimmune disorder]].{{Cite journal|last=Acién|first=Pedro|last2=Acién|first2=Maribel|date=2016-01-01|title=The presentation and management of complex female genital malformations|url=https://academic.oup.com/humupd/article/22/1/48/2457890|journal=Human Reproduction Update|language=en|volume=22|issue=1|pages=48–69|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmv048|pmid=26537987|issn=1355-4786}} ===First trimester=== {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center" |+Chromosomal abnormalities found in first trimester miscarriages !Description !Percent of total first trimester miscarriage |- |[[XY sex-determination system|Normal]] |45-55% |- |[[Trisomy|Autosomal trisomy]] |22-32% |- |[[Turner syndrome| Monosomy X (45, X)]] |5-20% |- |[[Triploid syndrome|Triploidy]] |6-8% |- |[[Chromosome abnormality#Structural abnormalities|Structural abnormality]] of
the chromosome |2% |- |[[Double trisomy|Double]] or triple trisomy |0.7-2%{{sfn|Hoffman|page=171}} |- |Translocation |unknownhttps://www.acog.org/-/media/For-Patients/faq100.pdf?dmc=1&ts=20150820T1255284207 |} Most clinically apparent miscarriages (two-thirds to three-quarters in various studies) occur during the first trimester.{{cite web | last = Rosenthal | first = M. Sara | title = The Second Trimester | website = The Gynecological Sourcebook | publisher = WebMD | year = 1999 | url = http://www.webmd.com/content/article/4/1680_51802.htm | accessdate = December 18, 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061201085538/http://www.webmd.com/content/article/4/1680_51802.htm | archivedate = December 1, 2006 | df = mdy-all }}{{Cite book|title=Williams Obstetrics|last=Cunningham|first=F, Leveno KJ, Bloom SL, Spong CY, Dashe JS, Hoffman BL, Casey BM, Sheffield JS|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=5|chapter=Abortion}} About 30% to 40% of all fertilized eggs miscarry, often before the pregnancy is known. The embryo typically dies before the pregnancy is expelled; bleeding into the decidua basalis and tissue necrosis causes uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. Early miscarriages can be due to a developmental abnormality of the placenta or other embryonic tissues. In some instances an embryo does not form but other tissues do. This has been called a "blighted ovum".{{Cite news|url=http://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-complications/blighted-ovum/|title=Blighted Ovum: Symptoms, Causes and Prevention|date=2012-04-26|work=American Pregnancy Association|access-date=2017-09-09|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170725113127/http://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-complications/blighted-ovum/|archivedate=July 25, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-loss-miscarriage/expert-answers/blighted-ovum/faq-20057783|title=Blighted ovum: What causes it?|work=Mayo Clinic|access-date=2017-09-09|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720141145/http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-loss-miscarriage/expert-answers/blighted-ovum/faq-20057783|archivedate=July 20, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{sfn|Hoffman|page=171}} Successful implantation of the [[zygote]] into the [[uterus]] is most likely 8 to 10 days after conception. If the zygote has not implanted by day 10, implantation becomes increasingly unlikely in subsequent days.{{cite journal | vauthors=Wilcox AJ, Baird DD, Weinberg CR | title=Time of implantation of the conceptus and loss of pregnancy | journal=[[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume=340 | issue=23 | pages=1796–1799 | year=1999 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199906103402304 | pmid=10362823 | deadurl=no | df=mdy-all }} A chemical pregnancy is a pregnancy that was detected by testing but ends in miscarriage before or around the time of the next expected period.{{cite book|last1=Condous|first1=edited by Tom Bourne, George|title=Handbook of early pregnancy care|date=2006|publisher=Informa Healthcare|location=London|isbn=9780203016213|pages=28–29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Y3PyNvc6dcC&pg=PA29|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910181311/https://books.google.com/books?id=_Y3PyNvc6dcC&pg=PA29|archivedate=September 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Chromosomal abnormalities are found in more than half of embryos miscarried in the first 13 weeks. Half of embryonic miscarriages (25% of all miscarriages) have an [[aneuploidy]] (abnormal number of chromosomes).{{cite journal|year=1980|title=Anatomic and chromosomal anomalies in 639 spontaneous abortuses|journal=Human Genetics|volume=55|issue=1|pages=87–98|doi=10.1007/BF00329132|pmid=7450760|vauthors=Kajii T, Ferrier A, Niikawa N, Takahara H, Ohama K, Avirachan S}} Common chromosome abnormalities found in miscarriages include [[Trisomy|autosomal trisomy]] (22-32%), [[Turner syndrome|monosomy X]] (5-20%), [[Polyploid|triploidy]] (6-8%), [[tetraploidy]] (2-4%), or other structural chromosomal abnormalities (2%). Genetic problems are more likely to occur with older parents; this may account for the higher rates observed in older women.{{cite web | title = Pregnancy Over Age 30 | website=MUSC Children's Hospital | url = http://www.musckids.com/health_library/hrpregnant/over30.htm | accessdate = December 18, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061113233603/http://www.musckids.com/health_library/hrpregnant/over30.htm |archivedate = November 13, 2006}} There is no evidence that progesterone given in the first trimester reduces the risk of miscarriage, and luteal phase progesterone deficiency may or may not be a contributing factor to miscarriage.{{cite journal | author = Wahabi HA, Fayed AA, Esmaeil SA, Al Zeidan RA | title = Progestogen for treating threatened miscarriage | journal = Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | issue = 12 | pages = CD005943 | year = 2011 | pmid = 22161393 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD005943.pub4 | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0013622/ | editor1-last = Wahabi | editor1-first = Hayfaa A | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131020003112/http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0013622/ | archivedate = October 20, 2013 | df = mdy-all }}{{Update inline|reason=Updated version https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30081430|date = November 2018}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Bukulmez O, Arici A | title = Luteal phase defect: Myth or reality | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology Clinics of North America | volume = 31 | issue = 4 | pages = 727–44, ix | year = 2004 | pmid = 15550332 | doi = 10.1016/j.ogc.2004.08.007 }} ===Second and third trimesters=== Second trimester losses may be due to maternal factors such as [[uterine malformation]], growths in the uterus ([[Uterine fibroid|fibroid]]s), or [[Cervical incompetence|cervical problems]]. These conditions also may contribute to [[premature birth]]. Unlike first-trimester miscarriages, second-trimester miscarriages are less likely to be caused by a genetic abnormality; chromosomal aberrations are found in a third of cases. Infection during the third trimester can cause a miscarriage. === Age === {{Further|Advanced maternal age}} The age of the pregnant woman is a significant risk factor. Miscarriage rates increase steadily with age, with more substantial increases after age 35.{{cite journal|author=Bray I, Gunnell D, [[George Davey Smith|Davey Smith G]]|year=2006|title=Advanced paternal age: How old is too old?|journal=Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health|volume=60|issue=10|pages=851–3|doi=10.1136/jech.2005.045179|pmc=2566050|pmid=16973530}} In those under the age of 35 the risk is about 10% while it is about 45% in those over the age of 40. Risk begins to increase around the age of 30. Paternal age is associated with increased risk.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=175}} ===Obesity, eating disorders and caffeine=== Not only is obesity associated with miscarriage, it can result in sub-fertility and other adverse pregnancy outcomes. Recurrent miscarriage is also related to obesity. Women with [[bulimia nervosa]] and [[anorexia nervosa]] may have a greater risk for miscarriage. Nutrient deficiencies have not been found to impact miscarriage rates but [[hyperemesis gravidarum]] sometimes precedes a miscarriage. {{sfn|Hoffman|page=173}} [[Caffeine]] consumption also has been correlated to miscarriage rates, at least at higher levels of intake. However, such higher rates have been found to be statistically significant only in certain circumstances. Vitamin supplementation has generally not shown to be effective in preventing miscarriage.{{Cite journal|title=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|journal = Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue = 5|pages = CD004073|last=Balogun|first=Olukunmi O|last2=da Silva Lopes|first2=Katharina|last3=Ota|first3=Erika|last4=Takemoto|first4=Yo|last5=Rumbold|first5=Alice|last6=Takegata|first6=Mizuki|last7=Mori|first7=Rintaro|date=2016-05-06|isbn = |language=en|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd004073.pub4|pmid = 27150280}} Chinese traditional medicine has not been found to prevent miscarriage. ===Endocrine disorders=== Disorders of the thyroid may affect pregnancy outcomes. Related to this, iodine deficiency is strongly associated with an increased risk of miscarriage.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=173}} The risk of miscarriage is increased in those with poorly controlled insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=173}} Women with well-controlled diabetes have the same risk of miscarriage as those without diabetes.{{cite book|author=Fred F. Ferri|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2017|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1198|year=2017|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-0-323-28048-8|page=1198}}{{cite book|author1=Sumita Mehta|author2=Bindiya Gupta|title=Recurrent Pregnancy Loss|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5KZWDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA185|year=2018|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-981-10-7337-3|page=185}} ===Food poisoning=== Ingesting food that has been contaminated with [[listeriosis]], [[toxoplasmosis]], and [[salmonella]] is associated with an increased risk of miscarriage. ===Amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling=== Amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling are procedures conducted to assess the fetus. A sample of amniotic fluid is obtained by the insertion of a needle through the abdomen and into the uterus. Chorionic villus sampling is a similar procedure with a sample of tissue removed rather than fluid. These procedures are not associated with pregnancy loss during the second trimester but they are associated with miscarriages and birth defects in the first trimester. Miscarriage caused by invasive prenatal diagnosis ([[chorionic villus sampling]] (CVS) and [[amniocentesis]]) is rare (about 1%). ===Surgery=== The effects of surgery on pregnancy are not well-known including the effects of [[bariatric]] surgery. Abdominal and pelvic surgery are not risk factors in miscarriage. Ovarian tumors and cysts that are removed have not been found to increase the risk of miscarriage. The exception to this is the removal of the corpus luteum from the ovary. This can cause fluctuations in the hormones necessary to maintain the pregnancy.{{sfn|Hoffman|pages=172–173}} ===Medications=== Immunizations have not been found to cause miscarriage.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=72}} There is no significant association between [[antidepressant]] medication exposure and spontaneous abortion.{{Cite journal|last=Ross LE|last2=Grigoriadis S|last3=Mamisashvili L|display-authors=etal|date=2013-04-01|title=Selected pregnancy and delivery outcomes after exposure to antidepressant medication: A systematic review and meta-analysis|journal=JAMA Psychiatry|volume=70|issue=4|pages=436–443|doi=10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2013.684|pmid=23446732|issn=2168-622X}} The risk of miscarriage is not likely decreased by discontinuing [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor|SSRI]] prior to pregnancy.{{Cite journal|last=Dalke|first=Katharine Baratz|last2=Wenzel|first2=Amy|last3=Kim|first3=Deborah R.|date=2016-04-19|title=Depression and Anxiety During Pregnancy: Evaluating the Literature in Support of Clinical Risk-Benefit Decision-Making|journal=Current Psychiatry Reports|language=en|volume=18|issue=6|pages=1–12|doi=10.1007/s11920-016-0698-x|pmid=27091646|issn=1523-3812}} Some available data suggest that there is a small increased risk of miscarriage for women taking any [[antidepressant]],{{cite journal|year=2010|title=Gestational exposure to antidepressants and the risk of spontaneous abortion: A review|journal=Current Drug Delivery|volume=7|issue=1|pages=76–92|doi=10.2174/156720110790396508|pmid=19863482|vauthors=Broy P, Bérard A}}{{cite journal|year=2010|title=Use of antidepressants during pregnancy and the risk of spontaneous abortion|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|volume=182|issue=10|pages=1031–7|doi=10.1503/cmaj.091208|pmc=2900326|pmid=20513781|vauthors=Nakhai-Pour HR, Broy P, Bérard A}} though this risk becomes less [[Statistical significance|statistically significant]] when excluding studies of poor quality.{{Cite journal|last=Yonkers|first=Kimberly A.|last2=Blackwell|first2=Katherine A.|last3=Glover|first3=Janis|last4=Forray|first4=Ariadna|date=2014-01-01|title=Antidepressant Use in Pregnant and Postpartum Women|journal=Annual Review of Clinical Psychology|volume=10|issue=1|pages=369–392|doi=10.1146/annurev-clinpsy-032813-153626|pmc=4138492|pmid=24313569}} Medicines that increase the risk of miscarriage include: * retinoids  * nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) , such as ibuprofen * misoprostol  * methotrexate ===Chemotherapy and radiation treatments for cancer=== Ionizing radiation levels given to a woman during cancer treatment cause miscarriage. Exposure can also impact fertility. The use of chemotherapeutic drugs used to treat childhood cancer increases the risk of miscarriage.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=173}} ===Intercurrent diseases=== Several [[intercurrent diseases in pregnancy]] can potentially increase the risk of miscarriage, including diabetes, [[polycystic ovary syndrome]] (PCOS), hypothyroidism, certain infectious diseases, and autoimmune diseases. PCOS may increase the risk of miscarriage. Two studies suggested treatment with the drug [[metformin]] significantly lowers the rate of miscarriage in women with PCOS,{{cite journal |vauthors=Jakubowicz DJ, Iuorno MJ, Jakubowicz S, Roberts KA, Nestler JE | title = Effects of Metformin on Early Pregnancy Loss in the Polycystic Ovary Syndrome | journal = Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism | volume = 87 | issue = 2 | pages = 524–9 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11836280 | doi = 10.1210/jc.87.2.524 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Khattab S, Mohsen IA, Foutouh IA, Ramadan A, Moaz M, Al-Inany H | title = Metformin reduces abortion in pregnant women with polycystic ovary syndrome | journal = Gynecological Endocrinology | volume = 22 | issue = 12 | pages = 680–4 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17162710 | doi = 10.1080/09513590601010508 }} but the quality of these studies has been questioned.{{cite web|last=Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|title=Long-term consequences of polycystic ovarian syndrome|url=http://www.rcog.org.uk/files/rcog-corp/uploaded-files/GT33_LongTermPCOS.pdf|archive-url=https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20100710113119/http://www.rcog.org.uk/files/rcog-corp/uploaded-files/GT33_LongTermPCOS.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-07-10|website=Green-top Guideline No. 27|publisher=Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=December 2007}} Metformin treatment in pregnancy has not been shown to be safe.{{cite journal |vauthors=Lilja AE, Mathiesen ER | title = Polycystic ovary syndrome and metformin in pregnancy | journal = Acta Obstetricia et Gynecologica Scandinavica | volume = 85 | issue = 7 | pages = 861–8 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16817087 | doi = 10.1080/00016340600780441 }} In 2007 the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists also recommended against use of the drug to prevent miscarriage. Thrombophilias or defects in coagulation and bleeding were once thought to be a risk in miscarriage but have been subsequently questioned.{{sfn|Hoffman|page=174}} Severe cases of [[hypothyroidism]] increase the risk of miscarriage.
