A short text attached to an ordinance regulating the Upper Shrine's ritual purity [[Taboo|taboos]] (物忌み ''monoimi'') originally enforced in 1238 and revised in 1317, the ''Suwa Kamisha monoimi no rei no koto'' (諏訪上社物忌令之事),{{cite journal|last1=Takei|first1=Masahiro|title=祭事を読む-諏訪上社物忌令之事- (Saiji wo yomu: Suwa Kamisha monoimi no rei no koto)|journal=飯田市美術博物館 研究紀要 (Bulletin of the Iida City Museum)|date=1999|volume=9|pages=121–144|url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110008434555}} relates that the Suwa deity, 'Takeminakata Myōjin' (武御名方明神), was originally the ruler of [[Mahajanapada|a certain Indian kingdom]] called 'Hadai' (波堤国 ''Hadai-koku''){{efn|This place name appears as one of the sixteen [[Mahajanapada|Mahājanapadas]] in [[Kumārajīva]]'s translation of the [[Humane King Sutra]].{{cite web|title=十六大国一覧表|url=http://www.sakya-muni.jp/pdf/mono15_s02_hu01.pdf|website=原始仏教聖典資料による釈尊伝の研究 (A Study of the Biography of Sakya-muni Based on the Early Buddhist Scriptural Sources)}}{{cite web|title=佛說仁王般若波羅蜜經 第2卷|url=http://tripitaka.cbeta.org/T08n0245_002|website=CBETA (Chinese Buddhist Electronic Text Association) 漢文大藏經}}}} who survived an insurrection instigated by the rebel Moriya (守屋 or 守洩) during the king's absence while the latter was out hunting deer. After going to [[Persia]] to rescue its inhabitants from an evil dragon, the king ruled over it for some time as 'Emperor Suwa' (陬波皇帝 ''Suwa Kōtei'') before retiring to "cultivate the seedling of virtue [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|and realize the Buddhist path]]." He eventually manifested in Japan, appearing in various places before finally choosing to dwell in Suwa.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 114-116.Takei (1999), pp. 129–130.Miyachi (1931b). p. 84.{{efn|(Version 1) 「當社明神者、遠異朝雲、分近南浮之巷狹、其名武御名方明神申。去者、和光古尋、波提國主〆文月未ノ比鹿野苑之御狩、守洩逆臣奉制、遁其難、廣大慈悲之得名給。(...) 南方波斯國御幸成、惡龍降伏シ、萬民救治、彼國諏方皇帝申セリ。到東方金色山、善苗植テ佛道成給。其後我朝移給、接州蒼海顯、垂跡ヲ三韓西戎之逆浪、諏テハ西宮顯ル、又ハ豐前高山麓光和、百王南面之護、寶祚誓給南宮申也、終ハ勝地信濃國諏方郡垂跡 ...」
(Version 2) 「當社明神者、遠分異朝雲、近交南浮塵給、申其名建御名方明神、去ハ和光之古ヲタツヌル、波提國ノ王トシテ文月未比鹿野苑御狩ノ時、奉襲守屋逆臣カ其難ヲノカレ、廣大慈悲之得名給。(...) 南方幸波斯國、降伏惡龍、救萬民、彼國ヲ治メ、爲陬波皇帝。東方至金色山、殖善苗成佛給。其後移我朝給テ、接州蒼海邊ニ垂迹、鎭三韓西戎之逆浪、表西宮、又ハ濃州高山ノ麓ニ和光、守百王南面之寶祚誓玉申南宮、終ニ卜勝地於信濃諏方郡垂跡給 ...」 :(When) the god (''myōjin'') of this shrine... as king of the land of 'Hadai', went to hunt at Deer Park in [[Japanese calendar#Months|the month of Fumizuki]], during the hour of the [[Earthly Branches|sheep]], subdued the renegade Moriya, he escaped from the calamity and received the name 'the immensely compassionate one'... :Going south (sic) to the land of [[Persia]], he defeated an evil dragon, rescuing its people. He ruled that land as Emperor Suwa. :Arriving at a golden mountain in the east, he cultivated the seedling of virtue and attained [[buddhahood]]. Afterwards he moved to our country, appearing in the sea of [[Settsu Province|Sesshū]] and (pacifying) the chaos of (lit. 'the rough sea of') the [[Xirong]] (of/and the) [[Three Kingdoms of Korea|three Han (kingdoms)]]. :He then (deliberated to) appear in [[Nishinomiya Shrine|Nishinomiya]], and at the foot of (Mount) Takayama in [[Mino Province|Nōshū]] (or: [[Buzen Province]]) he [[Honji suijaku|dimmed his radiance]] (...) Finally he manifested in the goodly district of Suwa in [[Shinano Province|Shinano]] ...}} [[File:御射山神社鳥居 - panoramio.jpg|thumb|left|Misayama Shrine (御射山神社) in [[Fujimi, Nagano|Fujimi]], Nagano. During the medieval period, the hunting ceremony held at Misayama - Suwa Shrine's sacred hunting ground - was the largest of Suwa's religious ceremonies and one of its most important, attracting thousands of people.]] The ''Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba'' relates a slightly different, fuller version of the first half of this story as an origin myth for the Upper Shrine's hunting ceremony held every seventh month of the year at Misayama (御射山) on the slopes of the [[Yatsugatake Mountains]]:
If one should inquire about the origins (因縁 ''in'en'', lit. 'causes and conditions') of this hunt: long ago, the Daimyōjin was the king of the land of Hadai in [[Tianzhu (India)|India]] who went out to hunt at [[Sarnath|Deer Park]] from the twenty-seventh to the thirtieth day of [[Chinese calendar|the seventh month]]. At that time, a traitorous vassal named Bikyō (美教) suddenly organized an army and sought to kill the king. The king, ringing a golden bell, looked up to heaven and shouted eight times: "I am now about to be killed by this rebel. I have hunted animals, not for my own enjoyment, but in order to lead them to the Buddhist path. If this my action is in accordance with Heaven's will, may [[Brahmā]] save me."
Brahmā then saw this and commanded the [[Four Heavenly Kings|four great deva-kings]] to wield [[vajra]]-poles and destroy the army. It is said that the Misayama (三齋山) of today reflects that event.
... One should know, therefore, that the deity's compassionate hunting is an [[Upaya|expedient means]] for the salvation of creatures.Translation based on Grumbach (2005). p. 210.{{efn|「扨も此御狩の因縁をたづぬれば、大明神昔天竺波提國の王たりし時、七月廿七日より同卅日にいたるまで鹿野園に出で狩をせさせ給ひたる時、美教と云亂臣忽に軍を率して王を害し奉らんとす。其時王金鈴を振て、蒼天に仰て八度さけびてのたまはく、『我今逆臣の為に害せられむとす、狩る所の畜類全く自欲の爲にあらず。佛道を成ぜしめむが爲也。是若天意にかなはば、梵天我をすくひたまへ』と。其時梵天眼を以て是を見て、四大天王に勅して金剛杖を執て群黨を誅せしめ給ひにけり。今の三齋山、其儀をうつさるゝ由傳たり。(...)爰に知ぬ、神明慈悲の畋獵は郡類濟度の方便なりと云事を。」{{cite book|editor1-last=Hanawa|editor1-first=Hokiichi|title=諏訪大明神繪詞 (Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba)|date=1914|publisher=Zoku Gunsho-ruijū Kanseikai|series=''[[Gunsho Ruijū|Zoku Gunsho-ruijū]]'' (続群書類従)|volume=3|page=534|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/65}} {{ja icon}}}}
Regarding the Upper Shrine's hunting rituals, the ''Monoimi no rei'' asserts that
[The shrine's] hunts began in the deer park of Hadai-no-kuni [in India]. [The use of] hawks began in [[Magadha|Magada-no-kuni]].Grumbach (2005). p. 206.
The second half of the legend (the slaying of the dragon in Persia and the king's migration to Japan) is used by the ''Ekotoba'''s compiler, Suwa Enchū, in a liturgical text, the ''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki'' (諏方大明神講式),諏方大明神講式 (''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki''), in {{cite book|editor1-last=Takeuchi|editor1-first=Hideo|title=神道大系 神社編30 諏訪 (Shintō Taikei, Jinja-hen vol. 30: Suwa)|date=1982|publisher=Shintō Taikei Hensankai}}{{cite web|title=諏方大明神講式 (''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki'')|url=http://base1.nijl.ac.jp/iview/Frame.jsp?DB_ID=G0003917KTM&C_CODE=KSRM-287105&IMG_SIZE=&PROC_TYPE=null&SHOMEI=%E3%80%90%E8%AB%8F%E6%96%B9%E5%A4%A7%E6%98%8E%EF%A8%99%E8%AC%9B%E5%BC%8F%E3%80%91&REQUEST_MARK=null&OWNER=null&IMG_NO=4|website=国文学研究資料館 (National Institute of Japanese Literature)}} where it is introduced as an alternative, if somewhat less credible, account of the Suwa deity's origins (in comparison to the myth of Takeminakata of Izumo as found in the ''Kuji Hongi'', touted by the same text as the authoritative origin story of the god) that nevertheless should not be suppressed.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). p. 116. =====Ancestry===== [[File:Shaka Nyorai.jpg|thumb|120px|Medieval Buddhist legends claim the Suwa deity to be a relative of [[Gautama Buddha]] (pictured)]] The ''Suwa Daimyōjin Kōshiki'' claims the king of Hadai to be a great-great-grandson of [[Sihahanu|King Siṃhahanu]] (獅子頬王 ''Shishikyō-ō''), [[Gautama Buddha]]'s grandfather.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). p. 115. A similar account appears in a work known as the ''Suwa Jinja Engi'' (諏訪神社縁起) or ''Suwa Shintō Engi'' (諏訪神道縁起),''Suwa Jinja Engi'' (諏訪神社縁起 上下卷), in {{cite book |editor1-last=Suwa Kyōikukai |title=諏訪史料叢書 巻26 (Suwa Shiryō Soshō, vol. 26) |date=1937 |publisher=Suwa Kōikukai |pages=54-64 |url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1185900/41}} wherein the Suwa deity is identified as the son of Kibonnō (貴飯王), the son of Amṛtodana (甘呂飯王 ''Kanrobonnō''), one of Siṃhahanu's four sons. The Lower Shrine's goddess, meanwhile, is the daughter of [[Pasenadi|Prasenajit]] (波斯匿王 ''Hashinoku-ō''), claimed here to be the son of Dronodana (黒飯王 ''Kokubonnō''), another son of Siṃhananu.Miyachi (1931b). p. 85. =====The ''Suwa Mishirushibumi''===== During the Misayama festival as performed during the medieval period, the ''Ōhōri'' recited a [[Norito|ritual declaration]] supposedly composed by the Suwa deity himself known as the ''Suwa Mishirushibumi'' (陬波御記文),Text and commentary in Kanai (1982). pp. 162-172. which begins:
I, Great King Suwa (陬波大王), have hidden my person during [[Sexagenary cycle|[the year/month/day of] the Yang Wood Horse]] (甲午 ''kinoe-uma'').
[The name] 'Suwa' (陬波) and [the sign] Yang Wood Horse [and] the seal (印文){{efn|The 'seal' referred to here is interpreted to be either the Upper Shrine's sacred seal made of deer antlerKanai (1982). p. 167. or the ''Mishirushibumi'' itself.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 117-118.}} - these three are all one and the same.{{efn|「陬波大王　限甲午隠身、陬波与甲午　印文同一物三名。」Kanai (1982). p. 163.}}
[[File:Yabusame00.jpg|thumb|left|[[Yabusame]] archers in hunting gear, Edo period]] Within the text, King Suwa (i.e. Suwa Myōjin) declares the ''Ōhōri'' to be his 'true [[Shintai|body]]' (真神体 ''shin no shintai'') and the Misayama (三斎山) hunting grounds below Yatsugatake (here likened to [[Vulture Peak]] in India) to be another manifestation of himself that cleanses (斎) the three (三) evils: [[Manasa, vacha, karmana|evil thoughts, evil speech and evil actions]].Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 119-120.Kanai (1982). pp. 168-169. He promises that whoever sets foot at Misayama will not fall into [[Saṃsāra (Buddhism)#Realms of rebirth|the lower, evil realms of existence]] (悪趣 ''akushu''); conversely, the god condemns and disowns whoever defiles this place by cutting down its trees or digging out the soil.Kanai (1982). p. 169. A commentary on the ''Mishirushibumi'', the ''Suwa Shichū'' (陬波私注 "Personal Notes on the ''Suwa Mishirusibumi''," written 1313-1314),Text and commentary in Kanai (1982). pp. 173-187. elaborates on the text by retelling the legend of Suwa Myōjin's consecration of his first priest:
The Daimyōjin was born during [the year/month/day of] the Yang Wood Horse and disappeared during [the year/month/day of] the Yang Wood Horse.
Sokutan Daijin (続旦大臣) was the Daimyōjin's uncle who accompanied him from India. When the Daimyōjin was to disappear, he took off his garments, put them on the Daijin, and dubbed him the ''Misogihōri'' (御衣木法理). He then pronounced a vow: "You shall consider this priest to be my body."{{efn|「一、大明神甲午仁有御誕生甲午仁隠御身給フ
一、続旦（ソクタン）大臣ト申ハ大明神ノ叔父御前自リ天竺御同道、大明神御体ヲ隠サセ給シ時御装束ヲ奉抜著（ヌキキセ）彼大臣給テ号御衣木（ミソキ）法理ト 我之躰以法理ヲ躰トセヨトハ誓給シ也」Kanai (1982). pp. 173-174.}}
The same text identifies the god's uncle Sokutan Daijin with Arikazu.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 117, 119.Kanai (1982). pp. 176-177.{{efn|「一、御衣木法理殿御実名ハ者有員云〻」Kanai (1982). p. 175.}} ====As Kōga Saburō==== {{see also|Kōga Saburō}} [[File:Tateshina03.JPG|thumb|right|[[Mount Tateshina]] on the border of the municipalities of [[Chino, Nagano|Chino]] and [[Tateshina, Nagano|Tateshina]] in [[Nagano Prefecture]].]] A popular story promulgated by wandering preachers associated with the shrines of Suwa during the medieval period claimed the Suwa deity to have originally been a man who temporarily became a dragon or a snake after a journey into the underworld.Miyasaka (1987). pp. 51-54.{{cite book|author1=John Breen|author2=Mark Teeuwen|title=Shinto in History: Ways of the Kami|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MADlfH002mAC&pg=PA35|date=January 2000|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2363-4|page=35}}{{cite book|author=Carmen Blacker|title=The Catalpa Bow: A Study of Shamanistic Practices in Japan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mR6PAgAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PA134|date=2 August 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1-135-31872-7}}Kanai (1982). pp. 278–317. Many variants on the basic story exist; the following summary is based on the earliest literary version of the tale found in the ''[[Shintoshu|Shintōshū]]''.諏訪縁起の事 (''Suwa engi-no-koto'') in {{cite book|author=Kishi, Shōzō (trans.)|title=Shintōshū (神道集)|series=Tōyō Bunko (東洋文庫) vol. 94|date=1967|publisher=Heibonsha|isbn=978-4-582-80094-4|pages=238–286}}Kanai (1982). p. 17. The third son of a local [[Jitō|landlord]] of [[Kōka District, Shiga|Kōka District]] in [[Ōmi Province]], a distinguished warrior named Kōga Saburō Yorikata (甲賀三郎諏方) was searching for his lost wife, Princess Kasuga (春日姫 ''Kasuga-hime'') in a cave in [[Mount Tateshina]] in Shinano, with his two elder brothers. The second brother, who was jealous of Saburō's prowess and fame and who coveted Kasuga, traps the latter inside the cave after they had rescued the princess. With no way out, Saburō has no other choice but to go deeper into the cave, which was actually an entrance to various underground realms filled with many wonders. After [[Katabasis#Trip into the underworld|travelling through these subterranean lands for a long period of time]], he finally finds his way back to the surface, only to find himself transformed into a giant snake or dragon. With the help of Buddhist monks (who turn out to be gods in disguise), Saburō regains his human form and is finally reunited with his wife. Saburō eventually becomes Suwa Myōjin, the god of the Upper Shrine of Suwa, while his wife becomes the goddess of the Lower Shrine. This version of the legend explains the origin of the name 'Suwa' (諏訪 or 諏方) via [[folk etymology]] as being derived from Saburō's personal name, Yorikata (諏方).Kishi (trans.) (1967). p. 282. It has been proposed that the Kōga Saburō legend arose as a result of the collapse of the Kamakura shogunate and the downfall of the [[Hōjō clan]], which the Suwa clan had faithfully served as [[Gokenin|retainers]]. The status and prestige of the ''Ōhōri'' having been diminished in the aftermath of these events, localized stories about Suwa Myōjin such as that of Kōga Saburō began to circulate among devotees of the Suwa cult.Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 130-132. ===Arrival in Suwa=== Both the official records of the central Yamato government and local myths agree in portraying the god of Suwa as an outsider who migrated into the region.Grumbach (2005). pp. 155-156. Stories of how Suwa Myōjin arrived in Suwa and established himself therein are related below. ====Entering Shinano==== [[File:Ikushimatarushima-jinja torii.JPG|thumb|200px|Ikushima-Tarushima Shrine (生島足島神社) in [[Ueda, Nagano|Ueda City]]]] One folk story relates that Takeminakata, upon being driven away from Izumo, first went to visit his mother Nunakawahime in [[Koshi Province|Koshi]] before proceeding southwards into Shinano. Upon reaching Azumi (modern [[Kitaazumi District]]) on the northernmost part of the province, the local deity would not let him through the pass of Sanosaka (modern [[Hakuba, Nagano|Hakuba Village]]). Takeminakata temporarily retreated to Mount Minekata (also in Hakuba), where messengers sent by the gods Ikushima-no-Kami (生島神) and Tarushima-no-Kami (足島神) arranged safe passage for him into the province.Imai (1976). p. 37-38. En route to Suwa, Takeminakata visited the gods Ikushima and Tarushima in what is now [[Ueda, Nagano|the city of Ueda]] and offered them [[Congee|gruel]].Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai, ed. (2017b). p. 106. [[File:Ono-jinja (Shiojiri) keidai.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Ono Shrine (小野神社) in [[Shiojiri, Nagano|Shiojiri]]]] Before entering Suwa, Takeminakata stayed for some time in what is now Ono Shrine in [[Shiojiri, Nagano|Shiojiri]], as he tried to find a way to defeat the god Moreya.Imai (1976). pp. 39-40.Tanigawa, ed. (1987). p. 379. Ono Shrine's Nenjiribō Matsuri held in January 6th, a contest in which locals scramble for long wooden poles,{{cite web |title=小野神社ねんじり棒祭 |url=http://www.82bunka.or.jp/bunkazai/detail.php?no=2336&seq=0 |website=The Hachijuni Culture Foundation |publisher=The Hachijuni Culture Foundation}} is claimed in legend to have been originally devised by Takeminakata and his retinue as a way to boost their morale during their stay.Imai (1976). p. 40.Tanigawa, ed. (1987). p. 381. ====Moreya==== {{see also|Moreya}} [[File:Fujishima Shrine (藤島社).png|thumb|Fujishima Shrine (藤島社) in what is now [[Suwa City]] during the early 20th century. It is one of two 'Fujishima Shrines' associated with Suwa Myōjin's battle against Moreya; the other is located in [[Okaya, Nagano|the city of Okaya]] by the Tenryū River.]] One god that opposed Suwa Myōjin upon his arrival in Suwa according to local myths was the god [[Moreya]] (Moriya). Suwa Nobushige's 1249 petition relates a story from "the ancient customs" (舊貫) that the Suwa deity came down from heaven in order to take possession of the land of Moriya Daijin (守屋大臣). The conflict between the two escalated into a battle, but as no winner could be declared, the two finally compete in a [[tug of war]] using hooks (''kagi''): Suwa Myōjin, using a hook made out of the [[wisteria]] plant (藤鎰), emerges victorious against Moriya, who used an iron hook (鐵鎰). After his victory, the god built his dwelling (what would become the Upper Shrine) in Moriya's land and planted the wisteria hook, which became a grove known as the 'Forest of Fujisuwa' (藤諏訪之森 ''Fujisuwa no mori'').{{efn|「一 守屋山麓御垂跡事
右謹檢舊貫、當砌昔者守屋大臣之所領也、大神天降御之刻、大臣者奉禦明神之居住、勵制止之方法、明神者廻可爲御敷地之祕計、或致諍論、或及合戰之處、兩方難決雌雄、爰明神者持藤鎰、大臣者以鐵鎰、懸此所引之、明神即以藤鎰令勝得軍陣之諍論給、而間令追罰守屋大臣、卜居所當社以來、遙送數百歲星霜、久施我神之稱譽天下給、應跡之方々是新哉、明神以彼藤鎰自令植當社之前給、藤榮枝葉號藤諏訪之森、毎年二ヶ度御神事勤之、自尓以來以當郡名諏方、爰下宮者當社依夫婦之契約示姫大明神之名、然而當大明神、若不令追出守屋給者、爭兩者卜居御哉、自天降之元初爲本宮之條炳焉者哉、」}} The ''Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba'' relates a variant of this myth as an origin story of Fujishima Shrine in [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]], one of the Upper Shrine's [[Setsumatsusha|auxiliary shrines]] where its yearly rice-planting ceremony is traditionally held.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). pp. 681-683.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 88-91.{{cite web|title=藤島社・藤島大明神|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/hujisimasya.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}}{{cite web|title=諏訪大社上社「御田植祭」|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sinji/otaue.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} In this version, the Suwa deity defeats "Moreya the evil outlaw" with a wisteria branch:
As for this so-called Fujishima no Myōjin (藤島明神): long ago, when the revered deity (尊神 ''sonshin'') [[Honji suijaku|manifested himself]], Moreya the evil outlaw (洩矢の惡賊) sought to hinder the god's stay and fought him with an iron ring (鐵輪), but the ''Myōjin'', taking up a wisteria branch (藤の枝), defeated him, thus finally subduing heresy (邪輪 ''jarin'', lit. "wheel/circle/ring of evil") and establishing [[Dharma (Buddhism)|the true Dharma]]. When the Myōjin swore an oath and threw the wisteria branch away, immediately it took root [in the ground], its branches and leaves flourishing in abundance, and [sprouted] beautiful blossoms, leaving behind a marker of the battleground for posterity. 'Fujishima no Myōjin' is named thus for this reason.{{efn|「抑此藤島の明神と申は。尊神垂迹の昔。洩矢の惡賊神居をさまたげんとせし時。洩矢は鐵輪を持してあらそひ。明神は藤枝を取りて是を伏し給ふ。終に邪輪を降して正法を興す。明神誓を發て。藤枝をなげ給しかば。則根をさして枝葉をさかへ花蘂あざやかにして。戰場のしるしを萬代に殘す。藤島の明神と號此故也。」}} Hanawa, ed. (1914). p. 530.Kanai (1982). p. 262.
[[File:Fujishima Shrine, Okaya City (藤島神社 岡谷市).jpg|thumb|Fujishima Shrine (藤島神社) in [[Okaya, Nagano|Okaya]]]] The ''Suwa Daimyojin Kōshiki'' integrates this story into the legend of the king of Hadai by portraying Moreya as an incarnation of Bikyō, the rebel who raised up an army against the king in India (cf. the version in the ''Monoimi no rei'', wherein the king is opposed by a rebel named 'Moriya').Fukuda; Nihonmatsu; Tokuda, eds. (2015). pp. 114-115. In later versions of this story which combine it with the ''kuni-yuzuri'' myth, Moreya opposes Takeminakata after the latter had fled from Izumo. After being defeated, Moreya swears fealty to Takeminakata and becomes a faithful ally.Imai (1960). pp. 3-15.Imai (1976). p. 41. Moreya is reckoned as the divine ancestor of the Moriya (守矢) clan, one of the former priestly lineages of the Upper Shrine.Moriya, Sanae (2017). ''守矢神長家のお話し (Moriya Jinchōke no ohanashi),'' in {{cite book |editor=Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum |title=神長官守矢史料館のしおり (Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan no shiori)|pages=2–3|publisher=Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum|edition=3rd}} {{ja icon}} While earlier sources such as Nobushige's petition and the ''Ekotoba'' situate the battle between the two gods somewhere in the vicinity of the Upper Shrine (modern [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]]),{{cite web |title=洩矢神社 岡谷市川岸橋原 |url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/moreya.htm |website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記） |publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} modern retellings instead place it on the banks of the [[Tenryū River]] (modern [[Okaya, Nagano|Okaya City]]).{{cite web |title=洩矢神社 (Moriya Shrine) |url=http://www.nagano-jinjacho.jp/shibu/04nansin/02suwa/4030.html |website=長野県神社庁 (Nagano-ken Jinjachō)}} [[File:Tatsuya-Sukura Shrine , 達屋酢蔵神社 - panoramio (1).jpg|left|thumb|Tatsuya-Sukura Shrine (達屋酢蔵神社) in [[Chino, Nagano|Chino]], associated with the gods Yatsukao (Ganigawara) and Hikosachi in folklore]] ====Yatsukao (Ganigawara)==== Another god that is said to have opposed Suwa Myōjin and his new ally Moreya in local folklore was Yatsukao-no-Mikoto (矢塚男命), also known as Ganigawara (蟹河原長者 ''Ganigawara-chōja'').Kobuzoku Kenkyūkai, ed. (2017b). p 79.{{cite web|title=蟹河原 （茅野市ちの横内）|url=http://tateshina-times.jp/?p=7866|website=たてしなの時間|publisher=蓼科企画}}''Shinano-no-kuni Kansha Suwa-jinja Jinchōkan Moriya-ke Ryaku-keizu'' (信濃國官社諏訪神社神長官守矢家略系圖), in {{cite book|author1=Nobukawa, Kazuhiko (延川和彦)|author2=Iida, Kotaro (飯田好太郎)|title=諏訪氏系図 続編 (Suwa-shi Keizu, Zokuhen)|date=1921|page=19|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/927368/21}} After Moreya's defeat, Ganigawara held Moreya in contempt for surrendering to Takeminakata and had messengers publicly harass him by calling him a coward. When Ganigawara's servants began to resort to violence, Takeminakata retaliated by invading Ganigawara's turf. Mortally wounded by an arrow in the ensuing battle, Ganigawara begs forgiveness from Moreya and entrusts his youngest daughter to Takeminakata, who gives her in marriage to the god Taokihooi-no-Mikoto (手置帆負命) a.k.a. Hikosachi-no-Kami (彦狭知神){{efn|Both Taokihooi and Hikosachi - identified as two distinct individuals - appear in the ''[[Nihon Shoki]]''{{cite wikisource |title=Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|wslink=Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|chapter=Book II |last=Aston |first=William George |authorlink=William George Aston |year=1896 |publisher=Kegan Paul, Trench, Trübner & Co. |location=London |page=81 |pages= |scan=Page:Nihongi_by_Aston.djvu/112|quote=Thereupon Ta-oki-ho-ohi no Kami, ancestor of the Imbe of the Land of Kii, was appointed hatter, Hiko-sachi no Kami was made shield-maker ...}}{{cite wikisource |wslink=zh:日本書紀|chapter=卷第二|title=日本書紀|quote=既以紀伊國忌部遠祖手置帆負神、定爲作笠者。狹知神、爲作盾者。}} and the ''[[Kogo Shūi]]''{{cite wikisource |wslink=zh:古語拾遺|title=古語拾遺|quote=手置帆負命。讚岐國忌部祖也。產狹知命。紀伊國忌部祖也。}} as ancestors of the Inbe clan (忌部氏).}}, who was injured by Ganigawara's messengers as he was keeping watch over Takeminakata's abode.Imai (1960). pp. 42-49.Imai (1976). pp. 46-51. [[File:ShunsenOgama.jpg|thumb|left|''Ōgama'' (大蝦蟇) from the ''[[Ehon Hyaku Monogatari]]'']] ====Other deities==== A few scattered local legends make reference to other deities who either submitted to the Suwa deity or refused to do so. In one legend, a god named Takei-Ōtomonushi (武居大伴主 or 武居大友主) swore allegiance to Suwa Myōjin and became the ancestor of a line of priests in the Lower Shrine known as the ''Takeihōri'' (武居祝).Miyasaka (1987). p. 22. Another story relates that the Suwa deity forbade the goddess of Sakinomiya Shrine in Owa, [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]] from building a bridge over the creek before her shrine as punishment for her refusal to submit to him.{{cite web |title=先宮神社 |url=https://www.jinriki.info/kaidolist/koshukaido/kamisuwa_shimosuwa/sakinomiyajinja.html |website=人力（じんりき）- 旧街道ウォーキング}} ===Subduing the toad god=== Two texts, the ''Monoimi no rei''Kanai (1982). pp. 165.Takei (1999), p. 134. and the ''Suwa Shichū'' (陬波私注 "Personal Notes on the ''Suwa Mishirusibumi''," written 1313-1314),Text and commentary in Kanai (1982). pp. 173-187. mention an oral legend about Suwa Myōjin pacifying the waves of the [[Four Seas|four seas]] by subduing an unruly and savage [[toad]] god (蝦蟆神).{{efn|「正一月日之蝦蟆狩之事　蝦蟆神成　大荒神　惱乱天下時、大明神彼ヲ退治御座し時、四海静謐之間、陬波卜云字ヲ波陬なりと讀り、口傅多し」(''Monoimi no rei'') :Concerning the Frog Hunting (Ceremony) of New Year's Day. :When the toad god turned into a greatly violent deity and caused trouble to [[Tianxia#Japan|all under heaven]], the ''Daimyōjin'' subdued it; the [[Four Seas|four seas]] then became tranquil. :The term 'Suwa' (陬波) means (lit. 'is read as') "a corner wave" (''namishizuka'', i.e. a wave lapping onto the sea's edgeTakei (1999), p. 139.). Many oral legends exist [about this event].}}{{efn|「一、陬波ト申事ナミシツカナリトヨメリ　蝦蟆カニタ神カエルノ事ナリ荒神惱ト天下時、大明神退治之御坐時 四海静謐之間 陬波卜云〻 口傅在之」(''Suwa Shichū'')}} After defeating the toad, Suwa Myōjin then blocked the way to its dwelling - a hole leading to the underwater palace of the [[Ryūjin|dragon god of the sea]], the [[Ryūgū-jō]] - with a rock and sat on it (御座石 ''Goza-ishi'' or 石(之)御座 ''ishi no goza'' "stone seat").{{efn|「一、御座石ト申ハ正面之内二在リ、件之蝦蟆神之住所之穴通龍宮城エ、退治蝦蟆神、破穴以石塞其ノ上坐玉シ間、名ヲ石之御座ト申也 口傅在之」(''Monoimi no rei'') :The so-called ''Goza-ishi'' is located within the ''Shōmen'' (i.e. the ''Kamisha'''s inner sanctum). :The toad god lived in a hole that led to the dragon king's palace (''[[Ryūgū-jō]]''). When [the ''Daimyojin''] subdued the toad god, he blocked the hole with a stone and sat on it. :The stone is thus named ''ishi no goza'' ('stone seat'). This [story] exists in oral legends.}}{{efn|「石御座ト申ハ 件蝦蟆神 住所之穴通龍宮城 退治蝦蟆神彼穴 以石ヲフタキテ 其上ニ坐シ給間 石御座リ申也 口傅在之」(''Suwa Shichū'')}}Kanai (1982). pp. 165, 177-179.Takei (1999), p. 136-137.{{cite web|title=蛙狩神事　元旦|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sinji/kawazu.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} This story functions as an [[Etiology|etiological legend]] for the annual sacrifice of frogs held every [[Japanese New Year|New Year's Day]] in the Suwa ''Kamisha'' ([[Takeminakata#As god of hunting|see below]])Miyasaka (1992). p. 20 as well as yet another [[folk etymology]] for the toponym 'Suwa', here explained as deriving from a term for a wave lapping onto the sea's edge (陬波 ''namishizuka'').Kanai (1982). pp. 177-178. The portrayal of Suwa Myōjin's enemy as a toad or a frog also hints at Suwa Myōjin's character as a serpentine water god, frogs being preyed upon by snakes. (As a point of comparison, the obscure snake god [[Ugajin]] was also credited with defeating a malevolent frog deity.{{cite book|last1=Hara|first1=Naomasa|title=龍蛇神: 諏訪大明神の中世的展開 (Ryūjashin: Suwa Daimyōjin no chūseiteki tenkai)|date=2012|publisher=Ningensha|isbn=978-4931388710|pages=40-41|language=Japanese}}) The toad god itself has been interpreted either as representing the native deities [[Mishaguji]] and/or Moreya, with its defeat symbolizing the victory of the cult of Suwa Myōjin over the indigenous belief system,Takei (1999). pp. 137-138.Kanai (1982). p. 68. or as a symbol of the Buddhist concept of the [[three poisons]] (ignorance, greed, and hatred), which Suwa Myōjin, as [[Honji suijaku|an incarnation]] of the bodhisattva [[Samantabhadra]], his esoteric aspect [[Vajrasattva]] and the [[Wisdom King]] [[Trailokyavijaya]] (interpreted as a form of Vajrasattva), is said to destroy. The current whereabouts of the ''Goza-ishi'' is unclear. The ''Monoimi no rei'' claims it to have been located "within the ''Shōmen''" (正面之内ニ在リ, i.e. the 'upper plateau' (上壇 ''jōdan'') of the ''Kamisha Honmiya'' where the inner sanctum is) and reckons it as one of seven sacred stones or rocks (七石 ''nana-ishi'') associated with the shrine.Hara (2012). p. 59.{{cite web|title=諏訪七石「小玉石・児玉石」|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/suwa7isi.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} While three of the seven stones are indeed located within the ''Kamisha Honmiya'' - the ''Suzuri-ishi'' (硯石),{{cite web|title=硯石（諏訪七石）|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/zatugaku/iwakura.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} the ''(O)kutsu-ishi'' (御沓石),{{cite web|title=御沓石（諏訪七石）|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/zatugaku/okutu.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} and the ''Kaeru-ishi'' (蛙石){{cite web|title=「蛙石」諏訪七石|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/zatugaku/kaeru.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} or ''Kabuto-ishi'' (甲石) - none of these are currently referred to as ''Goza-ishi''.Hara (2012). p. 62.{{cite web|title=「御座石」 諏訪七石|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/zatugaku/gozaisi.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} Nevertheless, attempts have been made to identify the ''Goza-ishi'' with any one of these three rocks.Hara (2012). pp. 65-71. Hara (2012) proposes the ''Goza-ishi'' to have been the same rock as the ''Kaeru-ishi'' / ''Kabuto-ishi'' (the precise location of which is itself under dispute), noting that two sources from the [[Edo period]] both claim the ''Kaeru-ishi'' to be beneath a stone [[pagoda]] once located in the inner sanctum known as the ''Tettō'' (鉄塔 "[[Vajrasattva#Shingon Buddhism|iron tower]]"; [[Takeminakata#Under shinbutsu-shūgō|see below]]), considered before the [[Shinbutsu bunri|separation of Buddhism and Shinto]] in the [[Meiji period]] to be the physical 'body' (''[[Shintai|go-shintai]]'') of the god of Suwa and the ''Kamisha'''s main object of worship,Hara (2012). p. 69-71. and that the 18th-century traveller and [[ethnologist]] Sugae Masumi (菅江真澄, 1754-1829{{cite book|author1=Louis Frédéric|translator=Roth, Käthe|title=Japan Encyclopedia|date=2002|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0674017535|page=908|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA908}}) reported that the frogs sacrificed during the New Year's Day ritual were offered up to an ''iwakura'' (磐座, a 'rock-throne' or sacred rock) in the shrine. [[File:Suwa taisha Kamisha Honmiya , 諏訪大社 上社 本宮 - panoramio (46).jpg|thumb|500px|A flight of steps leading up to the ''Kamisha Honmiya'''s ''[[Heiden (Shinto)|hei]]-[[Haiden (Shinto)|haiden]]''. The Tenryūsui-sha is the building to the right of the stairs.]]Meanwhile, a map of the ''Kamisha'' dating to the [[Tenshō (Momoyama period)|Tenshō period]] (1573-1592) depicts a rock labelled ''Goza-ishi'' located beside the Tenryūsui-sha (天流水舎), a building with a hole or pipe in its roof meant to collect the three drops of water said to miraculously trickle into it everyday no matter the weather.Hara (2012). p. 68.{{cite web|title=天流水舎・宝殿の天滴|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/zatugaku/tenryuu.htm|website=諏訪大社と諏訪神社（附･神社参拝記）|publisher=八ヶ岳原人}} One author has interpreted this to mean that the ''Goza-ishi'' was moved outside the inner sanctum once Buddhism became more firmly entrenched in the shrine and ''iwakura'' worship became less important.{{cite book|last1=Imai|first1=Hiroki|title=諏訪大社 (Suwa Taisha)|date=1980|publisher=Shinano Mainichi Shimbun-sha|page=228}}, as cited in Hara (2012). p. 68. However, no such rock currently exists beside the edifice. Outside of the ''Kamisha'', [https://www.google.co.jp/maps/place/%E3%80%92391-0003+Nagano-ken,+Chino-shi,+Honmachihigashi,+%EF%BC%91%EF%BC%95+%E5%BE%A1%E5%BA%A7%E7%9F%B3%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE/@36.0027084,138.1710517,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x601c50db13b93c69:0x87545471877b8e69!8m2!3d36.0027077!4d138.1732468 Goza-ishi Shrine]Tanigawa (1987). pp. 162-164. (御座石神社, also ''Gozansho''{{cite web|title=御座石神社「諏訪七石・御座石」　茅野市本町|url=http://yatsu-genjin.jp/suwataisya/sanpo/gozaisi.htm|website=八ヶ岳原人}}) in the city of [[Chino, Nagano]] houses a stone which is sometimes identified with the elusive ''Goza-ishi''.Kanai (1982). p. 179. Kanai (1982) meanwhile believed the ''Goza-ishi'' to originally refer to a large boulder in the artificial Lake Shirakaba{{cite web|title=Lake Shirakaba|url=https://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/spot/natuscen/lake-shirakaba.html|website=Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) Official Website}} ([[:ja:白樺湖|白樺湖]]), a former [[wetland]] at the foot of [[Mount Tateshina]], underneath which a cavern containing ancient pottery and stoneware{{cite web|title=茅野市尖石縄文考古館 (Togariishi Museum of Jōmon Archaeology)|url=http://www.city.chino.lg.jp/www/contents/1448540271429/index_k.html|website=Official website of Chino City}} - interpreted by Kanai to be ritual goods and a sign that the area once had religious significance - was discovered when a [[levee breach]] drained the lake in 1954.Hara (2012). pp. 60-61. [[File:Suwa-myojin.png|thumb|left|Suwa Daimyōjin as depicted in the ''[[Butsuzōzui]]'' (originally published 1690).]] ===Travel to Izumo=== According to a local folktale, Suwa Myōjin is one of the very few ''kami'' in Japan who do not leave their shrines during the month of [[Kannazuki]], when most gods are thought to gather at [[Izumo Province]] and thus are absent from most of the country. The folktale relates that Suwa Myōjin once came to Izumo in the form of a dragon so gigantic that only his head can be seen; his tail was still at Suwa, caught in a tall pine tree by the shores of the lake. The other gods, upon seeing him, were so astounded and frightened at his enormous size that they exempted him from attending their yearly meetings.Matsutani, Miyoko (1960). ''Shinano no minwa'' (信濃の民話). Miraisha. p. 48, cited in Kanai (1982). p. 7.{{cite web|title=Shinano no kuni no Kannazuki (信濃の国の神無月)|url=http://minwa.fujipan.co.jp/area/nagano_012/|website=Fuji Baking Co., Ltd.}} The supposed tree where the dragon's tail was caught (currently reduced to a stump) is locally known as ''Okakematsu'' ({{nihongo|尾掛松}}).{{cite web|title=Okakematsu (尾掛松)|url=http://suwaarea-examine.com/okakematu.html|website=Mahoroba Suwa-ken (まほろば諏訪圏)|access-date=2015-01-05}} A variant of this story transposes the setting from Izumo to the [[Kyoto Imperial Palace|Imperial Palace]] in [[Kyoto]]; in this version, the various ''kami'' are said to travel to the ancient capital every [[Japanese New Year|New Year's Day]] to greet the emperor.Ōbayashi, Taryō (1987). "Seikūkan no kōsei genri. Bunka-jinruigaku no shiten kara (聖空間の構成原理―文化人類学の視点から)." In {{cite book|author1=Ueda|author2=Gorai|author3=Ōbayashi|author4=Miyasaka, M.|author5=Miyasaka, Y.|title=Onbashira-sai to Suwa-taisha|pages=97–98}} ===''Omiwatari''=== [[Pressure ridge (ice)|Cracks and ridges]] that form on a frozen [[Lake Suwa]] during cold winters have traditionally been interpreted as the trail left behind by Suwa Myōjin as he leaves the ''Kamisha'' and crosses the lake to meet his wife enshrined on the ''Shimosha'' on the opposite (northern) shore.{{cite book|author=Japan. Dept. of railways|title=The Hot Springs of Japan (and the Principal Cold Springs) Including Chosen (Korea) Taiwan (Formosa) South Manchuria, Together with Many Tables Giving Classification, Chemical Basis, Curative Values, Radio-activity, Etc. 196 Illustrations, 15 Maps, Specially Drawn, 2 Colored Lithographs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=smA0AAAAMAAJ|year=1922|page=194}} Called ''Omiwatari'' (御神渡 'the god's crossing' or 'the god's pathway'), the cracks were considered to be a good omen for the coming year.{{cite news|title=Ice phenomenon warms up hearts in the Lake Suwa region|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2012/03/03/national/ice-phenomenon-warms-up-hearts-in-the-lake-suwa-region/#.WRpvc9SLRRA|agency=The Japan Times|date=2012-03-03}} The priests of the Grand Shrine of Suwa traditionally used the crack's appearance to divine the quality of the year's harvest.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 38-40. For the locals, the crack also served as a sign that the frozen lake was safe to walk upon.{{cite web|last1=Brazil|first1=Mark|title=Omi-watari|url=http://www.japanvisitor.com/about-japan/omi-watari|website=Japan Visitor}}Miyasaka (1992). p. 42. Conversely, the ''omiwatari'''s failure to appear at all (明海 ''ake no umi'') or the cracks forming in an unusual way were held to be a sign of bad luck for the year. Since the late 20th century, the ''omiwatari'' has become a much rarer sight than it was in the past due to rising temperatures caused by [[global warming]].{{cite book|editor1-last=Ichikawa|editor1-first=Atsunobu|title=Global Warming — The Research Challenges: A Report of Japan's Global Warming Initiative|date=2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1402029417|pages=34–35|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uXNHBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT34}}{{cite web|last1=Borre|first1=Lisa|title=Lake Suwa's Shinto Legend and the Oldest Lake Ice Record on Earth: What It Tells Us About Climate Change and Variability|url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2016/04/26/lake-suwas-shinto-legend-and-the-oldest-lake-ice-record-on-earth-what-it-tells-us-about-climate-change-and-variability/|website=National Geographic}} ===As god of war=== ====Apparition to Sakanoue no Tamuramaro==== The association of Suwa Myōjin with warfare and hunting is most apparent in another legend about his apparition to the general [[Sakanoue no Tamuramaro]] during the latter's campaign to subjugate the [[Emishi]] of northeastern Japan.諏訪大明神秋山祭の事 (''Suwa Daimyōjin Akiyama-sai no koto''), in Kishi (1967). pp. 49–56.{{cite book|last1=Konishi|first1=Jin'ichi|title=A History of Japanese Literature, Volume 3: The High Middle Ages|date=2014|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1400861828|page=526|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=szAABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA526}} The following summary is based on the version found in the ''Ekotoba''.{{cite book|editor=Hanawa|title=''Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba''|date=1914|pages=499–501|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/47}}Kanai (1982). pp. 225-226.{{cite journal|last1=Yamashita|first1=Masaharu|title=訓読・諏訪大明神絵詞 (一) (Kundoku: Suwa Daimyojjn Ekotoba 01)|journal=Annual report of the Institute of Cultural Sciences, Risshō University|date=2006|issue=16|pages=13–14|url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/els/110007324031.pdf?id=ART0009178568&type=pdf&lang=jp&host=cinii&order_no=&ppv_type=0&lang_sw=&no=1365910179&cp=}} [[File:Sakanoue Tamuramaro.jpg|thumb|216px|right|Sakanoue no Tamuramaro is credited with instituting the religious festivities of Suwa-taisha after the god of Suwa came to his aid during the campaigns against the Emishi peoples.]] During the reign of [[Emperor Kanmu]], an Emishi chief named Abe no Takamaru (安倍高丸) staged a rebellion against the imperial court. The emperor, in response, appointed Sakanoue no Tamuramaro as ''[[Shōgun|Sei-i Taishōgun]]'', sending him to [[Mutsu Province|Ōshū]] to quell the Emishi threat. Knowing that Takamaru cannot be defeated without divine aid, Tamuramaro prays to Suwa Myōjin for victory. As he and his troops [[Tōsandō|were passing by]] the [[Ina, Nagano|Ina]] and Suwa districts of Shinano Province, a warrior riding a dapple horse – Suwa Myōjin in disguise – joins their company.Kanai (1982). p. 225. Upon arriving at Takamaru's impregnable stronghold by the sea, the horseman from Shinano miraculously splits into five identical mounted warriors (the manifestations of Suwa Myōjin's thirteen divine children), while twenty men dressed in yellow (the god's attendants) appear from out of nowhere. The horsemen and the men in yellow then begin to hold a ''[[yabusame]]'' ([[mounted archery]]) competition over the surface of the sea, which succeeds in luring Takamaru out of hiding. The horseman then blinds Takamaru with his last remaining arrow as the twenty men in yellow proceed to capture and behead him, mounting his head onto a spear. On the return journey, the warrior's horse suddenly rises into the air as the rider assumes the aspect of a deity attired in [[Sokutai|court dress]]. He then announces to the company his true identity as the god of Suwa and his love of hunting. Tamuramaro questions why the god revels in such an activity that involves taking the lives of sentient beings, to which Suwa Myōjin gives an explanation to the effect that being hunted and killed actually helps sinful and [[Moha (Buddhism)|ignorant]] animals to reach [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|enlightenment]]. He then bequeaths to Tamuramaro a written [[dhāraṇī]] - probably a reference to the ''Suwa Mishirushibumi''Kanai (1982). p. 185. - and finally disappears. In accordance with Suwa Myōjin's request, Tamuramaro then petitions the court to institute the religious festivals of the shrines of Suwa.Kanai (1982). p. 226. ====Repelling the Mongol invasions==== Suwa Myōjin has also been credited with repelling the attempted [[Mongol invasions of Japan]] under [[Kublai Khan]]. The ''[[Taiheiki]]'' recounts a story where a five-colored cloud resembling a serpent (a manifestation of Suwa Myōjin) rose up from [[Lake Suwa]] and spread away westward to assist the Japanese army against the Mongols.{{efn|「如此御祈祷已に七日満じける日、諏訪の湖の上より、五色の雲西に聳き、大蛇の形に見へたり。八幡御宝殿の扉啓けて、馬の馳ちる音、轡の鳴音、虚空に充満たり。日吉の社二十一社の錦帳の鏡動き、神宝刃とがれて、御沓皆西に向へり。住吉四所の神馬鞍の下に汗流れ、小守・勝手の鉄の楯己と立て敵の方につき双べたり。」 :On the seventh day, when the Imperial devotions were completed, from Lake Suwa there arose a cloud of many colours, in shape like a great serpent, which spread away towards the west. The doors of the Temple-treasury of [[Hachiman]] flew open, and the skies were filled with a sound of galloping horses and of ringing bits. In [[Hiyoshi Taisha|the twenty-one shrines of Yoshino]] the brocade-curtained mirrors moved, the swords of the Temple-treasury put on a sharp edge, and all the shoes offered to the god turned towards the west. At [[Sumiyoshi taisha|Sumiyoshi]] sweat poured from below the saddles of the four horses sacred to the deities, and the iron shields turned of themselves and faced the enemy in a line. ... (trans. William George Aston)}}{{cite web|title=太平記 巻第三十九|url=http://j-texts.com/taihei/tk39.html|website=J-TEXTS 日本文学電子図書館}}{{cite book|last1=Aston|first1=William George|title=A History of Japanese Literature|date=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1108081061|page=181|edition=reprint|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xxxoBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA181}}De Visser (1913). p. 202.Ōbayashi (1987). p. 96. The ''Ekotoba'' recounts a similar anecdote about Suwa Myōjin appearing as a great dragon riding on a cloud in the summer of 1279 ([[Kōan (Kamakura period)|Kōan 2]]).{{efn|「後宇多院御宇弘安二年己卯季夏の天。當社神事時。日中に變異あり。大龍雲に乘じて西に向。參詣諸人眼精の及所そこはかとなく。雲間殊にひはたの色ひらひらと見ゆ。一龍か又數龍か。首尾は見えず。何樣にも明神大身を現じて。本朝贔屓の力を入れまします勢なり。」}}{{cite book|editor=Hanawa|title=''Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba''|date=1914|pages=499–510|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/53}}Kanai (1982). pp. 230-231. ==Analysis== ===Takeminakata's absence in other Izumo-related contexts=== Takeminakata's rather abrupt appearance in the ''Kojiki'''s version of the ''kuni-yuzuri'' myth has long puzzled scholars, as the god is mentioned nowhere else in the work, including the genealogy of Ōkuninushi's progeny that precedes the ''kuni-yuzuri'' narrative proper.Chamberlain (1882). [http://sacred-texts.com/shi/kj/kj033.htm Section XXVI.—The Deities the August Descendants of the Deity Master-of-the-Great-Land.] Aside from the parallel account contained in the ''Kuji Hongi'' (which was itself based on the ''Kojiki'''sSuwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). pp. 684-685, 687.), he is altogether absent from the ''Nihon Shoki'''s version of the myth.{{cite wikisource|Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|chapter=Book II|author=Aston, William George|date=1896|pages=68–70}}Miyasaka (1987). p. 18. In addition to this, early sources from Izumo such as the province's ''[[Fudoki]]'' also fail to mention any god named '(Take)minakata'; neither is there any trace of such a deity being worshipped in Izumo in antiquity. Pre-modern authors such as [[Motoori Norinaga]] tended to explain Takeminakata's absence outside of the ''Kojiki'' and the ''Kuji Hongi'' by conflating the god with certain obscure deities found in other sources thought to share certain similar characteristics (e.g. [[Isetsuhiko]]).Motoori, Norinaga (1937). [http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/1109355/81 古事記傳 (''Kojiki-den''), vol. 14] in Motoori Toyokai (ed.), 本居宣長全集 (''Motoori Norinaga Zenshū''), vol. 2. Tokyo: Yoshikawa Kōbunkan. pp. 683–684. (Original work written 1764–1798) While some modern scholars still suppose some kind of connection between the deity and Izumo by postulating that Takeminakata's origins lie either in peoples that migrated from Izumo northwards to Suwa and the [[Hokuriku region]]Muraoka (1969). pp. 60-66. or in Hokuriku itself (a region once under Izumo's [[sphere of influence]]), specifically in [[Echigo Province]] (modern [[Niigata Prefecture]]),Kanai (1982). pp. 8-9. others, in light of the aforementioned silence, think it more likely that the connection between Takeminakata and Izumo was an artificial construct by the ''Kojiki'''s compilers.{{cite book|author=Matsumae, Takeshi|title=Nihon shinwa no nazo ga yoku wakaru hon (日本神話の謎がよく分かる本)|date=2007|publisher=Daiwa Shobō (大和書房)|isbn=978-4-479-39166-1|pages=136–137}} ===The Yamato state's expansion into Suwa=== Yamato rule is thought to have entered Suwa from the south (the modern districts of [[Kamiina District, Nagano|Kamiina]] and [[Shimoina District, Nagano|Shimoina]]) somewhere around the latter half of the 6th century.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). "Suwa-jinja Kamisha Shimosha (諏訪神社上社・下社)". p. 686. The appearance of corridor-type (横穴式石室 ''yokoana-shiki sekishitsu'') ''[[kofun]]'' in the region, markedly different from the mounds (thought to be the tombs of influential local priest-chiefs) built on the southern side of [[Lake Suwa]] - the site of the Suwa ''Kamisha'' - during the 5th-6th centuries, which were characterized by ditches surrounding the burial area, are taken to be the signs of the expansion of the Yamato state in the region.Oh (2011). pp. 160-163. [[File:Shikishima-no-Kanasashi-no-Miya.jpg|thumb|right|A marker standing over the site of the [[Emperor Kinmei]]'s palace, the Shikishima-no-Kanasashi-no-miya (磯城嶋金刺宮), in [[Sakurai, Nara|Sakurai]] (ancient Shikishima), [[Nara Prefecture]]. One of Kinmei's courtiers, Kaneyumi-no-kimi, was said to have been dubbed ''Kanasashi-no-toneri-no-atai'' (金刺舎人直) by the emperor.]] The ''Kuji Hongi''{{cite book|editor=Keizai Zasshisha|title=国史大系 第7巻 (Kokushi-taikei, vol. 7)|date=1898|publisher=Keizai Zasshisha|location=Tokyo|page=413|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/991097/220}} mentions a grandson (or descendant) of Kamuyaimimi-no-Mikoto (a son of [[Emperor Jimmu]]), Takeiotatsu-no-Mikoto, (建五百建命) who was appointed the governor or ''[[kuni no miyatsuko]]'' of Shinano (科野国造) during the reign of [[Emperor Sujin]] (traditionally dated to the 1st century BCE but most likely somewhere around the 4th century CEHall, ed. (1988). p. 350.). The ''Ihon Aso-shi keizu'', of disputed historicity, ([[Takeminakata#The_Misogi-hōri|see above]]) claims that Takeiotatsu's descendant, Kaneyumi-no-kimi (金弓君), served as ''toneri'' (舎人, attendant or palace guard) of the [[Emperor Kinmei]] (reigned 539-571) in his palace, the Kanasashi-no-miya (金刺宮) in modern-day [[Sakurai, Nara|Sakurai City]], [[Nara Prefecture]], receiving the ''[[kabane]]'' ''atai'' (直) from said emperor.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 615. One of Kaneyumi's sons, Mase-gimi (麻背君), who became the ''kuni no miyatsuko'' of Shinano (reestablished for the first time in a few generations), had two sons: the first, Kuratari (倉足), was appointed the administrator (''[[Districts of Japan|kōri no kami''/''hyōtoku]]'') of Suwa district (諏訪評督), while the second, Otoei or Kumako (see [[Takeminakata#The Misogi-no-hōri|above]]), became the priest or ''ōhōri'' of the god of Suwa (諏訪大神大祝).Rekishi REAL Henshūbu, ed. (2016). p. 40.Miyasaka (1992). p. 7.Kanai (1982). pp. 106-109. ===Turnover of authority=== {{see also|Mishaguji|Suwa clan}} The Suwa region during the late [[Yayoi period]] was thought to have been originally populated by autonomous [[village communities]], the chiefs of which also functioned as the ritual heads of their respective communities. These villages were eventually united under a single leader who governed the religious practices of these communities, which were centered around the worship of the god(s) [[Mishaguji]],Oh (2011). pp. 155-163. spirits that were thought to descend upon and [[Animism|inhabit natural objects]] [[List of nature deities|like trees or rocks]] and function as [[List of fertility deities|life-giving]] [[Genius loci|guardians]] of local communities.Miyasaka (1987). pp. 23–30.Tanigawa (1987). pp. 191–194. The legend of the battle between the god [[Moreya]] and Suwa Myōjin ([[Takeminakata#Arrival in Suwa|see above]]) may suggest that the advent of Yamato rule in Suwa during the late 6th century was initially met with resistance, especially on the southern side of Lake Suwa, the stronghold of the indigenous Mishaguji cult. This intransigence was ultimately quelled, and politico-religious rule over the region was soon turned over from an indigenous lineage of priest-chiefs, what would later become known as the Moriya clan (守矢氏), to Yamato-appointed authorities.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). pp. 620-623, 683-688, 694.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 8-11. It was probably around this time that the [[Shamanism|shamanistic]] concept of the ''misogi-hōri''/''ōhōri'', the physical manifestation of an invisible divinity, came into being as a way to subsume native religious practices into the Yamato belief system. The office of ''ōhōri'' was probably meant to rival that of the ''okō'' (神使), a young boy (or boys) who became vessels for Mishaguji during religious rituals who later became interpreted as representatives of the ''ōhōri''.Ōwa (1990). p. 197.Oh (2011). p. 170-175. The priest-chieftain of the Moriya clan meanwhile was integrated into the new system as the ''kan no osa''/''jinchō'' (神長) or ''jinchōkan'' (神長官), the sole priest who could call upon Mishaguji.Oh (2011). p. 157. The Moriya's submission to and cooperation with the new system enabled the local Mishaguji cult to survive underneath it: while officially subservient to the ''ōhōri'', in reality the Moriya ''jinchōkan'', who presided over religious rites, continued to hold actual power while the ''ōhōri'' was but a symbolic figurehead.Oh (2011). p. 158. The ''ōhōri'''s investiture ceremony even involved the ''jinchōkan'' summoning Mishaguji to enter the young candidate's body during the ritual; it is only by being possessed by Mishaguji that the candidate became a god himself.Miyasaka (1987). p. 29. ===The rise of Takeminakata=== Both the Aso and the Suwa clan genealogies refer to the foundation of a sanctuary (社壇) on the southern side of Lake Suwa (where the Suwa ''Kamisha'' currently stands) by Otoei/Kumako, claimed to be in both sources as the first ''ōhōri'', where the "great god of Suwa" (諏訪大神) and other divinities were worshipped in the third month of the second year of the [[Emperor Yōmei]] (587 CE).{{efn|「乙頴 (諏訪大神大祝)：一名神子、又云、熊古　生而八歳、御名方富命大神化現脱着御衣於神子勅曰、吾無体以汝為体、盤余池辺大宮朝二年丁未三月構壇于湖南山麓、祭諏訪大明神及百八十神、奉千代田刺忌串斎之」}}Miyasaka (1992). p. 8.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). pp. 619-620. [[Image:Ono-Yasumaro.jpg|thumb|left|Portrait of Ō no Yasumaro by [[Kikuchi Yōsai]] (19th century)]]In 691 CE, the ''Nihon Shoki'' refers to envoys of the Yamato court going to [[Shinano Province]] to worship "the gods of Suwa and Minochi"(須波水内等神). This reference suggests that the cult of the ''ōhōri'' and the sanctuary at Suwa had become established and influential enough to attract attention from the Yamato imperial court.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 623.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 694. Just twenty years after this, the name '(Take)minakata(tomi)' - which may have originated as a name for (the deity manifest in) the ''ōhōri''Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 686, 693-694. - appears in the historical record for the first time in the ''Kojiki'' (711–712 CE). Due to the absence of Takeminakata in other sources dealing with Izumo, it is thought that the god was interpolated into the ''Kojiki'' by its chief compiler, [[Ō no Yasumaro]], who may have either adapted a preexisting myth or created one outright.Miyasaka (1987). pp. 17–26.Ōwa (1990). pp. 212–214.Oh (2011). pp. 157-158.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). pp. 687–689. Scholars believe various factors were at play for Takeminakata's introduction in the ''Kojiki'''s narrative - one being that Yasumaro's clan, the Ō (太氏; also written variously as 多, 意富, or 於保), were distantly related to the clan who ruled the Suwa region, the Kanasashi-no-toneri (金刺舎人), in that both were supposedly descendants of Kamuyaimimi-no-Mikoto:Miyasaka (1987). p. 19.Ōwa (1990). pp. 213, 220-222. Takeminakata's inclusion in the ''Kojiki'' was thus a means to advertise the 'new' god of the Kanasashi.Ōwa (1990). p. 19. Another possible reason was the special interest [[Emperor Tenmu]] (the one who commissioned both the ''Kojiki'' and the ''Nihon Shoki'') showed to Shinano: the ''Nihon Shoki'' speaks of Tenmu sending envoys to inspect the province "perhaps with the object of having a capital there" in the thirteenth year of his reign.{{cite wikisource|Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|chapter=Book XXIX|author=Aston, William George|date=1896|pages=362, 364}}Kanai (1982). p. 8. While the ''Kojiki'' does not yet explicitly mention the worship of Takeminakata in Suwa, by the following century, we see the name applied to the god worshipped in what is now the Grand Shrine of Suwa: aside from the ''Kuji Hongi'''s (807-936 CE) reference to Takeminakata being enshrined in 'Suwa Shrine in Suwa [[Districts of Japan|District]]' the ''[[Shoku Nihon Kōki]]'' mentions the deity 'Minakatatomi-no-Kami of Suwa District, Shinano Province' (信濃国諏訪郡 ... 南方刀美神) being promoted from rankless (无位) to junior fifth rank, lower grade (従五位下) by the imperial court in the year 842 CE ([[Jōwa (Heian period)|Jōwa]] 9).{{efn|「丁未。奉授信濃國諏方郡无位勳八等南方刀美神從五位下。」}}{{cite web|title=續日本後紀|url=http://www.j-texts.com/chuko/shokukouki.html|website=J－TEXTS 日本文学電子図書館}}{{cite wikisource |chapter=卷第十一|wslink=zh:續日本後紀|plaintitle=''[[Shoku Nihon Kōki]]'' (續日本後紀)}}{{cite web|title=南方刀美神社二座（建御名方富命神）|url=http://21coe.kokugakuin.ac.jp/db/jinja/kindex2.php?J_ID=240101|website=神社資料データベース (Shinto Jinja Database)|publisher=Kokugakuin University}}Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 689. During the 850-60s, Takeminakata and his shrine rose very rapidly in rank (''[[Nihon Montoku Tennō Jitsuroku|Montoku Jitsuroku]]'', ''[[Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku]]''), being promoted to the rank of junior fifth, upper grade (従五位上) in 850 ([[Kashō]] 3),{{efn|「己未。信濃國御名方富命神、健御名方富命前八坂刀賣命神、並加從五位上。」}}{{cite wikisource |chapter=卷第二|wslink=zh:日本文德天皇實錄|plaintitle= ''[[Nihon Montoku Tennō Jitsuroku]]'' (日本文德天皇實錄)}} to junior third (従三位) in 851 ([[Ninju]] 1),{{efn|「乙丑。進信濃國建御名方富命、前八坂刀賣命等兩大神階、加從三位。」}}{{cite wikisource |chapter=卷第三|wslink=zh:日本文德天皇實錄|plaintitle= ''[[Nihon Montoku Tennō Jitsuroku]]'' (日本文德天皇實錄)}} to junior (従二位){{efn|「廿七日甲申。 (...) 信濃國正三位勳八等建御名方冨命神從二位。」}} and then senior second (正二位){{efn|「十一日丁酉。(...) 授信濃國從二位勳八等建御名方富命神正二位。」}} in 859 ([[Jōgan]] 1),{{cite wikisource |chapter=卷第十|wslink=zh:日本三代實錄|plaintitle= ''[[Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku]]'' (日本三代實錄)}} and finally to junior first rank (従一位) in 867 (Jōgan 9).{{efn|「十一日辛亥。信濃國正二位勳八等建御名方富命神進階從一位。」}}{{cite wikisource |chapter=卷第十四|wslink=zh:日本三代實錄|plaintitle= ''[[Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku]]'' (日本三代實錄)}} The influence of the Kanasashi-no-toneri clan is thought to be behind the deity's sudden progress in rank.Ōwa (1990). p. 221-223. After a few decades, the 'Register of Deities' (神名帳 ''Jinmyōchō'') section of the ''[[Engishiki]]'' (927) speaks of the 'Minakatatomi Shrine(s)' (南方刀美神社) as enshrining two deities and being the two [[Myōjin|major ('eminent') shrines]] of Suwa district.{{efn|「諏方郡二座 並大 南方刀美神社二座 名神大」}}{{cite web|title=Engishiki, vol. 10 (延喜式 第十巻)|url=http://supercluster.cias.kyoto-u.ac.jp/berkeley/jhti/cgi-bin/jhti/image.cgi?page=9&kan=10&honname=3|website=Japanese Historical Text Initiative (JHTI)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227231608/http://supercluster.cias.kyoto-u.ac.jp/berkeley/jhti/cgi-bin/jhti/image.cgi?page=9&kan=10&honname=3|archivedate=2017-02-27|df=}} By 940 ([[Tengyō]] 3), the deity had been promoted to the highest rank of senior first (正一位).{{cite web|title=社家の姓氏-諏訪氏-|url=http://www.harimaya.com/o_kamon1/syake/middle/s_suwa.html|website=播磨屋 (www.harimaya.com)}} ===Takeminakata and Suwa Myōjin=== While the above sources (compiled by the imperial court in [[Heian-kyō]]) apply the name '(Take)minakata' to the god of Suwa Grand Shrine, within Suwa itself the god was never worshipped or referred to under that name. A testament to the enduring influence of the pre-Yamato Mishaguji belief system is the fact that many of the religious ceremonies of the Suwa ''Kamisha'' and surviving descriptions of said rituals feature Mishaguji as the focus of worship rather than 'Takeminakata', who never appears at all in these rites.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 671. Even local stories that feature the god of the Suwa ''Kamisha'' recorded in medieval texts ([[Takeminakata#Legends of Suwa Myōjin|see above]]) refer to the deity in question with such generic terms as ''sonshin'' (尊神 'revered deity') or ''[[myōjin]]'' (明神 'manifest deity').Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 688. Takeminakata's portrayal in the ''Kojiki'' and the ''Kuji Hongi'' as one who suffered a humiliating defeat was apparently seen as something of an embarrassment during the Middle Ages, leading to the appearance of alternative stories which portray Suwa Myōjin's origins in a more positive light such as the Kōga Saburō legend. The earliest documents from within (or connected to) Suwa to explicitly call Suwa Myōjin 'Takeminakata' or identify him with the god from Izumo are the ''Monoimi no rei'' (1238) - which refers in passing to Suwa Myōjin's name being 'Takeminakata Myōjin' (武御名方明神) - and the ''[[Suwa Daimyōjin Ekotoba]]'' (1356), the latter creatively retelling the Izumo ''kuni-yuzuri'' legend as found in the ''Kuji Hongi'' by omitting any mention of Takeminakata being defeated.{{cite book|editor1-last=Hanawa|editor1-first=Hokiichi|title=''Suwa Daimyōjin ekotoba'' (諏訪大明神繪詞)|date=1914|publisher=Zoku Gunsho-ruijū Kanseikai|series=''[[Gunsho Ruijū|Zoku Gunsho-ruijū]]'' (続群書類従)|volume=3|pages=494–495|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/936498/45}} {{ja icon}} The ''Ekotoba'''s popularity among a wide audience that included the priestly families of the Suwa Grand Shrine seems to have contributed to eventually cementing the identification of Suwa Myōjin with the Takeminakata of the official histories: Ōkuninushi's son who came to Suwa from Izumo. ==Consort and Offspring== [[File:Suwa taisha akimiya01bs3200.jpg|thumb|left|The ''Akimiya'' (秋宮) or Autumn Shrine, one of the two component shrines of the Suwa ''Shimosha''.]] ===Yasakatome=== Suwa Myōjin's spouse is the goddess {{nihongo|'''Yasakatome-no-Kami'''|八坂刀売神}}, most often considered to be the deity of the Lower Shrine of Suwa or the ''Shimosha''.Muraoka (1969). pp. 5–6. Unlike the relatively well-documented Suwa ''Kamisha'', very little concrete information is available regarding the origins of the ''Shimosha'' and its goddess.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 696. [[Yasakatome]]'s first historical attestation is in the ''Shoku Nihon Kōki'', where the goddess is given the rank of junior fifth, lower grade (従五位下) by the imperial court in the tenth month of [[Jōwa (Heian period)|Jōwa]] 9 (842 CE), five months after the same rank was conferred on Takeminakata.{{efn|「奉授安房國從五位下安房大神正五位下。无位第一后神天比理刀咩命神。信濃國无位健御名方富命前八坂刀賣神。阿波國无位葦稻葉神。越後國无位伊夜比古神。常陸國无位筑波女大神竝從五位下。」}}{{cite web|title=南方刀美神社二座（八坂刀売命神）|url=http://21coe.kokugakuin.ac.jp/db/jinja/kindex2.php?J_ID=240201|website=神社資料データベース (Shinto Jinja Database)|publisher=Kokugakuin University}} As Takeminakata rose up in rank, so did Yasakatome,Miyasaka (1987). pp. 37-38. so that by 867 CE, Yasakatome had been promoted to senior second (正二位). The goddess was finally promoted to senior first rank (正一位) in 1074 ([[Jōhō]] 1). Stories and claims about the goddess are diverse and contradictory. Regarding her parentage for instance, the lore of Kawaai Shrine (川会神社) in [[Kitaazumi District]] identifies Yasakatome as the daughter of [[Watatsumi]], god of the sea,{{cite web|title=八坂刀売神（ヤサカトメノカミ|url=http://japangod.dip.jp/%E5%85%AB%E5%9D%82%E5%88%80%E5%A3%B2%E7%A5%9E.html|website=日本の神様辞典 (Nihon no Kamisama Jiten)}} which has been seen as hinting to a connection between the goddess and the seafaring [[Azumi people|Azumi clan]] ([[:ja:阿曇氏|安曇氏]]).Miyasaka (1987). p. 39. Another claim originating from sources dating from the [[Edo period]] is that Yasakatome was the daughter of Ame-no-yasakahiko (天八坂彦命), a god recorded in the ''Kuji Hongi'' as one of the companions of [[List of Japanese deities#Minor kami|Nigihayahi-no-Mikoto]] when the latter came down from heaven.{{cite book|last1=Ponsonby-Fane|first1=R. A. B.|title=Studies in Shinto & Shrines|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1136893018|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UVO4AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT148}}{{cite web|title=先代舊事本紀卷第三 天神本紀|url=https://miko.org/~uraki/kuon/furu/text/sendaikuji/sendaikuji03.htm|website=私本 先代舊事本紀}} The ice cracks that appear on Lake Suwa during cold winters, the ''omiwatari'' ([[Takeminakata#Omiwatari|see above]]) are reputed in folklore to be caused by Suwa Myōjin's crossing the frozen lake to visit Yasakatome. ====Princess Kasuga==== The Kōga Saburō legend identifies the goddess of the Shimosha with Saburō's wife, whose name is given in some variants of the story as 'Princess Kasuga' (春日姫 ''Kasuga-hime''). ===Children=== In Suwa, a number of local deities are popularly considered to be the children of Suwa Myōjin and his consort. Ōta (1926) lists the following gods:Ōta (1926). pp. 44–45. [[File:Suwa taisha Kamisha Honmiya , 諏訪大社 上社 本宮 - panoramio (19).jpg|thumb|Izuhaya-sha (出早社), an [[Setsumatsusha|auxiliary shrine]] in the ''Kamisha Honmiya'' dedicated to the god Izuhayao (出早雄命), believed to be one of Suwa Myōjin's offspring.]] *Hikokamiwake-no-Mikoto (彦神別命) *Tatsuwakahime-no-Kami (多都若姫神) *Taruhime-no-Kami (多留姫神) *Izuhayao-no-Mikoto (伊豆早雄命) *Tateshina-no-Kami (建志名神) *Tsumashinahime-no-Kami (妻科姫神) *Ikeno'o-no-Kami (池生神) *Tsumayamizuhime-no-mMikoto (都麻屋美豆姫命) *Yakine-no-Mikoto (八杵命) *Suwa-wakahiko-no-Mikoto (洲羽若彦命) *Katakurabe-no-Mikoto (片倉辺命) *Okihagi-no-Mikoto (興波岐命) *Wakemizuhiko-no-Mikoto (別水彦命) *Moritatsu-no-Kami (守達神) *Takamori-no-kami (高杜神) *Enatakemimi-no-Mikoto (恵奈武耳命) *Okutsuiwatate-no-Kami (奥津石建神) *Ohotsuno-no-Kami (竟富角神) *Ōkunugi-no-Kami (大橡神) ===Claimed descendants=== ====Suwa clan==== {{see also|Suwa clan}} [[File:Jinchoukan-Moriya-shiryoukan_Oohouri-bosho.JPG|thumb|230px|right|The graves of various Suwa ''ōhōri'' within the historical estate grounds of the Moriya clan in Chino, Nagano. Both the [[:ja:神長官守矢史料館|Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum]] and the head [[Mishaguji]] shrine (''sōsha'') are located in the same precincts.]] The [[Suwa clan]] who once occupied the position of head priest or ''ōhōri'' of the Suwa ''Kamisha'' traditionally considered themselves to be descendants of Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata,{{cite book|last1=Picken|first1=Stuart D.B.|title=Historical Dictionary of Shinto|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-7172-4|page=288|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xlG3F6gSm9UC&pg=PA288}}Inoue (2003). p. 352.{{cite book|author=Rekishi REAL Henshūbu (歴史REAL編集部) (ed.)|title=Jinja to kodai gōzoku no nazo (神社と古代豪族の謎)|date=2016|publisher=Yosensha|isbn=978-4800308924|page=40}} {{ja icon}} although historically they are probably descended from the Kanasashi-no-toneri clan appointed by the Yamato court to govern the Suwa area in the 6th century ([[Takeminakata#Analysis|see above]]).Kanai (1982). pp. 14, 106-109. ====Other clans==== The Suwa ''ōhōri'' was assisted [[Suwa taisha#Kamisha|by five priests]], some of whom were also considered to be descendants of local deities related to Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata. One clan, the Koide (小出氏), the original occupants of the offices of ''negi-dayū'' (禰宜大夫) and ''gi-no-hōri'' (擬祝), claimed descent from the god Yakine.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 728, 731.{{cite book|author=Ōta, Akira|title=日本國誌資料叢書 信濃 (Nihon kokushi shiryō sōsho: Shinano)|date=1924|location=Tokyo|publisher=Isobe Kōyōdō|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/982145/84|page=164}} A second clan, the Yajima (八島(嶋)氏 or 矢島氏), which served as ''gon-no-hōri'' (権祝), considered the god Ikeno'o to be their ancestor.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 730.{{cite book|last1=Sasamoto|first1=Shōji|title=山をめぐる信州史の研究 (Yama wo meguru Shinshū-shi no kenkyū)|date=2003|publisher=Kōshi-shoin|isbn=978-4-906641-66-6|page=72}}{{cite web|title=茅野市神長官守矢史料館 (Chino-shi Jinchōkan Moriya Shiryōkan)|url=http://www.suwa-tourism.jp/archives/000733.php|website=信州諏訪観光ナビ}}{{cite book|last1=Ōta|date=1924|title=Nihon kokushi shiryō sōsho: Nagano|page=160}} ==Worship== ===Shrines=== As the gods of the Grand Shrine of Suwa, Suwa Myōjin/Takeminakata and Yasakatome also serve as the deities of shrines belonging to the Suwa shrine network (諏訪神社 ''Suwa-jinja'') all over Japan. ===As god of wind and water=== [[File:Nagikama.png|thumb|right|''Nagikama'']]The ''Nihon Shoki'''s record of Yamato emissaries worshipping the god of Suwa alongside the gods of [[Tatsuta Shrine]] - worshipped for their power to control and ward off wind-related disasters such as [[drought]]s and [[typhoon]]sHall, ed. (1988). p. 531.{{cite book|last1=Tyler|first1=Royall|title=Japanese No Dramas|date=1992|publisher=Penguin UK|isbn=978-0141907802|page=cclvi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4jf-tJ77z-oC&pg=PR256}}{{cite book|last1=Bock|first1=Felicia Gressitt|title=Engi-shiki; Procedures of the Engi Era: Books VI-X|date=1972|publisher=Sophia University|page=73}} - implies that the Yamato imperial court recognized the deity as a god of [[List of wind deities|wind]] and [[List of water deities|water]] during the late 7th century.{{cite book|editor1-last=Yazaki|editor1-first=Takenori|title=諏訪大社 (Suwa-taisha)|date=1986|publisher=Ginga shobō|series=Ginga gurafikku sensho|volume=4|page=22}} {{ja icon}}Muraoka (1969). p. 17. One theory regarding the origin of the name '(Take)minakata' even supposes it to derive from a word denoting a body of water (水潟 ''minakata''; [[Takeminakata#Etymology|see above]]).Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 686. Snake-shaped iron [[Kama (weapon)|sickle]] blades called ''nagikama'' (薙鎌) were traditionally used in the Suwa region to ward off strong winds, typhoons and other natural disasters; it was once customary for ''nagikama'' to be attached to wooden staves and placed on one corner of the rooftop of the house during the autumn typhoon season.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 172-173.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 677. ''Nagikama'' are also traditionally hammered onto the trees chosen to become the ''[[onbashira]]'' of the Suwa ''Kamisha'' and ''Shimosha'' some time before these are actually felled.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 164-172. In addition to these and other uses, the blades are also distributed to function as ''[[shintai]]'' for branch shrines of the [[Shinto shrine#Shrine networks|Suwa shrine network]].Yazaki, ed. (1986). pp. 98-100.Suwa Shishi Hensan Iinkai, ed. (1995). p. 674. ===Association with snakes and dragons=== Suwa Myōjin's association with the [[Snakes in mythology|snake]] or the [[Japanese dragon|dragon]] in many stories featuring the god such as the Kōga Saburō legend (see [[Takeminakata#Legends of Suwa Myōjin|'Legends of Suwa Myōjin']] above) might be related to his being considered as a deity presiding over wind and water, due to the association of dragons with winds and the rain in Japanese belief.Kanai (1982). pp. 4-7.{{cite book|last1=De Visser|first1=Marinus Willem|title=The Dragon in China and Japan|date=1913|page=153|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mpg6Xd2jW2YC&pg=PA153}} (See also ''[[mizuchi]]''.) [[File:Samantabhadra_Fugen_Bosatsu_Okura.JPG|thumb|left|170px|Suwa Myōjin was once believed to be a manifestation (''suijaku'') of the bodhisattva Samantabhadra.]] ===Under ''shinbutsu-shūgō''=== During the Middle Ages, under the then-prevalent [[Shinbutsu-shūgō|synthesis of Buddhism and Shinto]], Suwa Myōjin was [[honji suijaku|identified]] with the [[bodhisattva]] [[Samantabhadra]] (Fugen),{{cite book|last1=Yoshii|first1=Yoshitaka (ed.)|title=えびす信仰事典 (Ebisu shinkō jiten)|date=1999|isbn=978-4-900901-08-7|page=306|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=glXcN9r6GhAC}}Inoue (2003) p. 354. with the goddess of the ''Shimosha'' being associated with the [[Avalokiteśvara#Thousand-armed Avalokiteśvara|thousand-armed form of the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara]] (Senju Kannon).{{cite book|last1=Miyachi|title=諏訪史 第二卷 (Suwa-shi, vol. 2)|date=1931|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UHYSgY4lTZcC&pg=PA28|pages=75–76}} During the medieval period, [[Jingū-ji|Buddhist temples and other edifices]] were erected on the precincts of both shrines, including a stone [[pagoda]] called the ''Tettō'' (鉄塔 "iron tower") - symbolizing the legendary [[Vajrasattva#Shingon Buddhism|iron tower in India]] where, according to [[Shingon Buddhism|Shingon]] tradition, [[Nagarjuna]] was said to have received esoteric teachings from [[Vajrasattva]] (who is sometimes identified with Samantabhadra) - and a sanctuary to Samantabhadra (普賢堂 ''Fugendō''), both of which served at the time as the ''Kamisha'''s [[Shintai|main objects of worship]].Inoue (2003). pp. 349-350. [[File:Suwa Kamisha Tettō.png|thumb|200px|The ''Kamisha Honmiya'''s Iron Tower or ''Tettō'' photographed during the early 20th century. After the removal or demolition of Buddhist structures in Suwa Shrine following the [[Shinbutsu bunri|separation of Buddhism and Shinto]], this pagoda was moved to Onsenji Temple (温泉寺) in [[Suwa, Nagano|Suwa City]], where it currently resides.]]With the establishment of [[State Shinto]] after the [[Meiji Restoration]] in 1868 and the subsequent [[Shinbutsu bunri|separation of Buddhism and Shinto]], the shrine monks (''shasō'') attached to Buddhist temples in the Suwa shrine complex were laicized, with Buddhist symbols and structures being either removed or destroyed; Buddhist ceremonies performed in both the ''Kamisha'' and the ''Shimosha'', such as the yearly offering of the [[Lotus Sutra]] to Suwa Myōjin (involving the placing of a copy of the sutra inside the ''Tettō''), were discontinued.Inoue (2003). pp. 362-371. ===As god of hunting=== Suwa Myōjin is also worshipped as a [[List of hunting deities|god of hunting]]; not surprisingly, some of the ''Kamisha'''s religious ceremonies traditionally involve(d) ritual [[hunting]] and/or [[animal sacrifice]]. For instance, the Frog Hunting Ritual (蛙狩神事 ''kawazugari shinji'') held every New Year's Day involves the shooting (or rather, piercing) of frogs captured from a sacred river or stream within the ''Kamisha'''s precincts with miniature arrows.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 16-20.Yazaki, ed. (1986). p. 72.Tanigawa (1987). pp. 154-155. This ritual - which has come under harsh criticism from local activists and animal rights groups for its perceived cruelty to the frogs involved{{cite web|title=Suwa taisha skewering live frogs (生きたカエルを串刺しにする諏訪大社)|url=http://blog.livedoor.jp/liablog/archives/1790677.html|website=NGO Life Investigation Agency (LIA)|access-date=2016-01-05}}{{cite web|title=Rabid animal rights activists go head-to-head with tradition|url=https://japantoday.com/category/features/kuchikomi/rabid-animal-rights-activists-go-head-to-head-with-tradition|website=Japan Today}} - was traditionally performed to secure peace and a bountiful harvest for the coming year. Another festival, the ''Ontōsai'' (御頭祭) or the ''Tori no matsuri'' (酉の祭, so called because it was formerly held on the [[Earthly Branches|Day of]] [[Rooster (zodiac)|the Rooster]]) currently held every April 15, feature the offering of seventy-five [[Taxidermy|stuffed deer heads]] (a substitute for freshly cut heads of deer used in the past), as well as the consumption of [[venison]] and other [[Game (hunting)|game]] such as [[wild boar]] or [[rabbit]], various kinds of seafood and other foodstuffs by the priests and other participants in a ritual banquet.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 69-72.Yazaki, ed. (1986). pp. 74-75.Oh (2011). pp. 173-175.Tanigawa (1987). pp. 155-156.Fujimori, Terunobu (1991). ''Maemiya Jikkenrō de no saishi'' (前宮十間廊での祭祀). In Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum, ed. pp. 15–17. One of the Suwa ''Kamisha'''s hunting festivals, the Misayama Festival (御射山祭), formerly held in a field - the ''kōya'' (神野 'the god's plain') - at the foot of the [[Yatsugatake Mountains]] for five days (from the 26th to the 30th of [[Japanese calendar#Months|the seventh month]]),{{efn|Currently three days: from the 26th to the 28th of August.Tanigawa (1987). p. 157.}} was one of the grandest festivals in Suwa during the [[Kamakura period]], attracting many of the [[Samurai|samurai class]] from all across Japan who engaged in displays of [[Yabusame|mounted archery]], bouts of [[sumo wrestling]] and [[Takagari|falconry]] as part of the festivities, as well as people from all walks of life.Tanigawa (1987). pp. 159-160.Yazaki, ed. (1986). pp. 76-77.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 115-118. The ''Shimosha'' also held its own Misayama Festival at the same time as the ''Kamisha'' (albeit in a different location), in which various warrior clans also participated.Tanigawa (1987). pp. 158-159.Miyasaka (1992). pp. 119-124. Suwa Myōjin's association with the mountains and hunting is also evident from the description of the ''ōhōri'' as sitting upon a deer hide (the deer being an animal thought to be sacred to Suwa Myōjin) during the ''Ontōsai'' ritual as practiced during medieval times.Tanigawa (1987). p. 138.Oh (2011). pp. 173. ====Suwa Myōjin and meat eating==== At a time when slaughter of animals and consumption of meat was frowned upon due to [[Mahayana Buddhism]]'s [[Buddhist vegetarianism#Mahayana view|strict views on vegetarianism]] and [[Buddhist ethics#Killing|the general Buddhist opposition against the taking of life]], the cult of Suwa Myōjin was a unique feature in the Japanese religious landscape for its celebration of hunting and meat eating.Kanai (1982). p. 21-23. A four-line verse attached to the Kōga Saburō legend popularly known as the ''Suwa no kanmon'' (諏訪の勘文) encapsulates the justification of meat eating within a Buddhist framework: by being eaten by humans and 'dwelling' inside their bodies, ignorant animals could achieve [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|enlightenment]] together with their human consumers.Kanai (1982). p. 22.Miyasaka (1987). pp. 56-57. {{Quote|text=業尽有情 ''Gōjin ujō'' 雖放不生 ''Suihō fushō'' 故宿人天 ''Koshuku ninten'' 同証仏果 ''Dōshō bukka''See Kanai (1982). pp. 318-319 for attested variants. Sentient beings who have exhausted their [[Karma in Buddhism|karma]]: Even if one [[Animals in Buddhism#Release of animals|sets (them) free]], (they) will not live (for long); Therefore (have them) dwell within humans and [[Deva (Buddhism)|gods]] (That they may) as well achieve [[Buddhahood]]}} The ''Kamisha'' produced special talismans (鹿食免 ''kajiki-men'' "permit to eat [[venison]]") and [[chopsticks]] (鹿食箸 ''kajiki-bashi'') that were held to allow the bearer to eat meat.{{cite web|last1=Nogami|first1=Takahiro|title=Suwa Shinkō|url=http://k-amc.kokugakuin.ac.jp/DM/dbSearchList.do?class_name=col_eos&search_condition_type=1&db_search_condition_type=4&View=2&startNo=1&focus_type=0&searchFreeword=Suwa%20Shink%C5%8D&searchRangeType=0|website=Encyclopedia of Shinto|publisher=Kokugakuin University}}Miyasaka (1987). pp. 55-56.{{cite web|last1=Uehara|first1=Yoshiko|title=Revival of Japan's Wild Game Cuisine|url=http://www.nippon.com/en/views/b01712/|website=nippon.com}}''Kajikimen'' (鹿食免). In Jinchōkan Moriya Historical Museum, ed. (1991). pp. 27–28. Since it was the only one of its kind in Japan, the talisman was popular among hunters and meat eaters.Inoue (2003). p. 352. These sacred licenses and chopsticks were distributed to the public both by the priests of the ''Kamisha'' as well as wandering preachers associated with the shrine known as ''oshi'' (御師), who preached the tale of Suwa Myōjin as Kōga Saburō as well as other stories concerning the god and his benefits. ===As war god=== [[File:Hatajirushi3.png|180px|thumb|right|A depiction of war banners used by the [[Taira clan]] (right) and Takeda Shingen (left). The leftmost banner (white with blue border and red lettering) carries the inscription ''Suwa hosshō-kamishimo-daimyōjin'' (諏訪法性上下大明神).]] [[File:Shingen_Takeda%27s_armour.jpg|180px|thumb|right|A modern reproduction of Takeda Shingen's helmet.]] Suwa Myōjin is also considered to be a [[List of war deities|god of war]], one of a number of such deities in the Japanese pantheon. Besides the legend of the god's apparition to [[Sakanoue no Tamuramaro]] ([[Takeminakata#Apparition to Sakanoue no Tamuramaro|see above]]), the ''[[Songs to Make the Dust Dance on the Beams|Ryōjin Hishō]]'' compiled in 1179 (the late [[Heian period]]) also attest to the worship of the god of Suwa in the capacity of god of warfare at the time of its compilation, naming the shrine of Suwa among famous shrines to martial deities in the eastern half of the country. {{Quote|text=These gods of war live [[Kantō|east of the barrier]]:{{efn|During the Heian period, the expression 'east of the barrier' (関の東 ''seki-no-hi(n)gashi'', whence derives the term 関東 ''Kantō'') referred to the provinces beyond the checkpoints or barrier stations (関 ''seki'') at the eastern fringes of [[Kinai|the capital region]], more specifically the land east of the checkpoint at Ōsaka/Ausaka Hill (逢坂 'hill of meeting', old orthography: ''Afusaka''; not to be confused with the modern city of [[Osaka]]) in modern [[Ōtsu]], [[Shiga Prefecture]].{{cite book|last1=Marshall|first1=Yuko|title=Heterogeneous Japan: The Cultural Distinctions Between Western and Eastern Japan|date=2008|page=6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8EdvhO4Xkn4C&pg=PA6}} By the Edo period, ''Kantō'' was reinterpreted to mean the region east of the checkpoint in [[Hakone]], [[Kanagawa Prefecture]].}} [[Kashima Shrine|Kashima]], [[Katori Shrine|Katori]], Suwa no Miya, and [[Shirahige Shrine|Hira Myōjin]]; also [[Awa Shrine|Su]] in [[Awa Province (Chiba)|Awa]], [[:ja:下立松原神社|Otaka Myōjin]] in [[Shirahama, Chiba|Tai no Kuchi]], [[Kusanagi|Yatsurugi]] in [[Atsuta Shrine|Atsuta]], and [[Tado Shrine|Tado no Miya]] in [[Ise Province|Ise]].|title=''Ryōjin Hishō''|source=song 258{{cite book|last1=Kim|first1=Yung-Hee|title=Songs to Make the Dust Dance: The Ryōjin Hishō of Twelfth-century Japan|date=1994|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=978-0-520-08066-9|pages=144–145a|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SFlSLX-nCeEC&pg=PA144}} {{efn|「関より東(ひむかし)の軍神(いくさがみ)、鹿島・香取(かんどり)・諏訪の宮、また比良(ひら)の明神、安房の洲(す)滝(たい)の口や小鷹明神、熱田に八剣(やつるぎ)、伊勢には多度(たど)の宮。」}}}} During the Kamakura period, the Suwa clan's association with the [[Kamakura shogunate|shogunate]] and the [[Hōjō clan]] helped further cement Suwa Myōjin's reputation as a martial deity.Yazaki (1986). p. 25. The shrines of Suwa and the priestly clans thereof flourished under the patronage of the Hōjō, which promoted devotion to the god as a sign of loyalty to the shogunate. Suwa branch shrines became numerous all across Japan, especially in territories held by clans devoted to the god (for instance, the [[Kantō region]], traditional stronghold of the [[Minamoto]] ([[Seiwa Genji]]) clan).Muraoka (1969). p. 112.
